content: With security giant Symantec's  (SYMC) stock plunging to a 10-month low in early trading Thursday on the heels of its quarterly financial report late Wednesday, "disappointed" CEO Steve Bennett told IBD that the "tough quarter" involved more than 90% of salespeople having new territory assignments amid the security software maker's corporate strategic realignment. Earnings beat, but Symantec cut its…

With security giant Symantec's  (SYMC) stock plunging to a 10-month low in early trading Thursday on the heels of its quarterly financial report late Wednesday, "disappointed" CEO Steve Bennett told IBD that the "tough quarter" involved more than 90% of salespeople having new territory assignments amid the security software maker's corporate strategic realignment. Earnings beat, but Symantec cut its…

Symantec (SYMC) lost a third of its value Friday after the company forecast fiscal 2019 profit and revenue far short of expectations and disclosed an internal investigation driven by concerns raised by a former employee.Shares in the maker of computer security software crashed by more than 33% to close at 19.52 on the stock market today.For the June quarter, Symantec said it expects adjusted profit of 33 cents at its midpoint of guidance, below estimates of 41 cents. It forecast revenue in a range of $1.135 billion to $1.165 billion vs. estimates of $1.19 billion.For full-year fiscal 2019, Symantec forecast revenue in a range of $4.76 billion to $4.9 billion, below estimates of $4.927 billion. The company said it expects adjusted earnings of $1.50 to $1.65 a share, missing views for $1.81.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseSymantec said it has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission about the internal probe, led by its audit committee. The investigation's scope and potential length was not provided by the company. Symantec said it has retained external advisors to assist with the process.For its fiscal fourth quarter ended March 31, Symantec said adjusted earnings were 46 cents a share, up 64% from a year ago, with revenue rising 5% to $1.23 billion, topping analyst estimates. A year earlier, the company earned 28 cents a share on sales of $1.18 billion. Analysts expected earnings of 39 cents on sales of $1.19 billion.Symantec has been making acquisitions to spur growth. It acquired Blue Coat Systems in 2016 for $4.65 billion. Symantec also purchased LifeLock, a provider of consumer identity-theft protection services, for $2.3 billion.IBD's Computer-Software Security group is ranked No. 5 out of 197 industry groups. Palo Alto Networks (PANW)and Qualys (QLYS) have the highest Composite Ratings.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Sell And Take Profits Or Hold? Here Are Several Guidelines To FollowChart-Reading Basics: How A Buy Point Marks A Time Of Real Opportunity

Anti-virus software maker Symantec (SYMC) late Thursday fired CEO and President Steve Bennett, who had cut costs and was amid a major restructuring during his short tenure at the top."This considered decision was the result of an ongoing deliberative process, and not precipitated by any event or impropriety," Chairman Daniel Schulman said in a statement.Symantec stock was down 6.5% in after-hours trading, after the announcement. Symantec stock rose 1.6% in the regular session stock market today, closing at 20.91. The stock is down more than 25% since early August.Director Michael Brown was appointed interim CEO while the company searches for a new leader. Brown joined Symantec's board in July 2005 and formerly served as CEO at Quantum.Bennett joined Symantec as a board member in February 2010 and became chairman in August 2011. Bennett was named CEO and president in July 2012.In January, when the company reported a third consecutive quarter of EPS growth acceleration, Bennett told analysts on a conference call that costs had come down because of "lower spending and increased organizational efficiency."But sales fell 5% in fiscal Q3 ended Dec. 27, the second consecutive quarterly decline.The company in January 2013 split the roles of CEO and chairman, electing board member Schulman to the latter position."Separating the positions of chairman and CEO allows me to focus on executing the company's strategic plan and managing the company's operations and performance," Bennett said in a statement at the time.In an early February Q&A with IBD, Bennett was asked how things were going after most salespeople had been given new territory assignments."When you make that kind of big change, it creates some challenges, and we're still working through those," Bennett said then. "We'll be anxious to see how much progress we make in the fourth quarter. The pipeline looks solid."Symantec is slated to report results for its fiscal Q4 ended on or near March 31 on May 7.In answer to another question in the Q&A, Bennett was candid about the company's challenges, saying, "We're making the hard decision to position the company to win in the long term and taking a little short-term pain to reposition the company."Follow Kevin Shalvey on Twitter at @IBD_KShalveyRelated: Symantec CEO Sees More Work In Security Firm's Revamp
Palo Alto Networks, a leading stock pick, has vaulted higher as it puts a patent dispute to bed and as analysts see its security products in demand at data centers.
Known for network firewalls and other corporate security offerings, Palo Alto Networks (PANW) makes the IBD Leaderboard list of high-potential stocks. On Monday, it pushed up more than 3% to 83.85.

"PANW remains a top pick for 2014, our favorite play on the secular trend toward consolidated network-security functionality," Morgan Stanley analyst Keith Weiss wrote in an early-Monday research note boosting his price target to 105.

Weiss says several factors, including corporate security purchasing plans, bolster his confidence that the company can sustain 30% or better billings growth in fiscal 2015. He also notes that the company will see slower growth in capital expenditures and a reduction in litigation expenses.

Palo Alto Networks offers a next-generation network-security platform used by enterprises, service providers and government entities to protect their networks from viruses, malware and other threats. Its lineup includes network firewall software and hardware. It also sells subscription services for threat detection and prevention, web filtering and mobile device security.
Patent Issue Past

Palo Alto Networks stock is up 46% this year and 21% since the firm announced the end of a legal saga May 28 and released third-quarter fiscal 2014 results. They topped estimates with 49% year-over-year revenue growth to $150.7 million, and 57% earnings growth to 11 cents a share.

"These results were driven by continued strong product demand, robust service growth and a rapid market-share gain in the large and growing strategic enterprise security market," CEO Mark McLaughlin said on a call with analysts at the time, noting the firm had "settled all existing litigation with Juniper."

Palo Alto Networks paid $175 million to settle a suit in which Juniper Networks (JNPR) claimed that Palo Alto Networks products infringed on six of its patents. Under terms of the deal, Palo Alto Networks agreed to make a one-time payment of $75 million in cash and pay $100 million in shares of common stock and warrants to buy common stock.

Juniper Networks filed the suit in December 2011. Palo Alto Networks later accused the company of infringing on three of its patents. As part of the settlement, the two firms agreed to license the patents at issue to each other and not file infringement suits for the next eight years.

"As we said from the beginning of this case, we do not believe that we infringed on any Juniper patents, and we still believe this to be the case," McLaughlin said on the Q3 call. "However, over the course of the last 2-1/2 years, we've spent a large amount of time, money and other resources on this litigation. ... We believe that this outcome will allow us to continue to focus our efforts in what we do best: innovating and developing new products, servicing our customers and the growth that results from that."

Although $175 million is a hefty sum for a company with less than $400 million in revenue as recently as its last fiscal year, the settlement did remove "a key overhang" on Palo Alto Networks stock, says FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi.
Stock Sets New High
With the overhang gone, Palo Alto Networks stock, which debuted in an IPO two years ago, hit a record high of 82.27 on June 17 and then passed that by almost 2% Monday.
The settlement is also seen resolving hesitancy on the part of some customers to do business with Palo Alto Networks as long as the lawsuit was up in the air.
"With this removal, we think Palo Alto can experience incrementally more sales," Seyrafi noted.

Palo Alto Networks seeks to continue expanding an operation that already includes 16,000-plus customers in more than 120 countries across multiple industries. One potential growth area is in the enterprise market, where it looks to win business with a next-generation security firewall designed for corporate data centers.
Guard For Data Centers

Palo Alto Networks' new PA-7050 security appliance will help it gain market share in the enterprise market, analysts predict. The product, launched in February, provides up to 120 gigabits per second of throughput speed to analyze threats to corporate data centers.

"Palo Alto has plenty of room left to take share in enterprise network security," Pacific Crest Securities analyst Rob Owens wrote in a report. "Data-center deployments account for over 30% of Palo Alto's product revenue, and the release of the PA-7050 appliance expands the opportunity into even higher-performance environments."

Meanwhile, analysts praise Palo Alto Networks' ability to win new business in a competitive field that includes pure plays such as Juniper, Symantec (SYMC) and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), plus broader hardware and software firms such as Cisco Systems (CSCO).

"Palo Alto is the clear market leader and is defining the market in the next-generation firewall space," Citi Investment Research analyst Walter Pritchard noted. "With clear differentiation and technology leadership, we see continued share gains ahead for Palo Alto."

Among factors working for Palo Alto Networks' potential, Morgan Stanley analyst Weiss notes that 43% of corporate security executives polled plan a firewall refresh (upgrades and replacements) this year vs. 23% last year. And with only 10% using Palo Alto for their primary firewall and/or unified threat-management needs now, he sees room for market share gains.
Weiss says the company has strong positioning and an improving margin trend past fiscal 2015.
More Acquisitions Ahead?

As Palo Alto Networks gains size, it may also eye more buyouts as a way to expand its piece of the pie, analysts say. The firm has not made a huge number of deals through the years, though it has made a couple in 2014. In January, it acquired Morta Security, a Silicon Valley-based cybersecurity company, for an undisclosed sum. In April, it completed its $200 million buyout of Cyvera, a privately held cybersecurity company in Tel Aviv, Israel.

Palo Alto Networks might be set for more acquisitions after its recent decision to issue $500 million of convertible senior notes due in 2019. In a research note, William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho said Palo Alto intends to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, which include working capital, capital expenditures, potential acquisitions and strategic transactions.

"We believe the funds from the convertible offering would provide the company with significant latitude to further broaden its technology and next-generation security-solution suite, as it did with its recent acquisition of Cyvera to enter the endpoint-protection space in what we view to be a very positive fashion," Ho said.
A Palo Alto Networks spokeswoman said no company officials were available to speak for this story.

Financially, Palo Alto Networks continues showing robust growth, notching year-over-year revenue gains of at least 46% each quarter since going public. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect EPS of 40 cents for fiscal 2014, which ends in July, up from 21 cents last year. Fiscal 2015 earnings are seen rising 65% to 66 cents a share.Palo Alto Networks, a leading stock pick, has vaulted higher as it puts a patent dispute to bed and as analysts see its security products in demand at data centers.Known for network firewalls and other corporate security offerings, Palo Alto Networks (PANW) makes the IBD Leaderboard list of high-potential stocks. Symantec (SYMC) stock rose more than 3% on the stock market today as investors digested a mixed quarterly report from late Thursday containing some ambitious 2015 guidance that led to cautious optimism. The company's stock had previously been down 15% for the year to date.

The tech security giant, in mid-overhaul and with a new interim CEO since March, delivered Q4 fiscal 2014 revenue and bookings roughly in line with estimates, while margins and earnings per share beat, Cowen & Co. analyst Gregg Moskowitz noted in a Friday report.

"But far more important was that SYMC's interim CEO and new CFO provided a FY15 outlook that was both more detailed (given this management team is just starting out) and optimistic than expected," he wrote. "However, we're not convinced that SYMC will be able to deliver, and we fear the company is setting itself up for more disappointment."

FBR & Co. analyst Daniel Ives called the March quarter results "good enough," but said that "Everest-like" challenges remain. The company had begun its overhaul early last year after ending up bloated with too many managers and from acquisitions it had been unable to integrate effectively.

In an interview with IBD Thursday, interim CEO Michael Brown, appointed in March, said that there is "a lot of opportunity" for more operational efficiency on the top and bottom line — everything from tweaks to the product-renewals process to changes in discount pricing and potentially fewer data centers worldwide.

The company needs "to be focusing more," Brown said, so he will steer toward "optimizing our businesses based on where they are in their life cycle and growth potential — before we might've had more of a philosophy of 'let's invest in everything.'"

He told IBD that the company's information-availability and Norton consumer-security businesses are examples of mature segments that can be optimized for margin. Meanwhile, the company's enterprise backup, enterprise storage management and enterprise security businesses are areas where investment can yield better growth. So there will be a shift in research and development spending.

Symantec reported earnings of 47 cents a share for its fourth quarter, 5 cents ahead of the consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters and 7% higher than a year ago. Revenue fell 7% to $1.625 billion, below the consensus view of $1.645 billion.

Symantec gave fiscal Q1 2015 guidance that is, at the midpoint, $30 million above what Moskowitz had estimated. The Symantec guidance calls for revenue between $1.65 billion and $1.69 billion, down from $1.71 billion a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected $1.64 billion.

For full-year fiscal 2015, the company sees revenue between $6.63 billion and $6.77 billion, roughly unchanged vs. $6.7 billion a year earlier. Analysts had been modeling for $6.66 billion, according to the Thomson Reuters poll.
"While down seasonally (for Q1 2015), the guidance we have for the full fiscal year is roughly flat in revenue," Brown told IBD, "so growing in the second half."
Moskowitz noted that Symantec expects around 28% operating margins in fiscal 2015, reflecting 20-70 basis points of expansion and 50 basis points above his estimate.

"We believe the FY15 revenue target (and possibly margins) will likely prove somewhat aggressive, at least in the absence of additional M&A," Moskowitz wrote. "We do, however, agree with management's assertions that revenue and bookings will grow moderately in (the second half of fiscal 2015)."

Sterne Agee analyst Robert Breza said in a Friday research note that "with a CEO search under way, management uncertainty remains high, which will likely stall growth for the foreseeable future, while focus is on business rationalization."

Symantec is the largest company by market cap in IBD's Computer Software-Security industry group, followed by Check Point Software (CHKP), Verisign (VRSN), Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and FireEye (FEYE), which ended down nearly 4% in Friday's session following disappointing results May 6. Its stock is down 38% for the year.Symantec (SYMC) stock rose more than 3% on the stock market today as investors digested a mixed quarterly report from late Thursday containing some ambitious 2015 guidance that led to cautious optimism. Insurers put food on the table by preparing for disasters that most people would rather not think about: fires, hurricanes, earthquakes, car accidents, collapsing buildings. Now they're increasingly writing policies for another worry — cyberattacks.

One of the many changes brought by the Internet revolution is that stealing customer data or a company's proprietary information is easier than ever. One doesn't even need to be on the same continent anymore to commit the theft. And it can be weeks or even months before the damage is even detected.

In response, insurers are selling more cyberpolicies . Coverage may include loss or corruption of business data, lost business activity, legal defense costs, the cost of posting cash rewards to catch cybercriminals, crisis communications management, identity theft and defamation via social media.
While these hazards can be difficult to underwrite, insurers have had years to refine their products.

"It's probably the fastest-growing aspect of the insurance market right now," said Bob Parisi, leader of network security and private practice for insurance broker and risk adviser Marsh USA. "We've seen nothing to indicate that acceleration is going to wane any time soon."

In May, a federal grand jury indicted five Chinese officials for allegedly committing industrial espionage by hacking into the data systems of U.S. Steel (X), Alcoa (AA), Allegheny Technologies (ATI) and others.

A Chinese businessman was arrested last month for allegedly hacking into the computer systems of Boeing (BA), Lockheed Martin (LMT) and other companies that have large defense contracts with the U.S. government.
Recently cyberattacks moved into the top 10 list of global business risks, according to the Allianz Risk Barometer Survey, which polled more than 400 corporate insurance experts from 33 nations.
"It's more prevalent now than it was and harder to detect," said Murray Jennex, a management information systems professor at San Diego State University.
Yet challenges remain to raise awareness that cyberinsurance can be an effective tool to protect against the costs of repairing and defending against cyberattacks.

With $2 billion paid in cyberinsurance premiums in 2013, the specialty still makes up a small percentage of the $1 trillion total paid in U.S. insurance premiums last year, said Marsh Management Research, a division of Marsh USA.

Average coverage limits purchased by firms with more than $1 billion in revenue rose by 10% in 2013 to $28.2 million each, says Marsh. The estimated cost varies widely. A 2014 study sponsored by the software security firm McAfee estimated that cybercrime costs businesses worldwide $445 billion annually. An old Symantec (SYMC) study put that total at $114 billion — 13 years ago in 2001.
"Many businesses may not completely understand their vulnerability at this point," said Robert Hartwig, president and chief economist at the Insurance Information Institute.
Challenges remain for underwriters and clients to know how much to insure and why. For instance, what is the value of lost privacy?
"We're a century and a half ahead when it comes to mitigation and prevention of fires," Hartwig said. "We're in the first decade when thinking of how to prevent cyberattacks."
The costs of compromised computer security are very real.

The cybersecurity breach last December at Target (TGT), in which hackers obtained tens of millions of consumers' credit and debit card information, ultimately cost Chief Executive Officer Gregg Steinhafel his job.

The attack made some customers skittish, hurt sales and contributed to a 14% decline in Target's share price over two months. The Minneapolis-based big-box retailer was hit with more than 50 lawsuits, now being coordinated before a federal judge in Minnesota.
Michaels (MIK), eBay (EBAY), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and St. Joseph Health System all have reported cyberattacks within the last 12 months.

The number of U.S. companies with cyberinsurance varies with the research. Nearly a third of U.S. companies have a cyberinsurance security policy, according to a 2013 report sponsored by Experian and conducted by the Ponemon Institute. Zurich Insurance Group reported last year that 52% of U.S. companies surveyed were covered, but a study sponsored by Willis Group Holdings (WSH) said that a mere 6% of Fortune 500 companies carry such protection.
Whatever the number of cyberattacks inflicted or cyberinsurance policies sold, insurers will try to protect clients and cash in on this wrinkle in the Internet revolution.

"While it's hard to underwrite," said Marsh USA's Parisi, "that hasn't been a deterrent to insurance companies rushing into this market space."Insurers put food on the table by preparing for disasters that most people would rather not think about: fires, hurricanes, earthquakes, car accidents, collapsing buildings. One doesn't even need to be on the same continent anymore to commit the theft. And it can be weeks or even months before the damage is even detected.In response, insurers are selling more cyberpolicies . Zurich Insurance Group reported last year that 52% of U.S. companies surveyed were covered, but a study sponsored by Willis Group Holdings (WSH) said that a mere 6% of Fortune 500 companies carry such protection.Whatever the number of cyberattacks inflicted or cyberinsurance policies sold, insurers will try to protect clients and cash in on this wrinkle in the Internet revolution."While it's hard to underwrite," said Marsh USA's Parisi, "that hasn't been a deterrent to insurance companies rushing into this market space."

Symantec (SYMC) stock rose more than 3% on the stock market today as investors digested a mixed quarterly report from late Thursday containing some ambitious 2015 guidance that led to cautious optimism. The company's stock had previously been down 15% for the year to date.

The tech security giant, in mid-overhaul and with a new interim CEO since March, delivered Q4 fiscal 2014 revenue and bookings roughly in line with estimates, while margins and earnings per share beat, Cowen & Co. analyst Gregg Moskowitz noted in a Friday report.

"But far more important was that SYMC's interim CEO and new CFO provided a FY15 outlook that was both more detailed (given this management team is just starting out) and optimistic than expected," he wrote. "However, we're not convinced that SYMC will be able to deliver, and we fear the company is setting itself up for more disappointment."

FBR & Co. analyst Daniel Ives called the March quarter results "good enough," but said that "Everest-like" challenges remain. The company had begun its overhaul early last year after ending up bloated with too many managers and from acquisitions it had been unable to integrate effectively.

In an interview with IBD Thursday, interim CEO Michael Brown, appointed in March, said that there is "a lot of opportunity" for more operational efficiency on the top and bottom line — everything from tweaks to the product-renewals process to changes in discount pricing and potentially fewer data centers worldwide.

The company needs "to be focusing more," Brown said, so he will steer toward "optimizing our businesses based on where they are in their life cycle and growth potential — before we might've had more of a philosophy of 'let's invest in everything.'"

He told IBD that the company's information-availability and Norton consumer-security businesses are examples of mature segments that can be optimized for margin. Meanwhile, the company's enterprise backup, enterprise storage management and enterprise security businesses are areas where investment can yield better growth. So there will be a shift in research and development spending.

Symantec reported earnings of 47 cents a share for its fourth quarter, 5 cents ahead of the consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters and 7% higher than a year ago. Revenue fell 7% to $1.625 billion, below the consensus view of $1.645 billion.

Symantec gave fiscal Q1 2015 guidance that is, at the midpoint, $30 million above what Moskowitz had estimated. The Symantec guidance calls for revenue between $1.65 billion and $1.69 billion, down from $1.71 billion a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected $1.64 billion.

For full-year fiscal 2015, the company sees revenue between $6.63 billion and $6.77 billion, roughly unchanged vs. $6.7 billion a year earlier. Analysts had been modeling for $6.66 billion, according to the Thomson Reuters poll.
"While down seasonally (for Q1 2015), the guidance we have for the full fiscal year is roughly flat in revenue," Brown told IBD, "so growing in the second half."
Moskowitz noted that Symantec expects around 28% operating margins in fiscal 2015, reflecting 20-70 basis points of expansion and 50 basis points above his estimate.

"We believe the FY15 revenue target (and possibly margins) will likely prove somewhat aggressive, at least in the absence of additional M&A," Moskowitz wrote. "We do, however, agree with management's assertions that revenue and bookings will grow moderately in (the second half of fiscal 2015)."

Sterne Agee analyst Robert Breza said in a Friday research note that "with a CEO search under way, management uncertainty remains high, which will likely stall growth for the foreseeable future, while focus is on business rationalization."

Symantec is the largest company by market cap in IBD's Computer Software-Security industry group, followed by Check Point Software (CHKP), Verisign (VRSN), Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and FireEye (FEYE), which ended down nearly 4% in Friday's session following disappointing results May 6. Its stock is down 38% for the year.Symantec (SYMC) stock rose more than 3% on the stock market today as investors digested a mixed quarterly report from late Thursday containing some ambitious 2015 guidance that led to cautious optimism. Microsoft (MSFT) extended its lead in the global enterprise software market last year, research firm IDC reported Monday.

The total software market rose 5.5% to $369 billion in 2013, topping the 4.3% growth reported in 2012, IDC said. Sales last year benefited from a recovery in Europe and continued above-average growth in the U.S.

Microsoft led the market with revenue of $65.6 billion, a 12% increase from the prior year. Its market share rose to 17.8% from 16.7%. IBM (IBM) was second with an 8% market share. IBM revenue in the field rose 1.2% to $29.4 billion. Rounding out the top five were Oracle (ORCL), SAP (SAP) and Symantec (SYMC), according to the IDC report.
IDC tabulated software revenue from three primary segments: applications, application development and deployment, and systems infrastructure software.

Among the three segments, application development and deployment, which comprised nearly 23% of total software revenue in 2013, had the fastest growth with a 5.6% year-over-year gain. Oracle led this segment with market share of 21.5%, followed by IBM and Microsoft.
In the applications software segment, which comprised 50% of total software revenue and grew 5.5%, Microsoft led the field with a 14% share. It was followed by SAP, Oracle and IBM.
The systems infrastructure software segment comprises 27% of total software revenue and grew 5.5%. Microsoft led the field with a 29.3% of market share, followed by IBM, Symantec and EMC (EMC).

North America and Latin America were the top growing regions in 2013 followed by Western Europe.Microsoft (MSFT) extended its lead in the global enterprise software market last year, research firm IDC reported Monday.The total software market rose 5.5% to $369 billion in 2013, topping the 4.3% growth reported in 2012, IDC said. Stocks got off to a positive start Friday, but slipped into mixed trade as several drugmakers fell abruptly and pulled the Nasdaq into negative territory.

The Dow Jones industrial average was ahead 0.4%, the S&P 500 up 0.3%. The Nasdaq fell 0.3%, with Gilead Sciences (GILD), Celgene (CELG), Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX) and other drugmakers posted sharp losses.
Options expirations forced volume up in the stock market today, with trade up in triple-digit percentages on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq, compared with Thursday's early action.

Broadcaster Media General (MEG) swept ahead 12% after announcing it would buy peer LIN Media (LIN) in a cash and stock deal valued at $1.9 billion. The combination, which includes nearly $1 billion in LIN debt, would create a TV broadcaster with 74 stations serving 46 markets. Providence, R.I.-based LIN Media was up 27%.

Symantec (SYMC) tanked 12% at the start of trade. The antivirus software maker announced late Thursday it had dropped CEO Steve Bennett. The company said the decision was "the result of an ongoing and deliberative process," not the result of "any event or impropriety." The company named director Michael Brown as interim CEO. Symantec shares have been in a deepening correction since August.

Among leading stocks, Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) popped 3% in powerful trade to grab a new high. The fast-casual sport bar chain remained in buying range, 3% above a 152.01 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

On the downside, Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) reversed an early gain and backed off 4% in heavy trade. The drugmaker has been in a flattish consolidation below a Feb. 25 high.Stocks got off to a positive start Friday, but slipped into mixed trade as several drugmakers fell abruptly and pulled the Nasdaq into negative territory.The Dow Jones industrial average was ahead 0.4%, the S&P 500 up 0.3%. FireEye (FEYE) stock hit a new high Wednesday, supported by a price target increase by FBR Capital Markets.
FBR analyst Daniel Ives raised his price target on the provider of cybersecurity software to 105 from 90.
FireEye stock was up 8.5% to 95.72 in early afternoon trading on the stock market today. Earlier in the session, it hit a record of 96.33.

FireEye makes threat-protection software that business and government customers use to identify and block malware and other threats in emails, files, websites and mobile apps. Its technology is geared toward detecting the latest kinds of cyberattacks.

In the report, Ives referenced "massive growth opportunities on the horizon." He said recent checks with customers, partners and information technology consultants "have been incrementally positive, leaving us encouraged that the combination of FireEye and Mandiant under one roof is making headway in taking significant share as an end-to-end, next-generation security software vendor."

On Jan. 2, FireEye announced the acquisition of security software firm Mandiant for about $1 billion in cash and stock. While FireEye aims to detect malware before a breach occurs, Mandiant's technology analyzes and neutralizes threats after a breach.

The combination of FireEye and Mandiant presents "a serious share gain opportunity" from traditional security vendors that include Juniper Networks (JNPR), Symantec (SYMC) and McAfee, which is owned by Intel (INTC).
FireEye launched its IPO on Sept. 20. Priced at 20 the stock rose 80% on the first day of trading. The stock is up more than 375% from its IPO price.
On Feb. 11, FireEye issued a lower-than-expected Q1 outlook, a surprise to analysts and investors. The stock fell 12% on the news, then rebounded, as IBD reported.
"We think the company's 2014 outlook appears conservative relative to the explosive demand we are seeing in the field," Ives wrote.

Although Chinese stocks have dominated this column in recent sessions, they are not the only game in town for investors looking to gain foreign exposure. A few Israeli firms also offer strong fundamentals and technicals.

Caesarstone's (CSTE) top-line growth has ramped up in recent quarters, thanks to strong demand for its quartz surfaces. The company reported a 27% jump in Q4 sales last month. That was the biggest gain in more than a year and also marked the third straight quarter of acceleration.
Earnings in the latest-reported period increased 53% — the seventh straight quarter of double-digit growth.

Sales in the U.S. jumped 59% in the fourth quarter and accounted for about 36% of total revenue. "We believe these results demonstrate the realization of our quartz penetration vision and our solid position in the U.S. market," said CEO Yosef Shiran in a press release.
Caesarstone, a 2012 IPO, is trading near an all-time high, but is not in buying range. In recent weeks, it has staged a big comeback after a failed breakout from a cup base in January.

Check Point Software (CHKP) is trading near its best levels in nearly 13 years. The stock cleared a flat base with a 63.39 buy point in late December and has worked 9% higher, supported by its 10-week moving average. Tight weekly closes show solid buying demand from fund managers.
The company is a provider of network security software, hardware and services. Check Point is the second biggest firm in the Computer Software-Security group next to Symantec (SYMC).
In late January, Check Point beat expectations with an 8% rise in Q4 earnings. Broad demand for its products helped revenue grow 5%.

Even though many medical stocks took heat in the latest week, Taro Pharmaceuticals (TARO), also based in Israel, was relatively unscathed. The stock found support at its 10-week line and ended little changed for a third straight week.

Technically, the stock met the criteria for a three-weeks-tight pattern. But that add-on pattern is not valid here, as areas of tight trading are common in the stock. Taro is also thin, whereas three-weeks-tight patterns are best for more liquid stocks.

Taro is a global maker of generic and branded drugs. The stock has a Composite Rating of 98, the second-highest in the Medical-Generic Drugs group.Although Chinese stocks have dominated this column in recent sessions, they are not the only game in town for investors looking to gain foreign exposure. Symantec (SYMC), the largest computer security software maker, made progress on its yearlong overhaul, raised its outlook ahead of analysts' estimates and beat expectations for the most recent quarter in its earnings report delivered after Wednesday's close. But revenue last quarter fell, and Symantec stock was down nearly 3% in after-hours trading. Shares rose 3.7% in the regular session, in…
A year ago, Symantec CEO Steve Bennett called the security company he leads, the largest in its hot industry group, "bloated" after many acquisitions.
Today, the company is leaner after hefty management cuts and a realignment around 10 functional areas and customer pain points. But there's still much work to be done, he says.

Symantec (SYMC) on Jan. 29 beat expectations for its third quarter of fiscal 2014, and raised guidance. But it's not yet growing the way Bennett would like: revenue has declined on a year-over-year basis the past two quarters.
After the earnings release, Bennett spoke with IBD about the rationale of enduring some short-term pain for, he hopes, long-term gains.
IBD: You started the corporate overhaul a year ago and in October reported a "tough quarter." What's happened since?

Bennett: We said we had to overcome the shortfall in the second (fiscal) quarter and we did that in the third quarter, and produced results better than the second quarter in every dimension. We exceeded our forecast.

We're not completely satisfied — we're not growing our revenue year-over-year (it declined 5% YOY for the quarter ended Dec. 27) — but we're going into our fourth quarter with positive momentum. So we're optimistic about the fourth quarter.
IBD: You mentioned in your earnings release that last quarter Symantec benefited from "improved total business activity." What did you mean by that, since revenue fell vs. the year-earlier quarter?
Bennett: Investors look at our company in terms of what happens with revenue growth plus, they call it, implied billings, which is revenue growth plus the change in our deferred (revenue) balance.
The deferred revenue is really an important thing.

We made progress on those fronts from the previous quarters. There's a lead and a lag between bookings converting to revenue. Depending on whether you sell subscriptions or licenses, it comes in different cycles.
IBD: Almost all of your salespeople had new territory assignments as of fiscal Q2. How have they adjusted?

Bennett: I think positively, as you can see from the results. When you make that kind of big change, it creates some challenges, and we're still working through those. We'll be anxious to see how much progress we make in the fourth quarter. The pipeline looks solid.
IBD: What are the most successful functional categories of your business out of this realignment?

Bennett: Overall, there are really three things we've been focused on as a company, as we move from having individual point solutions to building on our strongest point solutions to answer customer problems.

One, we're building more integrated solutions and building some industry partnerships, like in November to be a part of the Cisco Systems (CSCO) Application-Centric Infrastructure (ACI) design (which automates provisioning of applications).
No. 2, we made a lot of changes in our go-to-market (strategy). As we come up with solutions, we have to fine-tune them.
And third, we have to focus on taking the complexity out of our systems.

IBD: Are you still sticking with the 10 focus areas you picked a year ago? (Mobile Workforce Productivity, Norton Protection, Norton Cloud, Information Security Services, Identity/Content-Aware Security Gateway, Data Center Security, Business Continuity, Integrated Backup, Cloud-Based Information Management, and Object Storage Platform.)
Bennett: We're changing some things in the reframing, but nothing substantial.

IBD: Check Point Software (CHKP) on Jan. 28 reported what its CEO Gil Shwed called one of the best quarters he can remember. What did Symantec notice, if anything, about the corporate security-buying environment?

Bennett: I think the environment is still strong; just read the newspaper every day. We're making the hard decision to position the company to win in the long term and taking a little short-term pain to reposition the company. I think the market's strong and there's a tailwind at our back.

IBD: Will Symantec be able to compete in the network security segment where Check Point is doing well and several next-gen companies — from Palo Alto Networks (PANW) to Fortinet (FTNT) — are making inroads?

Bennett: We don't participate in that segment directly. Our strategy has been to partner, and we're close to some announcements on that. We're looking for ways to solve the biggest customer problems vs. always doing things ourselves.
IBD: You say in your earnings release that you are where you expected to be at this point in your three- to five-year transformation. So, what work remains to be done and what are your targets?
Bennett: We've been in operational mode now about six months — we're making progress. The feedback on our strategy from around the world is terrific.
The question is: On this kind of change, can you execute?

We did better in the third quarter than in the second, and I look forward to improvement in the fourth quarter, and to carry that into fiscal 2015.A year ago, Symantec CEO Steve Bennett called the security company he leads, the largest in its hot industry group, "bloated" after many acquisitions.Today, the company is leaner after hefty management cuts and a realignment around 10 functional areas and customer pain points. But there's still much work to be done, he says.Symantec (SYMC) on Jan. 29 beat expectations for its third quarter of fiscal 2014, and raised guidance. Network security company Check Point Software (CHKP) beat analysts' profit estimates with its fourth-quarter earnings report Tuesday morning, as sales of its high-end appliances for data centers sold well along with its next-generation threat prevention software. It also announced a share buyback of up to $1 billion.
Check Point stock was up nearly 4% in midday in the stock market today, near 66. Earlier Tuesday, the stock touched a 13-year high of 67.25.

Check Point's report is the first big one this earnings season out of IBD's hot Computer Software-Security industry group, which ranks No. 6 of 197 groups tracked. Check Point is No. 2 by market cap in the group. No. 1 Symantec (SYMC) reports after the market close Wednesday.

"This morning, Check Point delivered rock-solid December results, as the company beat the Street across-the-board on the heels of strong cybersecurity tail winds and a healthy product cycle in the company's back pocket," FBR analyst Daniel Ives said in a research note. "It appears, after a somewhat choppy period of growth for the company over the past few years, that brighter days are on the horizon as consistent license growth is now here to stay, in our opinion."

Both Check Point and Symantec went into Tuesday slightly down for 2014 amid a checkered stock market — Check Point by 1% and Symantec by 3% — while smaller next-generation security rival Mandiant was up 57%, with a $1 billion acquisition and raised Q4 guidance announced earlier this month. But Check Point's results show corporate purchasing is in gear and that companies are on board with Check Point's modular network security approach involving high-speed security appliances that different software "blades" can be added to for different security functions.
"The fourth quarter represented one of the best quarters that I can remember, which is reflected in our customer wins and deferred revenues," Check Point CEO Gil Shwed said in the earnings release.

Check Point reported Q4 revenue of $387.1 million, up 5% from the year-earlier quarter, and earnings per share of 98 cents. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were looking for EPS of 95 cents on revenue of $383.6 million.

For the year, Check Point revenue rose 4% to $1.39 billion, with EPS of $3.43. Analysts had been looking for $3.41 and $1.39 billion. Analysts have modeled Q1 at 83 cents EPS and $341.2 million in revenue, with full-year 2014 at $3.64 and $1.47 billion.

"The company ... is guiding for FQ1 and F2014 results in line with consensus. Still, we are raising our EPS estimates meaningfully due to an increase in our product revenue growth assumptions and due to a lower tax rate (the F2014 tax rate is expected to increase lower than previously expected)," FBN Securities analyst Shebly Seyrafi wrote in a research note Tuesday.
Last year, Check Point repurchased 10.1 million shares at a pace of about $135 million a quarter. Under its new plan, which replaces the old one, it can repurchase up to $200 million a quarter.

Symantec's fiscal 2014 Q3 report Wednesday comes a year after the company announced a big revamp under the direction of recently added CEO Steve Bennett, who told IBD then that the company was "bloated" with "a lot of redundancies" after many acquisitions over the years. Investors will get to see how effectively the streamlining he planned got put into place.
After delivering its fiscal 2014 Q2 report in October, Symantec stock dived despite an earnings beat, as the company cut guidance and revenue came in short of analyst views.
At the time, Symantec cut its guidance for fiscal Q3 to revenue of $1.63 billion to $1.67 billion, down from $1.79 billion in the year-earlier quarter, with EPS of 41 to 43 cents, down from 45 cents.

Back then, analysts were looking for $1.79 billion and 51 cents. Now, the consensus view of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters calls for revenue of a little over $1.65 billion and EPS of 42 cents. For the current fiscal Q4, they see revenue of $1.64 billion and EPS of 41 cents, putting full-year results for fiscal 2014 at revenue of $6.64 billion and EPS of $1.77.

After Symantec and Check Point, the next-biggest security group stocks by market cap, VeriSign (VRSN) and FireEye (FEYE), are set to give their own quarterly reports on Feb. 6. and Feb. 11, respectively. Fifth-in-size Palo Alto Networks (PANW) reported its fiscal Q1 in late November. Its stock was up 4% for the year going into Tuesday trading.

FireEye this month announced that it bought privately held Mandiant in a deal valued at about $1 billion. Some hopes appear pinned on this purchase with so many recent attacks on companies — Target (TGT) being one of the big ones — and Mandiant's background having included insights into some notable cases. Nearly a year ago it made the high-profile claim that China was behind a series of computer spying incidents.

FireEye this month said it expects to report Q4 revenue of $55 million-$57 million, up from its earlier guidance of $52 million-$54 million. At the time of the announcement, analysts were expecting $53.6 million.

Carbon Black (CBLK) late Thursday reported a narrower-than-expected loss as revenue met expectations in its fiscal first quarter. The computer security firm forecast current-quarter sales and profit roughly in line with analyst estimates.Carbon Black reported an adjusted fiscal Q1 loss of 98 cents a share, nearly flat from a year ago, with revenue rising 35% to $48.4 million. A year earlier, the company had a loss of 99 cents a share on sales of $36 million. Analysts expected Carbon Black to report a loss of $1.27 a share on sales of $48 million for the period ended April 30.Shares in the maker of computer security software initially fell 3.5% in after-hours trading on the stock market today. But they rebounded and were up 5.3% late. In Thursday's regular session, shares fell 2.6% to 26.31.The security firm's software detects malware on computer network "endpoint" devices. They include mobile phones, laptops, tablets, and the Internet of Things.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. "The (software) protects customers from today's most advanced cyber threats, including ransomware and new types of attacks that have never been seen before and are undetectable by legacy anti-virus products."For the July quarter, Black Carbon expects a loss in a range of 41 cents to 42 cents vs. estimates of a 43-cent loss. The company forecast revenue of $48.5 million to $49 million. Analysts had projected $48.2 million.Waltham, Mass.-based Carbon Black raised $152 million in its May initial public offering, with shares priced at $19. Stocks got off to a mixed start Friday, as the Dow industrials struggled to stretch its rally to an eighth day, but earnings-driven declines by Nvidia (NVDA), Symantec (SYMC) and others dragged on early trade.The Dow Jones industrial average clung to a fractional gain in opening trade. Verizon (VZ) was an early strong suit among blue chips, up 1.9% after an upgrade from JPMorgan.The S&P 500 also defended a narrow gain, while the Nasdaq Composite slipped into tight early losses. Security software developer Symantec fell hard, to the bottom of both indexes.Earnings news provided a hub for early action, with Nvidia, Trade Desk (TTD), Yelp (YELP) and Symantec all posting significant moves.On the Dow index, Verizon swung to an early lead, after JPMorgan upgraded the stock to overweight, from neutral. Verizon shares spiked, then sold off hard at the end of April, on news of a $26 billion merger between Sprint (S) and T-Mobile U.S. (TMUS). Shares ended Thursday 13% below their April high.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseNvidia was a key a name to watch Friday, opening almost 2% lower after its late-Thursday earnings report.  The graphics chip pioneer crushed fiscal first-quarter earnings and revenue expectations, and gave second-quarter revenue guidance above consensus views. The company offered no earnings guidance for the second quarter. Still, the industry leader's slip threatened the week's strong performance among chipmakers.Friday's early loss dragged the stock back below a flat-base buy point at 254.60. The chart also can be interpreted as a double-bottom base. By that view, shares remained extended 5% above the 239.35 entry.Nearly all of the chip stocks listed on the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index moved lower in early trade.  Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) fell alongside Nvidia, down 2% in early action. The Philly Chip Index gained 4.9% for the week through Thursday, and was leaning toward its first two-week advance since March.Symantec collapsed 35% as analysts downgraded the stock following its fiscal fourth-quarter report late Thursday. Weak guidance damaged an otherwise stronger-than-expected quarterly performance. Symantec shares had climbed 17% in a seven-week advance since March, attempting to build the right side of a seven-month consolidation.Trade Desk spiked 33% in opening trade. The online advertising services platform reported late Thursday its first-quarter earnings growth accelerated to 89%. Growth in revenue also accelerated for a 61% increase. Both numbers easily topped analyst targets. Management's raised second-quarter and full-year revenue and earnings guidance were well above consensus hurdles.The IPO's opening action marked a breakaway gap, that lifted sharesw well beyond buy range past a 61.03 buy point in a gnarled-looking cup base. This remains a buy opportunity, but it's best to read up on buying breakaway gaps before trying to jump in.Another IPO, Dropbox (DBX), fared less well. The stock stumbled 2.1% lower after reporting better-than-forecast first quarter earnings, revenue and user growth late Thursday. It was the company's first report since going public in March. Shares remained 50% above their IPO price.Business review site Yelp spilled nearly 9% lower, despite reporting a narrower loss and better revenue growth than expected in its first quarter. The loss ended a six-weekj advance, sending the stock below its 10-week moving average in heavy trade.Energy stocks were largely quiet as crude oil prices traded narrowly lower early Friday. U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate was down 0.3%, holding well above $71 per barrel. Crude gained 0.3% Thursday, with WTI settling at $71.36 a barrel, up 2.4% so far for the week. Prices could feel some effect on Friday when Baker Hughes (BHGE) releases its weekly rig-count survey at 1 p.m. ET.Import prices crept up 0.3%, export price jumped 0.6% in April, the Labor Department reported. Economist had expected a 0.5% jump in imports and a smaller, 0.3% rise in export prices.The University of Michigan delivers its preliminary reading on May consumer sentiment at 10 a.m. ET.A glance across Asian stock markets shows Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rallying more than 1% on Friday. That left the benchmark with a 4% gain for the week, its best since mid-February, as it attempts to climb up from a three-month consolidation. China's Shanghai Composite slipped 0.4% Friday, ending the week with a 2.3% gain. In Japan, the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo capped the week with a 1.2% rally Friday, advancing 1.3% for  its seventh straight weekly gain.Europe's market improved to mixed trade Friday, with Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris each down more than 0.3% in afternoon trade. London's FTSE 100 fought to hold a fractional gain. For the week, the FTSE 100 is up 1.7%, the DAX ahead 1.2% and the CAC-40 holds a fractional gain. Shares in Zscaler (ZS) climbed Tuesday as a slew of analysts initiated coverage of the computer network security provider following its initial public offering.Baird, BTIG Research, Credit Suisse and Needham rated the cybersecurity provider as buy or outperform. U.S. stock futures turned narrowly positive early Friday, as the Dow looked to extend its six-session win streak and the S&P 500 tacked toward its best week in almost three months.A busy after-hours earnings reporting session on Thursday saw Nvidia (NVDA), Trade Desk (TTD) and Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) among the names in motion after hours.Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average shook off earlier losses and edged 0.1% above fair value. Kroger (KR), the largest grocery chain in the U.S., is joining Walmart (WMT) and Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) in tightening gun restrictions following last month's school shooting in Parkland, Florida.X Kroger's Fred Meyer chain, which carries general merchandise in addition to groceries, will no longer sell firearms and ammunition to buyers under age 21, the company said on Thursday."In response to the tragic events in Parkland and elsewhere, we've taken a hard look at our policies and procedures for firearm sales," Kristal Howard, a spokeswoman for the retailer, said in an email. "Recent events demonstrate the need for additional action on the part of responsible gun retailers."Kroger's decision comes after Dick's and Walmart announced on Wednesday that they would both increase the purchasing age of firearms to 21. Dick's said it would stop selling assault rifles altogether, which Walmart has not done since 2015. In addition to increasing the age to purchase guns and ammunition, Walmart said it would stop the sale of items "resembling assault-style rifles," such as airsoft guns and toys."We take seriously our obligation to be a responsible seller of firearms," Walmart said in a statement posted on its website Wednesday evening. The Bentonville, Arkansas-based chain said it requires "customers to pass a background check before purchasing any firearm."Dick's said it would stop selling assault rifles like the one used in the Parkland, Florida high school massacre on Feb. 14. Walmart stopped selling them in 2015, citing slow sales.The decision by America's largest retailer is the latest by companies re-evaluating their relationship with the firearms industry. Last week, MetLife (MET), Symantec (SYMC), and Enterprise said they would no longer offer discounts to members of the National Rifle Association. Delta Air Lines (DAL) parted ways with the NRA too, spurring Georgia Republicans to oppose a planned $50 million tax break for the Atlanta-based carrier.Sign Up For Free IBD Newsletters: Market Prep | Tech Report"American voters and companies are waking up to the scope of our nation's gun violence crisis. They are listening to the cries for action from students," Gabrielle Giffords, a gun control advocate and former congresswoman, said in a statement. "They understand that it's our responsibility as a society to do everything we can to prevent guns from falling into dangerous hands. When will Congress realize the same?"Giffords was shot and severely wounded in a 2011 mass shooting outside Tucson.Shares of Sturm Ruger (RGR) and American Outdoor Brands (AOBC), maker of Smith & Wesson firearms, rose more than 6% on the stock market today. That could reflect concerns of increased gun restrictions by retailers as well as President Trump's call for new gun control measures.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Chart-Reading Basics: How A Buy Point Marks A Time Of Real Opportunity How Do You Spot A Major Market Top? Apple reversed from a 0.7% gain to a 0.3% loss to slide below its 200-day moving average. It fell to the line on Friday amid a price target cut from Morgan Stanley, which cited weaker iPhone sales. Apple had been approaching the top of a flat base before it started heading south on Wednesday.Metals miners, semiconductors and telecom led the downside among sector funds in the stock market today. SPDR S&P Metals & Mining (XME) lost 2.5% to test its 50-day line. The ETF is tracing a possible double-bottom base with a 38.81 buy point for now.VanEck Vectors Semiconductor (SMH) slid 1.3% to breach its 200-day line for the first time in nearly two years. Chip stocks had a tough last week, sparked by Taiwan Semiconductor's (TSM) 6% plunge Wednesday following the chipmaker's disappointing outlook. Taiwan Semi fell 0.5% Monday; Intel reversed to a 0.9% loss.Retail, banks and energy outperformed. SPDR S&P Regional Banking (KRE) and SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) gained a respective 0.9% and 0.8%. KRE is trying to retake its 50-day moving average as it shapes a shallow base with a 65.43 potential buy point.Gold plays fell along with gold futures, which declined 1% to $1,325.30 an ounce.But Bitcoin climbed 1% to $8,851.96, according to CoinDesk, after opening near $9,000. Bitcoin Investment Trust (GBTC) rose 3% to pad its gains above the 50-day line, which it recovered Friday for the first time in three months.Cybersecurity is hot as technology focused ETFs continue to dominate among this year's top-performing sector funds. But biotech has weakened a bit.Top honors go to ETFMG Prime Cyber Security (HACK), which scored a 16.7% year-to-date gain through Tuesday, according to Morningstar Direct. It was featured in this ETF Leaders column on April 12, while it was in buy range from a rebound off its 50-day moving average. Shares marked a new record high on Wednesday, and are now extended from the entry.The $1.4 billion fund, which tracks the Prime Cyber Defense Index, invests in companies that provide hardware, software, consulting and services to defend against cybercrime. Top five holdings included Commvault Systems (CVLT), Japan's Trend Micro, Fortinet (FTNT) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW). The top five accounted for nearly 23% of the 47-stock portfolio.In second place: iShares North American Tech-Software (IGV) with a 15.1% year-to-date return. The ETF is working on the right side of a shallow base with a potential buy point at 183.33. It pulled back Friday with the broader market, but the pattern remains intact. Of those, Amazon and Netflix are near record highs. FDN is building a shallow base with a potential 132.09 entry.First Trust NASDAQ Cybersecurity (CIBR) is next with a 14.3% year-to-date gain. Palo Alto Networks (PANW) has risen about 20% from the 156.95 buy point of a January breakout. For example, Commvault Systems (CVLT) is an expert in cloud computing and data handling.Well-publicized hackings of major retailers, credit rating agency Equifax and dozens of others are reminders that consumer data remain vulnerable. Hackers also have hit computers of military, utility and other critical operations. New types of threats are emerging, such as "ransomware" attacks that demand payment to stop a data breach.Spending in cybersecurity is expected to climb 19% to $90 billion this year, according to a report from market research firm GBH Insights, quoted in Barrons.com.
