Symantec (SYMC) late Wednesday reported in-line earnings, but revenue and June-quarter guidance fell short of expectations, sending shares down in late trading.Symantec said that adjusted fourth-quarter earnings were 28 cents a share, up 27% from a year ago, with revenue rising 28% to $1.12 billion, for the period ended March 31. A year earlier, Symantec earned 22 cents a share on sales of $873 million.Analysts expected Symantec to report earnings of 28 cents a share on sales of $1.18 billion. Shares in the maker and provider of computer security software fell 5.7% to 31.25 in after-hours trading on the stock market today.For the June quarter, Symantec forecast earnings of 30 cents a share at its midpoint of guidance, and revenue in a range of $1.13 billion to $1.16 billion, vs. consensus estimates of 38 cents and $1.27 billion.Mountain View, Calif.-based Symantec acquired Blue Coat Systems in 2016 for $4.65 billion. Blue Coat CEO Greg Clark became Symantec's CEO in August. Then, in February, Symantec closed the purchase of LifeLock, a provider of consumer identity-theft protection services, for $2.3 billion.The LifeLock deal was aimed at bolstering its Norton security unit. The Blue Coat acquisition put Symantec in the fast-growing cloud-access security broker market. CASB products act as a middleman between a corporate network and cloud applications hosted externally.RELATED:FireEye Stock Jumps On Q1 Beat, Guidance Above Views

Stocks opened slightly lower Tuesday, as the market headed into the final two trading days of May.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 dipped 0.2%. The Nasdaq and Russell 2000 shed each less than 0.1%.The Nasdaq ends the month in good stead, sitting atop a seven-day advance, snug up against new highs and up 2.7% so far for May, tacking toward a seventh straight monthly advance.  The S&P 500 has also posted a seven-day run up, and is up 1.3% for May. The Dow industrials have climbed 0.7% for the month.Small caps are a different story. The Russell 2000 is nursing a 1.3% decline so far for May, tacking toward its second decline in three months. The S&P Smallcap 600 is down 1.6% for the month, and looking at its third slip in five months.Verizon (VZ) set up an early lead among blue chips, rising 0.5% at the open. General Electric (GE) brought up the rear amond Dow stocks, down 0.8% in early trade.South Korea's LG Display (LPL) swung up more than 6%. The maker of LCD panels turned its sales and earnings from declines to accelerating gains over the past three quarters. The early move hoisted share just above a 14.06 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Internet and network security play Symantec (SYMC) popped nearly 4%. Barclays upgraded the stock to overweight, from equal weight. Symantec has logged four weeks of a shallow consolidation after running up 99% in the 12 months to early May.AutoZone (AZO) added almost 1%, torn by conflicting analyst ratings. Webush downgraded the stock to neutral from outperform. Goldman Sachs upgraded the retailer to buy, from neutral. Shares are down 11% so far for May, and in a downtrend begun in August.IPO Biohaven Pharmaceuticals (BHVN) jumped 7% after both Barclays and William Blair initiated coverage on the biotech. Blair gave the stock an outperform rating and a 46 price target. Blair rated the stock overweight with a price target of 30. The stock is trading 50% above its May 4 initial offering, and extended above an IPO base buy point of 23.23.Among IBD 50 stocks, Stamps.com (SMTP) leapt more than 2%, lifting it just beyond buy range above a 136.10 buy point.Personal income climbed 0.4% in April, the Commerce Department estimated, double March's 0.2% increase and in line with economists' expectations. Consumer spending rose 0.4%, after a flat performance in March, and was also in line with consensus projections.The Personal Consumption Expenditures Index rose 0.2%, reversing March's 0.2% decline, meeting targets. The core PCE Index, minus energy and food, rose 0.2%, vs. a 0.1% slip in March and above estimates for a 0.1% gain.Home price growth held steady in March, sending the Case-Shiller Home Price Index up 0.9%, month-over-month. That topped February's 0.7% gain as well as economist projections for a 0.8% advance.May consumer confidence data from the Conference Board will follow at 10 a.m. ET.Oil prices were in the red, with West Texas Intermediate down 1.1% and just above $49 a barrel. Gold was off 0.7% to below $1,263 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, up vs. the euro and down against the yen. Bonds inched higher, trimming the 10-year yield by 1 basis point to 2.24%.Europe's markets were under pressure near midday: Frankfurt's DAX was off 0.1%,  the FTSE 100 in London softened 0.3% and the CAC 40 in Paris slid 0.6%.RELATED:Broadcom Leads Top-Rated Stocks Reporting: Investing Action Plan Analysts Bullish On These Four Top-Rated Chip Stocks

Alibaba (BABA) and Adobe (ADBE) had their price targets raised Friday, while Snap (SNAP) was downgraded, Zynga (ZNGA) was upgraded on signs of turnaround.X Stifel hiked Alibaba Group's price target to 165 from 139, citing its improved mobile monetization via higher customer engagement and conversion."The opportunity to leverage consumer data will support continued gains in monetization as evidenced by guidance," said the Stifel report. Stocks climbed out of the starting gate Monday, despite a Tesla (TSLA) downgrade and weak reading on New York manufacturing.The Dow Jones industrial average quickly moved up 0.3%, led by Cisco Systems (CSCO).  The S&P 500 traded up 0.2% and the Nasdaq climbed 2% to take out a new high, buoyed partly by a rally among cybersecurity stocks.Cisco Systems topped the Dow industrials, jumping 1.8% after a Morgan Stanley upgrade to overweight, from equal weight. the move left shares just below a 34.61 buy point in a flat base. Cisco plans to report its fiscal third-quarter results after the market closes Wednesday.Tesla dipped more than 3% in opening action, as Morgan Stanley downgraded the stock to equal weight, from overweight. The downgrade cited revised operating costs, saying the company would continue to post losses on a GAAP basis through late 2019. The note also reportedly warned that deliveries of Tesla's Model 3, which it forecasts will become the company's leading revenue driver, could be much lower than anticipated through 2018. Valuation was also at issue, as the stock has climbed past the Morgan Stanley price target of 305. Shares fell to 314.22 Monday, narrowly above a 313.83 buy point of a cup-with-handle base.Symantec (SYMC) popped 5% at the open, one in a rally in cybersecurity stocks apparently tripped by fears of a resurgence in the cyberattacks dubbed "WannaCry" that swept global markets Friday. Palo Alto Networks (PANW) opened 3% higher.  Fortinet (FTNT) surged 4%.Germany-based Trivago (TRVG) spiked 9%. The hotel and travel search engine reported a 100% gain in first quarter earnings, meeting analyst targets, and a better-than-expected 68% rise in revenue. The stock is trading up 36% from a cup-base breakout in April, and 77% above its December IPO price.Among IBD 50 stocks, Momo (MOMO) climbed almost 2% at the open.  The stock is in buy range above a 39.35 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. The China based social networking site is scheduled to release first-quarter results May 23.The New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey dived to a reading of -1.0% for May, down sharply from April's 5.2 tally and disappointing consensus estimates for an increase to 8.0. The gauge of New York regional manufacturing activity reported a 4.4% drop in new orders, a 16-point drop in unfilled orders and a 9-point decrease in delivery times. Employment indexes were stable, although the total number of employees was slightly lower than in April.The May Housing Market Index from the National Association of Home Builders is due for a 10 a.m. release.The price of West Texas Intermediate oil bolted nearly 4% higher, to above $49 per barrel, after Saudi Arabia and Russia were among the countries agreeing to extended the limits on production established in October through the first quarter of 2018.Gold rose 0.6% to above $1,235 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, down vs. the euro and up against the yen. Bonds eased, lifting the 10-year yield 1 basis point to 2.33%.Europe's markets remained narrowly mixed in afternoon trade, with the FTSE 100 in London up 0.2% and Frankfurt's DAX down 0.2% and Paris' CAC-40 trading 0.1% lower.RELATED:Alibaba, Salesforce.com, Home Depot, Wal-Mart: Investing Action PlanCheck Out These Five Stocks In Or Near Buy Zones

X Network security stocks led the market Monday as a pervasive cyberattack threatened to unleash a second wave around the world.The Nasdaq was up 0.4%. Amazon.com (AMZN) was down slightly but volume was big enough to make it one of the most heavily traded stocks on the day.The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average also were up 0.4%, just off their session highs. The small-cap Russell 2000 led with a 1% increase. Volume was tracking higher on the Nasdaq compared with the same time Friday, but was flat on the NYSE.Security software stocks were up more than 4% in afternoon trading. Symantec (SYMC), which last week struggled to hold its 31.20 buy point, was back above the entry. Most notably in that group, Proofpoint (PFPT) broke out of a cup-type base with an 84.46 buy point. Volume was tracking about four times the stock's 50-day average.Goldman Sachs upgraded Proofpoint, FireEye (FEYE) and Mimecast (MIME), saying it expects those companies to benefit the most from the WannaCry ransomware attack. Security experts believe another wave of computers will be hit by the attack this week.Proofpoint went public at 13 a share in April 2012. Currently, the stock holds a 79 Earnings Per Share Rating, but this rating is weighed down by net losses scored from 2008 to 2015. In 2016, the Sunnyvale, Calif., firm posted its first annual net profit as a publicly traded company, earning 37 cents a share.Now, the Street sees Proofpoint earning 12 cents a share in Q2, double vs. a year ago, and 58 cents a share for FY 2017, up 57%.Imperva (IMPV) broke out of a cup-with-handle base, rising past the 48.77 buy point in heavy volume. The base is part of a much larger pattern that stretches out to the start of 2016. Imperva is another member of the security software industry group, but is not a leader like Proofpoint or Symantec.Energy, chip and cyclical stocks such as machinery makers were among the best performing in today's trading.Yet on the downside, building products firms have been struggling lately.W.W. Grainger (GWW) fell 2% to the lowest level since January 2016. The building products company has been in a steep decline since peaking Jan. 25, exacerbated by an 11% plunge on its April 18 weak earnings report.Grainger holds a horrible Composite Rating of 18 from IBD Stock Checkup. Growth investors should focus on those with a 90 or higher.Its meltdown is part of a broad weakness in building products stocks. Computer security stocks rose Monday morning extending gains in the wake of the ransomware cyberattack Friday that struck some 150 countries, including Britain and Russia. There's a concern that the attacks will step up again with the new workweek.The malicious software, called WannaCry, infects computers and encrypts files with a key that only extortionist hackers can access. After computers are disabled, a message pops up demanding a ransom.Shares in Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) rose 1.3% in premarket trading Monday after climbing 1.7% on Friday to 107.60. Palo Alto Networks (PANW) stock advanced 3% Monday after Friday's 1.1% advance. FireEye (FEYE) stock popped 4% in the premarket after a 2.3% advance Friday. Barracuda Networks (CUDA), which sells email protection and next-generation firewall software, was not yet active after climbinge 3% to 21.79 on Friday.  Fortinet (FTNT) stock also was not yet trading after Friday's fractional gain.IBD'S TAKE:  Facebook, Applied Optoelectronics and Arista Networks are among IBD's Sector Leaders, a list that highlights the best stocks in 33 sectors. All Sector Leaders show outstanding earnings and sales growth in recent quarters. After a slew of high-profile data breaches in 2013-14, many companies rushed to upgrade firewalls that sit between private networks and the internet and invested in threat-detection technologies. But, spending on security technology has slowed as many companies shift their technology  infrastructure to the cloud.CyberArk Software (CYBR) stock climbed 2.7% Monday morning after crashing 12% to 48.29 on Friday after the company's guidance disappointed. Shares in Symantec (SYMC) rose 3.2% after losing 5.1% on Thursday and 1.4% on Friday following its weak guidance.In a report, Symantec recently said ransomware attacks jumped 36% worldwide in 2016. The FBI in early 2016 warned hospitals, school districts, state and local governments, and businesses to protect themselves from ransomware.RELATED:Symantec Revenue, EPS Guidance Light; Stock Falls After HoursFireEye Stock Jumps On Q1 Beat, Guidance Above ViewsHas Cisco Systems Got Its Groove Back Through Cybersecurity?

Symantec (SYMC) saw an improvement in its IBD SmartSelect Composite Rating Friday, from 84 to 96.The revised score means the stock currently tops 96% of all other stocks in terms of key performance metrics and technical strength. History shows the top market performers tend to have a 95 or higher score as they launch their major climbs.But Symantec has flashed technical warning signs, including a sharp gap down in heavy volume on Thursday after reporting earnings. It managed to find support above its prior 31.20 buy point, but has slipped back below that entry heading into afternoon trading Friday.See if the cybersecurity and storage leader can hold the line and move higher in heavy volume.One weak spot is the company's 69 EPS Rating, which tracks quarterly and annual earnings-per-share growth. Look for that to improve to 80 or better to show it's in the top 20% of all stocks.Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A shows heavy buying by institutional investors, such as mutual funds and pension funds, over the last 13 weeks.In Q4, the company reported 27% EPS growth. It has now posted accelerating EPS gains for two consecutive quarters. Sales growth climbed 28%, up from 15% in the prior report. That marks three consecutive reports with increasing revenue gains.Symantec holds the No. 1 rank among its peers in the Computer Software-Security industry group. Qualys (QLYS) and Cyberark Software (CYBR) are also among the group's highest-rated stocks.RELATED:Which Companies Are Now Outperforming 95% Of All Stocks?

The stock market headed lower early Tuesday following three-day Memorial Day weekend. The S&P 500 index and Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively, while the Nasdaq dipped nearly 0.1%.Among the Dow industrials, Verizon (VZ) paced the advancers with a 1.1% rise. Fast-food chain McDonald's (MCD) fell 0.2% despite having its price target hiked at Barclay's to 164 from 155. The firm maintained its outperform rating amid its raised expectations for the company's digital and delivery efforts.In early trading, the blue chip's laggards include financial component Goldman Sachs (GS) and energy components Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM). The global investment bank fell 1.9%, while the oil giants fell 0.8% and 0.4%, respectively, as oil prices slipped more than 1%, leaving West Texas Intermediate just above $49 a barrel.On the S&P 500, computer security firm Symantec (SYMC) rose 2% after being upgraded to overweight from equal-weight at Barclay's. Shares were attempting to reclaim their 50-day line after piercing it on May 17.On the downside, energy names found themselves at the bottom of the S&P 500's performers amid a 1.4% decline in the price of crude oil. Devon Energy (DVN) and Valero Energy (VLO) fell 3.1% and 1.3%, respectively.Among other leading stocks, Micron Technology (MU) jumped more than 2% as it surged above a 29.97 flat-base buy point. Fellow data storage firms Western Digital (WDC) and Seagate Technology (STX) rose 2.3% and 1.5%, respectively.Nvidia (NVDA) rose 2.8% as it set a fresh record high, while e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN) briefly broke above the vaunted 1000 price level, rising 0.3%.Among analyst actions, former highflier Ambarella (AMBA) fell 6.5% after being downgraded to sector weight from overweight at Pacific Crest. Over the last eight weeks, the stock has made a strong comeback on its way to building the right side of a potential cup-base. Meanwhile, Tesla (TSLA) was initiated at hold by Independent Research. Shares of the electric automaker soared over 2% to reach a new high, extending its three-day winning streak.Action in the IBD 50 was mostly positive after the open, but several leaders found themselves under pressure early Tuesday. Recent issue Floor & Decor (FND) dropped nearly 7% after last week's IPO-base breakout. Shares remain above the 39.59 entry. China education stocks New Oriental Education (EDU) and TAL Education (TAL) fell 3.5% each.On the upside, Match Group (MTCH) and Ichor (ICHR) moved up 2.9% and 3.4%, respectively.RELATED:Analysts Tout McDonald's, Yum But Cut Ambarella, AutoZoneSnap Seeks Support, But These 3 Hot IPOs Are Near Buy ZonesDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisWeek In Review: Stocks Hit Highs On FANGs; Oil Dives After OPEC; Best Buy, Ulta Shine

Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) hiked its stake in Apple (AAPL) by more than 125% to 129.4 million shares in the first quarter, and made modest changes to its airlines holdings while avoiding Snapchat parent Snap (SNAP), which went public in March.Meanwhile, Soros Fund Management bought 1.7 million shares of Snap, joining David Tepper's Appaloosa Management and Dan Loeb's Third Point. Soros also dissolved his firm's positions in Amazon.com (AMZN) and Delta Air Lines (DAL), and added to its stake in Facebook (FB), according to filings late Monday.David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital trimmed its Apple holdings to 4.2 million shares from 6.1 million in Q4, while more than quadrupling its stake in General Motors (GM) to 55 million shares from 13 million.In Q1, Berkshire grew its American Airlines (AAL) stake to 49.3 million shares, up 8.4% vs. the previous quarter, and its investment in Southwest Airlines (LUV) to 47.7 million, up 10.4%. It trimmed its position in Delta to 55 million shares, down 8.3%, while keeping its holdings in United Airlines (UAL) steady at 28.9 million.The regulatory filing confirmed news from early May that Berkshire's Buffett busily dumped tech giant IBM (IBM) in Q1. It had 64.6 million shares left at quarter-end, down 20%. (Even IBM Retirement Fund's unloaded 70,000 shares of IBM, leaving it with 12,451 IBM shares in Q1, according to the fund's 13F filing on May 10.)Meanwhile, the conglomerate's massive long-term stakes in Coca-Cola (KO), American Express (AXP) and Kraft Heinz (KHC) were left basically unchanged.Buffett had already said Berkshire more than doubled its Apple holdings in Q1, giving it a 2.5% stake in the iPhone maker's outstanding shares. Berkshire initiated a position in Apple, worth $1.1 billion, in Q1 2016 and doubled down on Apple as the year progressed.By contrast, Appaloosa Management slashed its stake in 2017's best-performing Dow component Apple by a third, to 300,000 shares, and trimmed Facebook by 12.6%, to 1.9 million shares in Q1, according to filings from Friday. The company also scooped up 100,000 shares of Snap, which tanked 17.5% last week on a dismal debut earnings reports following its March IPO.Similarly, Third Point exited its 1.85 million-share stake in Apple during Q1, while buying 2.25 million shares of Snap.Shares of Berkshire closed up 0.3% at 163.76 on the stock market today. Apple dipped 0.3%, down from Friday's fresh record high, and Snap rallied 8.4%, after last week's plunge. Facebook eased 0.1%, and IBM added 0.7%.Among Appaloosa's other notable moves, the fund entirely liquidated its massive stakes in two troubled stocks: chipmaker Qualcomm (QCOM) and retailer J.C. Penney (JCP).Appaloosa added a 1.6 million-share stake in Symantec (SYMC), which was leading a cybersecurity stock rally Monday on the heels of a global ransomware attack. Appaloosa also raised its Western Digital (WDC) stake by 16.1% to 1.3 million shares.But the hedge fund's biggest bet seems to be on an American industrial renaissance. It opened positions of roughly half a million shares each in AK Steel (AKS) and Nucor (NUE), while upping ArcelorMittal (MT) by more than 410%, to nearly 5 million shares.Other hefty new positions included Bank of America (BAC) and CBS (CBS) (8.8 million and 1.0 million shares, respectively).Third Point's other moves include adding to positions in T-Mobile (TMUS), Salesforce (CRM), Qualcomm and Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD).The fund closed a small stake in Goldman Sachs (GS), and reduced holdings in Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase (JPM).Late Friday, Trian Fund Management also disclosed bigger positions in General Electric (GE) and Procter & Gamble (PG) and a smaller stake in DuPont (DD).RELATED:What Will Berkshire Filing Show As Loeb Cuts Facebook, Apple Stakes?Why Buffett Still Isn't Sure If He'd Buy Amazon, Alphabet Stock Now

X The U.S. government's 'stockpiling' of cyberweapons opened the door to the WannaCry ransomware attack, Microsoft (MSFT) alleged Monday as new concerns over computer hacking sent shares in security vendors up.Further, while the WannaCry ransomware attack targeted PCs with Microsoft software, one researcher said Apple (AAPL) could also be hit with similar attacks. Aleksandr Yampolskiy, founder and chief executive of SecurityScorecard, told CNBC that Apple computers are also vulnerable as well.The WannaCry ransomware seemed to be built to exploit computer spying tools originally designed by the U.S. National Security Agency, researchers said. Cybersecurity experts say the worm exploits those NSA tools and takes advantage of a vulnerability in Microsoft software to spread the infection."An equivalent scenario with conventional weapons would be the U.S. military having some of its Tomahawk missiles stolen," Microsoft President Brad Smith said in a blog.The WannaCry ransomware attack hit 10,000 organizations and companies in more than 100 countries on Friday. A second wave was expected early this week. WannaCry encrypts files with a key that only extortionist hackers can access. After computers are disabled, a message pops up demanding a ransom."This attack provides yet another example of why the stockpiling of vulnerabilities by governments is such a problem," said Smith. "This is an emerging pattern in 2017. The governments of the world should treat this attack as a wake-up call."Microsoft has updated its security software to deal with the crisis.Microsoft shares rose 0.1% to 68.43, closing near session highs and still in range from a 66.01 buy point. Apple was off 0.3% to 155.70 after hitting a record 156.65 intraday.But shares in cybersecurity specialists Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Proofpoint (PFPT) and FireEye (FEYE) rose solidly Monday, following gains on Friday."We believe organizations that have been affected (by WannaCry) will likely increase their cybersecurity spending," said Jonathan Ho, a William Blair analyst in a report. "While we do not expect an immediate return to the breach reaction spending seen in 2015 from the large number of enterprise attacks discovered during that time frame, we believe that attacks such as WannaCry will help sustain awareness and willingness to spend among organizations."After a slew of high-profile data breaches in 2013-14, many companies rushed to upgrade firewalls that sit between private networks and the internet and invested in threat-detection technologies. That caused security stocks to peak in late 2015.Details about those tools were recently disclosed to the public.IBD'S TAKE:  The Computer-Software Security group is ranked No. 137 out of 197 industry groups. Spending on security technologies has slowed as companies reassess priorities amid the shift to cloud computing. Symantec has the highest Composite Rating of security companies. Learn more about the security group at IBD Stock Checkup. Shares in Check Point 2.6% to 110.36 Monday after climbing 1.7% on Friday. Palo Alto stock advanced 2.7% Monday after Friday's 1.1% gain. FireEye stock popped 7.5% on Monday after a 2.3% advance Friday.  Shares in Barracuda Networks (CUDA), which sells email protection and next-generation firewall software, were up 5.8% to 23.05 on Monday after climbing 3% on Friday. Fortinet (FTNT) stock jumped 3.4% to 40.45 after Friday's fractional gain.Proofpoint stock shot up 7.4% to 86.05. Symantec (SYMC) stock was up 3.2% to 32.RELATED:Symantec Revenue, EPS Guidance Light; Stock Falls After HoursFireEye Stock Jumps On Q1 Beat, Guidance Above ViewsHas Cisco Systems Got Its Groove Back Through Cybersecurity?

Stocks opened lower Thursday, despite some positive economic news and a continued surge in oil prices.The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 dropped 0.3%.The Dow headed into Thursday's session toting a 0.3% loss so far for the week. The Nasdaq was up 0.5%, while the S&P 500 held a narrow gain and was trading less than 0.5% below its March 1 high.On the Dow, Merck (MRK) rose 2% at the open. The Kenilworth, N.J.-based drugmaker announced late Wednesday the Food and Drug Administration had approved its Keytruda as part of a chemotherapy regimen to treat certain forms of lung cancer. Merck shares climbed back above their 10-week moving average, and continued building the right side of a two-month base pattern.Among other blue chips, Caterpillar (CAT) climbed more than 1% after Bank of America upgraded the stock to buy from neutral, and raised its price target to 120 from 105.In earnings action, Whole Foods Market (WFM) and ExOne (XONE) posted early gains after reporting results. Ctrip.com International (CTRP) and Symantec (SYMC) — two stocks that pushed to new highs Wednesday — both fell hard in premarket trade after their reports.But Snap (SNAP) took the headlines, diving more than 20% after reporting a more severe loss than expected in its first quarterly report as a public company late Wednesday. At Thursday's low, the stock came back almost to its IPO price of 17 a share.China-based NetEase (NTES) jumped 3% after its 53% gain in Q1 earnings gain and 61% rise in revenue squarely beat analysts estimates. The IBD 50 stock climbed above its 10-week moving average as it works on the right side of a base.Macy's (M) shed 9% at the open after a broad first-quarter miss.Straight Path Communications (STRP) skidded 20% at the open, after confirming it had accepted a takeover bid from Verizon (VZ) at $184 per share. The $3.1 billion deal ends a bidding war between Verizon and AT&T (T) that had driven Straight Path shares up 576% for the year through Wednesday. Verizon and AT&T were flat at Thursday's open.Prices paid by producers rose 0.5% in April, the Labor Department estimated, up from a 0.1% decline in March in a move much bigger than the 0.2% gain expected by economists. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.4%, compared to a no change reading in March and vs. consensus expectations for a 0.2% gain.First-time unemployment claims eased slightly, to 236,000, in the week ended May 6. The prior week's tally was 238,000 claims, and economist had projected an increase to 244,000 new claims.Oil prices continued their bounce begun Wednesday, spurred by data showing a sharp reduction in weekly stockpiles. West Texas Intermediate pulsed 1.3% higher early Thursday, climbing to just below $48 a barrel and up about 4% so far for the week. Gold edged up 0.2% to $1,221 an ounce. The dollar eased as bonds climbed, trimming the 10-year yield by 2 basis points to 2.39%.New York Federal Reserve Bank President William Dudley, speaking to a group at India's Bombay Stock Exchange at 6:30 a.m. ET, detailed his view that protectionist trade policies may provide short-term benefits, but have a broad negative impact on the longer-term economy."Protectionism can have a sirenlike appeal," Dudley was reported saying by Reuters, but in the longer term "it would almost certainly be destructive to the economy overall."Markets were tightly mixed in Europe after the Bank of England voted to hold its key interest rate at a record low 0.25%, citing data showing the U.K. economy slowed to 0.3% growth in the first quarter. The CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX each dropped 0.1%, while the FTSE 100 in London managed a narrow gain.RELATED: Forget Snap, Watch These Unicorns: Investing Action PlanSnap Is Losing Facebook Clone War; This Dow Drug Stock Nears Buy

Growth-hungry Cisco Systems (CSCO) has its groove back in cybersecurity — maybe in just the nick of time.With its core network business shrinking, cybersecurity seems a good bet for Cisco, analysts say. Hacker attacks are more sophisticated and widespread, while large companies and government agencies are making digital asset security a priority.And with Cisco being the Dow component and networking giant that it is, it can grow via acquisitions — something it's never been shy about doing. The new head of Cisco's security business, David Ulevitch, came from startup OpenDNS. Cisco acquired the specialist in advanced threat detection in 2015 for $652 million."I think of us as a very large security startup," Ulevitch told Investor's Business Daily in an interview. "There are only two competitors near our size, IBM (IBM) and Symantec (SYMC). We get to leverage the Cisco customer base and sales organization. But I like to operate like a startup that's growing out into the market for the first time, with products that are extraordinarily competitive, because customers are looking for best in class."Cisco's security revenue jumped 14% to $528 million in the January quarter, growing at roughly twice the rate of the overall market. For the computer networking giant as a whole, however, fiscal 2017 revenue is forecast to grow a paltry 1% to $48.4 billion. That figure excludes divestitures.Meanwhile, cybersecurity has room to grow, comprising only 6% of Cisco's total revenue now. Cybersecurity is one key to Cisco's shift to a software and services business model from its origins in internet routers and switches. With security and other initiatives, Cisco's goal is to grow recurring revenue from software subscriptions.In late 2016, Cisco combined its networking hardware and security businesses under David Goeckeler, a senior vice president and general manager. Cisco plans to leverage its huge networking customer base and distribution channels to sell security products.Cisco was an early leader in internet firewalls that block unauthorized traffic from entering private networks. But Cisco, along with Juniper Networks (JNPR), let its product offerings grow stale.That opened the door for Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Fortinet (FTNT) and others that introduced next-generation firewalls better suited for handling web-based applications a decade ago.Cisco took its eye off the security market for a while but has "woken up," said Jonathan Ho, a William Blair analyst who follows rivals such as Palo Alto and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP).There is one caveat, though. Corporate budgets have tightened up since 2015's spending frenzy."Security is a dynamic market where you cannot rest on your laurels," Ho said. "Their customers want to stick with them, but they weren't offering compelling products before and now they seem to be doing a much better job."Acquisitions have jelled. The 2013 purchase of Sourcefire for $2.7 billion continues to breath new life into Cisco's network security products, making Cisco a player in next-generation firewalls. Martin Roesch, Sourcefire's founder, is still at Cisco as a vice president and chief architect for the security business group."(Cisco) has acquired a number of private companies that help them offer a broader solution than the competition," Ho added. "Customers want to buy more capabilities from a single vendor, particularly if they can integrate those solutions. That seems to be the direction Cisco is heading. And the companies they are buying are addressing more forward-looking issues like public cloud and advanced threats."Some analysts view Cisco as a security industry consolidator that could snap up more public companies, such as Sourcefire. Acquiring Check Point or Palo Alto, for example, would double the size of Cisco's security business. But, there might be too much product overlap and integration risks, analysts say.Instead, Cisco may kick the tires at more private companies. Aside from OpenDNS, Cisco bought Lancope for $452 million in 2015 and CloudLock for $293 million last year.Cisco's investment fund has backed many security startups, including Exabeam, HyTrust, Netronome, Team8, eSentire, and Skyport Systems. As in the case of OpenDNS, Cisco sometimes acquires startups it has backed.Venture capital funding in cybersecurity jumped in 2014 and 2015 after a slew of high-profile data breaches, reaching $2.5 billion in 2014 and $3.7 billion in 2015, says CB Insights.Ulevitch says he expects a shakeout among startups. It could give Cisco an opportunity to acquire emerging security technologies at fire-sale prices."I think we're in for a Malthusian (unsustainable) environment where all these startups have been funded but there's not enough customer dollars to satisfy them," he said. "There's innovation from startups but not revenue acceleration. It'll be interesting over the next 12 to 18 months. I think you're going to see a lot of consolidation."UBS estimates that Cisco still garners half of security revenue from firewalls and intrusion prevention appliances, though it's expanding into other security markets.By acquiring Sourcefire in 2013, Cisco obtained firewall, intrusion detection and advanced malware protection technologies.With the purchase of ThreatGrid in 2014, Cisco got "sandboxing" technology that executes suspicious code in an isolated environment to test if a program contains a virus or malware. Through those moves, analysts say Cisco has been gaining share vs. FireEye (FEYE) in the advanced malware protection market.Cisco also competes with Proofpoint, an email security specialist. Proofpoint's software spots malware-ridden emails before they arrive in inboxes. Cisco gained email protection tools through the 2007 acquisition of IronPort Systems.With corporate America outsourcing more information-technology department workloads to cloud service providers, such as Amazon Web Services, many security firms have been racing to acquire cloud tools. With the CloudLock acquisition, Cisco gained cloud-access security broker software. Cloud-access security products act as a middleman between a corporate network and web applications hosted externally.Analysts say internet firewalls have become a security hub, meshing various technologies. But, one worry for Cisco is that spending on network security could slow as companies prioritize new security tools.UBS analyst Steven Milunovich, in an October report, said Cisco could push into identity and access management, where many private companies are active, as well as security vulnerability management. Okta (OKTA), a startup that provides access management tools that authenticate network user credentials, has filed to go public. If Cisco moves into security analytical tools, it would take on Splunk (SPLK) and others.One of Cisco's challenges, analysts say, is in winning back "thought leadership" in how companies should combat hackers, some of whom are state-sponsored. With its networking products installed at millions of locations, one of Cisco's strengths is visibility into global internet traffic on a daily basis.To set its security technology apart, Cisco aims to turn its switches and routers into network sensors that gather intelligence and detect threats."We gave petabytes of data that we analyze on a daily basis, and turn into strategic effectiveness," Ulevitch said. He says Cisco has 300 security researchers, some working on artificial intelligence and machine learning.Vijay Bhagavath, an analyst at Deutsche Bank, says Cisco outlined plans at a security conference in March on using its "Talos" security research outfit for tracking threats across corporate networks. Cisco expects attacks that flood a website with illegitimate requests for data to increase, for example."Cisco's moat in next-generation security is driven by scale of the company's 400,000-plus sales-channel footprint and $200 billion networking installed base," Bhagavath said in a report.Amid slowing revenue growth, Cisco has restructured to lower costs. In 2016, Cisco cut 5,500 positions, about 7% of its workforce.While Cisco transforms itself, it has steadily hiked dividends. Cisco stock has been trading at the highest levels since the eve of the 2008 bear market. Cisco has $70 billion in cash on its balance sheet, giving it dry powder for shareholder returns and strategic moves.After shooting past the 32 level in mid-February, Cisco shares climbed then retreated. The stock was up 0.2% Monday to 33.02.

Proofpoint (PFPT) reported first-quarter profit and revenue that topped expectations late Thursday, sending shares in the provider of computer security software up sharply in late trading.Proofpoint reported adjusted earnings of 12 cents a share, swinging to a profit from a 9-cent loss in the year-earlier period, with revenue climbing 43% to $113.3 million. Analysts had projected earnings of 9 cents a share and revenue of $110.6 million.Proofpoint stock was up 5% to 74.55 in after-hours trading in the stock market today. In the regular session on Thursday, Proofpoint stock fell 8.5%. Baird on Thursday downgraded Proofpoint to neutral from outperform and lowered its price target to 77 from 92.Meanwhile, Proofpoint Chief Executive Gary Steele and Tracey Newell, the company's executive VP of worldwide sales, said in an April 11 filing that they sold shares valued at more than $4.1 million.Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Proofpoint specializes in email and data loss protection for corporate networks and cloud-computing infrastructure.IBD'S TAKE: Which companies are hitting 52-week highs? That's easy to find on IBD's New Highs list, which ranks the companies making new highs by Composite Rating. So the best are at the top, making this a quick and easy way to find stocks for your watch list.Proofpoint's software spots malware-ridden emails before they arrive in inboxes.  Tools identify "spear phishing," emails with personal information or legitimate-sounding requests that target specific accounts. Proofpoint competes with Cisco Systems (CSCO), Symantec (SYMC) and FireEye (FEYE).Barracuda Networks on Monday reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings and revenue that topped views, but a disappointing outlook from the company sent shares plummeting.Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) and Fortinet (FTNT) report earnings on April 27.RELATED:Barracuda Earnings, Revenue Outlook Disappoints, Stock Dives

XFutures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index, Nasdaq 100 and Russell 2000 were little changed early Friday as the market looks to cap a solid weekly rebound.Dow industrials component Cisco Systems (CSCO), Symantec (SYMC), Fortinet (FTNT), Qualys (QLYS) and VeriSign (VRSN) are all forming bullish patterns near buy points.Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500, Nasdaq 100 and Russell 2000 fell 0.1% vs. fair value.In Thursday stock market trading, the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index rose 0.3%. The Nasdaq composite also climbed 0.3%, its fifth straight advance, to a record close, less than nine points below its all-time high set last week. The big-cap Nasdaq 100 did set an intraday best Thursday. Meanwhile, the small-cap Russell 2000 gained 0.8%, retaking its 50-day moving average.IBD'S TAKE: Cisco Systems is trading close to a proper entry point. The latest Investing Action Plan highlights five more Dow stocks near buy range that hail from a variety of industry sectors.Several cybersecurity plays have been showing positive action, with five crafting bases or consolidations worth watching.Cisco Systems is a networking giant, with the bulk of its revenue still hailing from routers, switches and other hardware. But Cisco is moving into software and services, including network security. For its latest quarter, security revenue rose 14% to $528 million, the best growth of any segment, while total sales dipped 2% to $11.6 billion.Cisco, which has been trading tightly, is working on a flat base, needing one more day to make it a valid pattern with a potential buy point of 34.63. Cisco shares were unchanged at 33.74 on Thursday.Symantec has made some sizable acquisitions over the past year, beefing up key areas as it competes with Cisco, Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and others. Earnings growth has revived, fueling the stock.Symantec shares broke out of a flat base on Jan. 13, continuing to advance on its earnings report in early February and peaking at a record-high 31.10 on March 13. Symantec has traded in a narrow range for nearly three weeks. Like Cisco, Symantec needs one more day to complete a three-weeks-tight pattern, which would have a 31.20 buy point.Fortinet tried to clear a 38.43 flat base entry on Thursday, hitting 38.56 intraday — the highest since October 2015 — before reversing lower to close at 37.85. FireEye's (FEYE) stock popped on an upgrade to buy by a Goldman Sachs analyst, who's upbeat on a new security product platform but also sees a possible acquisition of the company.Shares in FireEye, also upgraded on Monday by Bank of America to buy, jumped  6% to 12.19 in the stock market today. Gabriela Borges, a Goldman Sachs analyst, says there's a 15% to 30% chance FireEye could be acquired. Borges says an offer at around $18 per share could seal a deal.That would be lower than FireEye's apparent asking price nine months ago."Bloomberg reported in June 2016 that FireEye had received proposals from multiple potential acquirers earlier in 2016, but the company said that it had expectations for $30 per share or higher," said Borges. The Goldman Sachs analyst says  that FireEye holds $1.3 billion in tax credits that could attract a buyer.Symantec mulled an offer for FireEye six months ago, according to one report.FireEye provides web, email and malware security software to businesses and government agencies.Borges on Thursday also downgraded Proofpoint (PFPT) to sell from neutral. Proofpoint stock fell 6.8% to 73.79.IBD'S TAKE: The Computer-Software Security group is ranked only No. 143 out of 197 industry groups.  Fortinet and Check Point Technologies have the highest Composite Rating at 88 and 86 out of a possible 99, respectively. "We forecast moderating share gains in email security, as McAfee contributions are peaking and customers are increasingly choosing "good enough" security technologies over "best in breed," said the Goldman Sachs analyst.FireEye on Feb. 2 reported fourth quarter revenue and billings that missed views and announced management departures.  FireEye said its CFO, Mike Berry, and board chairman, David DeWalt, were leaving. FireEye also forecast current-quarter revenue below estimates.Borges, though, is upbeat on a new Helix-branded security product. "We believe the introduction of Helix, an advanced analytics platform, addresses many of FireEye's previous challenges," said the analyst.RELATED:Acquisitions Bolster Symantec Vs. Symantec[ticker symb=SYMC] is making the right moves with acquisitions, says Morgan Stanley, which upped its price target on the computer security software provider Wednesday.Analyst Keith Weiss upped his price target to 37 from 33 a share, noting that recent acquisitions should help improve its standing amid rivals such as Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW)."(With acquisitions) Blue Coat and LifeLock, we see Symantec posting high single-digit revenue growth in fiscal 2018/19 on an organic basis and 36% operating margins in 2019 — a material improvement from Symantec's flat growth profile and 28% operating margins in December 2015," Weiss said in a note to clients.Mountain View, Calif.-based Symantec acquired Blue Coat Systems in 2016 for $4.65 billion. Blue Coat Chief Executive Greg Clark became Symantec's CEO in August. Then in February, Symantec closed the purchase of LifeLock, a provider of consumer identity-theft protection services, for $2.3 billion."With the LifeLock and BlueCoat acquisitions, we see Symantec returning its consumer business to growth while better addressing long-term secular themes within enterprise security, such as consolidation into security platforms and increased visibility across multiple attack vectors," added Weiss.Symantec on Feb. 1 reported fiscal third-quarter earnings and revenue that topped views but forecast current-quarter sales and profit below expectations.IBD'S TAKE: Revenue growth is harder to come by for many security vendors these days as large companies reassess spending priorities. Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), which tops the IBD 50 roster of growth stocks, reported revenue growth of 38% to $6.9 billion in 2016.The LifeLock deal is aimed at bolstering its Norton security unit. The Blue Coat acquisition put Symantec in the fast-growing cloud-access security broker market. CASB products act as a middleman between a corporate network and cloud applications hosted externally.Symantec recently announced a $1 billion debt offering. It could make more acquisitions, says Weiss."We believe Symantec will focus its investments on the enterprise side of its business, adding technology that bolsters its security focused on the cloud, and endpoint detection/remediation capabilities," he wrote.Symantec stock rose 2.2% to 30.66 on the stock market today. Shares in Symantec have climbed 28% in 2017.IBD's Computer-Software Security group ranks No. 156 out of 197 industry groups.RELATED:Why This Is The Time Of Year Cisco Investors Love The StockCheck Point Price Target Hiked On Consolidation ThemeCisco, Palo Alto, Symantec Gear Up For Cloud Cybersecurity Shift

The major indexes made piecemeal moves in afternoon trading Wednesday, but techs continued to lead the way higher with just three more trading sessions left in March.Cisco Systems (CSCO) is taking a breather, falling nearly 0.7% to 33.76 in light volume and hampering efforts of the Dow Jones industrial average to rally. The 30-member Dow is down roughly 0.2%, while the Nasdaq composite and the tech-rich Nasdaq 100 are both up about 0.3%. The S&P 500 inched slightly higher and is just above 2360.Cisco shares, however, are still up more than 5% past a recent flat-base entry at 31.99. It's been featured frequently in IBD's Income Investor column, which highlights companies that have excellent earnings stability, a minimum 2% annualized yield, and decent relative strength.Cisco, the greatest stock market winner of the 1990s as it literally built the plumbing of the world wide web, no longer has the same growth characteristics as it did when it initially cleared a double-bottom base as a small-cap growth leader right after the stock market bottomed in October 1990. Now, with a $169 billion market cap and a 3.4% annualized dividend yield, the Silicon Valley stalwart in data networking routers, switches and other communications gear has been busy battling new upstarts including Arista Networks (ANET), currently ranked No. 1 in the IBD 50.Arista, embroiled in a technology patent court battle with Cisco, is down nearly 0.7% to 133.00, but volume is quiet and the stock's uptrend is firmly intact since its breakout past a 75.50 cup-shaped pattern in the week ended Aug. 12, 2016.That cup helped put the finishing touches on a long bottoming base pattern, seen among many current stock market leaders today. Arista went public in June 2014 at 43 and quickly ramped up to 94.84, then went into a deep freeze for nearly two years before finally building that first-stage cup pattern and eventually breaking out to 52-week highs.Arista has grown earnings per share 54%, 47%, 51%, 36%, 37%, 41% and 30% vs. year-ago levels over the past seven quarters. That amazing track record of profit growth is one reason why the Santa Clara, Calif., firm holds a 98 EPS Rating from IBD Stock Checkup.Revenue rose 33% to 42% over that same time frame. Wall Street sees FY 2017 earnings growth slowing, up 14% to $3.77 a share.As noted in a recent Big Picture column, while policy at the federal government level can certainly spur entrepreneurship and risk-taking, it's the innovative companies themselves that are the true engines of economic growth and job creation. Look for those companies that have outstanding products and services, rock-solid management, and stocks that have the ability to power to new highs and rise above their 10-week moving averages.All of these factors go into IBD's seven-point CAN SLIM investment paradigm, noted by AAII as the top investment strategy for stocks across multiple time periods going back to the late 1990s.Ulta Beauty (ULTA), which has redefined the way people shop for cosmetics, hair and skin care products and services, has made a terrific move since clearing a three-month cup at 188.58 back on March 11, 2016.Ulta today gained 0.57 to 283.43 and is currently in the proper buy zone, up 3% past a 274.09 entry in a double-bottom-with-handle base. Shares broke out of the slightly warped-looking pattern in early February in light volume. Both the advance and volume picked up steam on March 10, a day after Ulta reported a 33% jump in fiscal Q4 earnings per share and a 25% rise in revenue to $1.58 billion.That matched the biggest year-over-year top-line increase in 16 quarters.The top-performing specialty retailer is expected to see strong double-digit EPS growth during the next two fiscal years (up 24% in FY 2018 to $8.07 a share, up 21% in FY 2019). In tech land, NetEase (NTES) also deserves continued watch. The Chinese giant in online video games is basing after rising past a 257.78 cup-with-narrow-handle entry. Watch for potential support at the 10-week line.Symantec (SYMC) is staging a stunning turnaround, not just in stock price but also in profits. The stock, up more than 1% to 30.84, has shot 19% past a 25.82 flat-base entry.Wall Street sees earnings rising 14% to $1.19 a share in FY 2017, which ends this month, then galloping 47% higher to $1.75 a share in FY 2018. Industry peer Fortinet (FTNT) rose 4% to 38.08 in above-average turnover.The stock joined IBD's new SwingTrader premium service as one with potential to make a strong move over a period of several days to potentially a few weeks.Finally, digital marketing and imaging software leader Adobe Systems (ADBE) continues to thrive, edging up for a sixth straight session to 129.21. The San Jose, Calif., firm cleared a 107.90 entry in a shallow double-bottom base with handle in early January and has climbed as much as 19%.Adobe gets a solid 95 Composite Rating from IBD Stock Checkup on a scale of 1 to 99. Wall Street sees profit rising 31% to $3.95 a share in FY 2017, ending in November, and another 26% to $4.99 a share in FY 2018.RELATED:Stock Market Today I: Can Snap Finish A First-Stage Base?Stock Market Today II: 5 Solid Big Cap Names For 2017How To Invest: The Elements Of A Bottoming Base PatternHow To Invest: How To Find An Outstanding Cup-With-Handle Base

Symantec (SYMC) late Wednesday reported fiscal Q3 earnings and revenue that topped views but forecast current-quarter sales and profit below expectations, sending shares in the security software maker down after hours.Symantec said fiscal Q3 earnings minus items rose 23% from the year-earlier quarter to 32 cents. Revenue climbed 20% to $1.09 billion for the three months ended Dec. 30.Analysts had projected non-GAAP profit of 28 cents and $1.08 billion in revenue.In the current quarter, Symantec forecast profit of 28 cents, up 27%, and $1.08 billion in sales, up 25%, at the midpoint of its guidance range, vs. consensus estimates of 29 cents and $1.1 billion.Mountain View, Calif.-based Symantec stock was down 3% in after-hours trading in the stock market today, following the company's earnings release. Shares fell 1% to 27.25 in the regular session Wednesday.IBD'S TAKE: Revenue growth is harder to come by for security vendors these days. Chipmaker Nvidia, which tops the IBD 50 roster of growth stocks, reports earnings on Feb. 9. Inphi, a member of IBD's Sector Leaders, reports on Feb. 7.Symantec acquired Blue Coat Systems in 2016 for $4.65 billion. Blue Coat Chief Executive Greg Clark became Symantec's CEO in August. Symantec in November announced it would acquire LifeLock, a provider of identity-theft protection services, for $2.3 billion.John DiFucci, an analyst at investment bank Jefferies, says Symantec might revise guidance when the LifeLock deal closes.Symantec sells security software to both businesses and consumers. Analysts say the LifeLock deal is aimed at bolstering its Norton security unit.Symantec's anti-virus software is often bundled with PCs. The Blue Coat acquisition put Symantec in the fast-growing cloud-access security broker market. CASB products act as a middleman between a corporate network and cloud applications hosted externally.Symantec on Wednesday also announced a $1 billion debt offering. Although Symantec will have some $8 billion in debt when the LifeLock deal closes, analysts say Symantec's acquisition spree could go on. Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) are also viewed as companies that could be looking to make acquisitions.IBD's Computer-Software Security group ranks No. 148 out of 197 industry groups. Facebook (FB) reported better-than-expected earnings late Wednesday. So did Cavium (CAVM). Symantec (SYMC) and Apple (AAPL) iPhone chipmakers Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and Qorvo (QRVO) gave weak guidance.Estimates: EPS to jump 66% to $1.31 as revenue surges 46% to $8.51 billion.Results: EPS leapt 78.5% to $1.41 as revenue grew 51% to $8.81 billion. Those marked the second straight quarters of decelerating growth for the social networking giant.Mobile ad revenue accounted for 84% of total ad revenue in Q4. Daily active users rose 18% to 1.23 billion, with mobile users up 23% to 1.15 billion.Facebook also said it lost a virtual reality suit and must pay $500 million.Outlook: Facebook executives said on the post-earnings call that "we continue to expect that our revenue growth rate will come down meaningfully in 2017." Facebook says the ad load can still rise on its photo-sharing Instagram app, even as ad loads peak on the main Facebook site.Facebook plans to accelerate already heavy R&D and hiring, predicting that "expense growth rates will increase over the course of the year." Facebook pegged adjusted total expenses up 47%-50%.Stock: Facebook initially jumped more than 3% in late trading, but pared the advance to less than 1% following the call. Shares closed up 2.2% to 133.23 on the stock market today after slipping 0.5% Tuesday, threatening to undercut the 129.37 buy point that Facebook cleared last week.RELATED:Facebook Q4 Earnings Beat On Strong Ad GrowthThe Business World Tries To Cope With Trump's Immigration BanEstimates: EPS to pop 93% to 54 cents, with revenue soaring 122% to $224.5 million.Results: EPS doubled to 56 cents, revenue more than doubled to $226.2 million.Stock: Cavium rose nearly 4% late. Cirrus expects gross margin of 48%-50%.Stock: Cirrus Logic tumbled 7% in late trading. Shares closed up 6% to 63.96 Wednesday, buoyed by Apple after its strong earnings and iPhone sales announced late Tuesday. Cirrus Logic is now out of buy range after breaking out of a flat base with a 58.18 entry point in late November.Estimates: EPS to rise 21% to $1.25, with revenue up 32% to $821.3 million.Results: EPS of $1.35. Revenue was $826.3 million.Outlook: Qorvo sees fiscal Q4 EPS of 70-90 cents vs. views for $1.04. Qorvo sees revenue of $610 million to $650 million vs. analyst estimates of $719 million.Stock: Qorvo shares plunged 11% in after-hours action. Shares rose 0.5% to 64.55, despite Apple's results and stock action. After spending most of the new year above their 50-day moving average, shares are now looking to clear a 64.90 buy point.Estimates: Fiscal Q3 EPS to grow 8% to 28 cents; revenue up 18.5% to $1.08 billion.Results: EPS rose to 32 cents as revenue climbed to $1.09.Outlook: Symantec sees Q4 EPS of 27-29 cents vs. views for 29 cents. It expects revenue of $1.07 billion to $1.09 billion vs. analyst targets for $1.1 billion.Symantec also announced it will sell $1 billion in unsecured notes.Stock: Symantec fell 3% in after-hours trading. The computer security firm fell 1.1% to 27.25 at the close. The stock is still just out of the 5% chase zone (up to 27.11) after clearing a 25.82 entry point in mid-January.

Imperva's (IMPV) fourth-quarter earnings and revenue beat late Wednesday sent its stock up along with shares of other computer software security firms such as Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Fortinet (FTNT).Imperva, which has been cutting costs, reported Q4 earnings per share minus items of 32 cents, up 60% from the year-earlier period and blowing past Wall Street estimates of just a 2-cent profit. Revenue rose 8% to $78.4 million vs. consensus estimates of $70.2 million.Imperva in November said it planned to stay independent following a board review of strategic options.  Some buyout firms were said to be interested in Imperva. Activist investor Elliott Management disclosed in June that it had amassed about a 10% stake in Imperva.IBD'S TAKE: Stamps.com, NetEase, Inphi and GrubHub are among IBD's Sector Leaders, a list that highlights the best stocks in 33 sectors. All Sector Leaders show outstanding earnings and sales growth in recent quarters. Imperva stock surged 9% to close at 46.75 in the stock market today. Shares of Palo Alto Networks rose 2.4% to 155.49, while Fortinet gained 1.5% to 37.99. Both Palo Alto and Fortinet have formed cup patterns, though they remain below buy points.FireEye (FEYE) advanced 2.3%, Symantec (SYMC) 1.3% and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) 0.9%.CyberArk Software (CYBR) closed 2.9% higher but sank 5% late after reporting quarterly results. IBD's 26-company Computer-Software Security group was up 1.4% at a more than two-month high. The group ranks just No. 114 out of 197 industry groups, but that's up from No. 153 four weeks ago and No. 176 eight weeks ago. Many analysts have predicted a comeback for security software this year, after a slow 2016 that followed a spike the previous two years after a number of high-profile data breaches.Imperva said it expects 20% revenue growth in 2017, in line with earlier management commentary.RBC Capital hiked its price target on Imperva stock to 52 from 45."The key take-away for us is that execution appears to have improved significantly from several quarters ago while expectations remain in check," Matthew Hedberg, an RBC Capital analyst, said in a research report.Imperva also said it sold its SkyFence cloud security unit to Forcepoint for $40 million.Piper Jaffray hiked its PT on Imperva to 53 from 45."It appears the company's focus on sales execution is driving improved fundamentals, as this was the second consecutive quarter the company exceeded guidance," said Andrew Nowinski, a Piper Jaffray analyst, in a report.RELATED:Lumentum Stock Breaks Out On Apple iPhone 3D Sensor SpeculationZendesk Q4 Billings Beat, 2017 Sales Forecast Tops ViewsPaycom Revenue Outlook Tops Street Amid ObamaCare Uncertainty

Fiscal Q1 sales should climb 3% to $4.979 billion.Results: Q1 EPS of 39 cents excluding a variety of items. Sales edged up nearly 2% to $4.9 billion. The organic and natural foods grocer pioneer has struggled with high prices as competitors proliferate, including pure-play Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) and mainline grocer Kroger (KR).Estimates: Qualys is expected to report a 14% EPS decline to 18 cents, with sales up 18% to $52.62 million.Results: Qualys earned 23 cents, with sales of $52.2 million.Outlook: Qualys sees Q1 EPS of 17-19 cents with sales of $52 million to $53 million. Analysts expected EPS of 21 cents and sales of $54.48 million. For the full-year, Qualys predicts EPS of 81-86 cents and revenue of $224 million to $228 million. Wall Street had been looking for EPS of 91 cents and revenue of $233.51 million.Stock: Shares fell nearly 8% in late trade. The stock had closed up 0.3% to 36.85 after rising intraday above a 37.10 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Shares peaked above that entry on Feb. 3, but pulled back on Monday.Cybersecurity stocks were hot for much of 2016, but have slumped. Fortinet (FTNT), Check Point Software (CHKP) and Symantec (SYMC) reported strong results in recent weeks, but FireEye (FEYE) plunged on its quarterly figures.RELATED:Do Fortinet, Check Point Earnings Mean Upside For Palo Alto, Cisco?MaxLinear Beats Q4 Targets, But Sales Guidance Lags, Stock Falls

Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) is well-positioned if the security software market consolidates amid a slowdown in corporate spending, says Jefferies, which hiked its price target on Check Point stock.Jefferies analyst John DiFucci increased his price target on Check Point to 118 from 110."As the pioneer of important firewall technology that provides the cornerstone of its platform, Check Point is well positioned for a consolidating IT security market," said DiFucci in his research report. "Moderating security industry growth will affect most vendors, including Check Point, and while there remain uncertainties around the cloud, CHKP's bias toward enterprises and the data center/cloud perimeter should at least partially offset these potential headwinds."DiFucci, who published an in-depth report on the security market, has buy ratings on Mimecast (MIME), Varonis (VRNS) and Splunk (SPLK) and hold ratings on Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Symantec (SYMC).IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Computer-Software Security group ranks just No. 157 out of 197 industry groups. The group fell 16% in 2016, but it's up in 2017, in part on expectations that M&A activity will pick up. CyberArk Software has the group's highest Composite Rating. See how CR is an important CANSLIM investing metric.Check Point reports Q4 earnings before the open Thursday. Check Point stock finished 0.9% lower at 89.61 on the stock market today, but it's up 7% in 2017 and hit a 16-year high of 92.23 on Friday. Check Point stock is back in a buy range after breaking out of a cup-with-handle formation at 85.95 on Dec. 16.After a slew of high-profile data breaches in 2013-14, many companies rushed to upgrade firewalls that sit between private networks and the internet and invested in threat-detection technologies. The shift of IT infrastructure to the cloud has many companies reassessing spending priorities, analysts say."Corporations are overwhelmed with the plethora of seemingly endless technologies required to protect their enterprise and now accept that consolidation of the solution is a legitimate and welcome alternative," added DiFucci in the report. "Those vendors that can accomplish this as a contiguous platform play or those that can consolidate others' solutions should benefit."In order to accomplish or even simply pursue this nirvana, vendors have to be willing to break out of their "swim lanes" to address adjacent technology needs ... . We believe we will likely see increased acquisitions of point solutions that are among best-of-breed."RELATED:Could Microsoft Join Cisco In Hunt For Security Firms?Check Point, Rival Proofpoint Next Up For Security Company EarningsCisco, Palo Alto, Symantec Gear Up For Cloud Cybersecurity Shift

Shares of computer security providers Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), Proofpoint (PFPT) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) have gained in 2017 as analysts debate which companies can outperform amid a tougher environment in the once-hot sector.Palo Alto stock has climbed 10%, while shares of Proofpoint are up 14%. Check Point stock has gained 7% and hit a 16-year high on Friday. Check Point stock is still in a buy range after breaking out of a cup-with-handle formation at a buy point of 85.95 on Dec. 16.Check Point reports Q4 earnings before the open on Thursday, with Proofpoint following on Jan. 26. Palo Alto Networks is slated to report fiscal Q2 earnings in late February."Following the past two quarters of challenging results across the cybersecurity space, we are more optimistic that companies have now, broadly speaking, reset growth expectations to more achievable levels," said Jonathan Ho, a William Blair analyst, in a research report Tuesday.IBD'S TAKE: Two weeks into the new year, the mining sector has shown solid gains. The stocks of gold and metal ores have been rising from December lows as mixed economic data and uncertainty about President-elect Donald Trump's policies. Learn more at IBD Sector Leaders.His top picks include CyberArk Software (CYBR), Check Point and Palo Alto.At Citigroup, analyst Walter Pritchard's lone buy recommendation in the group is Proofpoint.Fortinet (FTNT) and FireEye (FEYE) both report earnings on Feb. 2, with CyberArk and Mimecast (MIME) following on Feb. 9.IBD's Computer-Software Security group ranks No. 153 out of 197 industry groups. The group fell 16% in 2017, but it's up 7% in 2017 as of midday trading in the stock market today."Security has lagged with slowing growth, low sentiment, and market rotation," said Melissa Gorham, a Morgan Stanley analyst, in a report. "We lean more favorably into 2017 as expectations have reset against a stabilizing demand environment, with easing comps and valuations well below historical averages."Morgan Stanley has buy ratings on Fortinet, Palo Alto, Proofpoint and Symantec (SYMC).Analysts estimate Check Point's Q4 earnings rose 4% year over year to 1.25 per share, with revenue rising 4% to $477.8 million.Check Point stock ended Tuesday trading down a fraction to 90.39 at the close, after peaking at 92.23 on Friday."Coming off a mixed year for network security vendors, our checks pointed to a slightly better quarter while investors will likely focus on management's initial cut at 2017 guidance," said Matthew Hedberg, an RBC Capital analyst, in a report on Check Point.In the September quarter, he noted several security firms, on their earnings conference calls, said they saw longer sales cycles.After a slew of high-profile data breaches in 2013-14, many companies rushed to upgrade firewalls that sit between private networks and the internet and invested in threat-detection technologies. That uptick in crisis spending drove security software stocks to fresh highs in mid-2015.The shift of IT infrastructure to the cloud has many companies reassessing spending priorities, analysts say.RELATED:Cisco, Palo Alto, Symantec Gear Up For Cloud Cybersecurity ShiftCould Microsoft Join Cisco In Hunt For Security Firms?

Samsung Electronics will boost shareholder returns and review its corporate structure, the South Korean titan said Tuesday adopting many of the reforms urged by activist fund Elliott Management.Samsung will return 50% of free cash flow to shareholders through next year vs. its prior pledge to return 30%-50%. That implies a return of 9.5 trillion won ($8.1 billion). It will boost dividends by 30% in 2016 to a total of 4 trillion won, with the rest spend on share buybacks.Samsung has a dividend yield of about 1.3% vs. 2% at Apple (AAPL), 2.6% at Microsoft (MSFT) and 3.4% at IBM (IBM).The Korea corporate giant will spend the next six months reviewing the possibility of creating a holding company and listing on more exchanges.All that spells a partial victory for Elliott Management, led by billionair Paul Elliott Singer. Last October, Elliott Management urged a U.S. listing, a 30 trillion won special dividend and a split into an operating company and holding company. Elliott also proposed three independent directors on Samsung's board.Samsung is struggling with the fallout from its Note 7 smartphone overheating fiasco, which tarnished its image and left a product hole as Apple launched its iPhone 7, seen as an incremental not revolutionary handset advance. Samsung also is linked somewhat to an influence-peddling scandal that has engulfed President Park Geun-hye.Elliott Management has been busy, and successful, and spurring companies to boost shareholder value via cash returns or put themselves up for sale.Cognizant Technology Solutions (CTSH) leapt 7% on the stock market today after Elliott disclosed a 4% stake in the IT services firm. It wants Cognizant to buy back $2.5 billion in stock in the first half of 2017. Cognizant said it would review Elliott's letter.Earlier this month, chip design firm Mentor Graphics (MENT) accepted a $4.5 billion buyout from Germany's Siemens (SIEGY) after pressure from Elliott, which owns 8.1%. ID theft prevention services firm Lifelock (LOCK) took a $2.3 billion deal from cybersecurity firm Symantec (SYMC) after urging from Elliott, which owns 11%.RELATED:Cognizant Stock Jumps On Elliott Stake, Buyback UrgedSiemens Grows Digital Business With $4.5 Billion Mentor Graphics BuySymantec Rallies On LifeLock Deal

Symantec (SYMC) will buy LifeLock (LOCK), which provides identity theft protection services, the companies said late Sunday, following media reports that a deal had been reached. Meanwhile, Palo Alto Networks (PANW) crashed following earnings after Monday's close.Symantec will pay $2.3 billion cash, or 24 a share, for LifeLock, the companies said in a statement. They expect the deal will close in the first quarter of 2017. That's a 16% premium to LifeLock's Friday close of 20.75. It's 36% more than LifeLock's share price when reports on Nov. 11 arose that the ID theft firm was mulling a sale.LifeLock rose nearly 15% to 23.81 on the stock market today.Symantec rose 3.2% to 24.52, but was unable to close above its 50-day moving average. The stock fell 5% last week amid buzz that Symantec was interested in LifeLock. Symantec is in a flat base with a 25.82 buy point."As we all know, consumer cybercrime has reached crisis levels. LifeLock is a leading provider of identity and fraud protection services, with over 4.4 million highly-satisfied members and growing. With the combination of Norton and LifeLock, we will be able to deliver comprehensive cyber defense for consumers," said Greg Clark, Symantec's CEO.Symantec will combine LifeLock with Norton Security anti-virus to provide a broader consumer cybersecurity solution. Norton Security revenue has been falling as Symantec shifts from opt-out licenses to opt-in subscriptions.Elliott Management, which owns 11% of Lifelock, had urged the company to explore buyout bids.Symantec reiterated its fiscal 2017 and 2018 adjusted EPS guidance, predicting that the deal will boost profit in FY 2019.Symantec apparently beat out various private equity firms for LifeLock. Earlier this year, Symantec bought Blue Coat Systems for $4.65 billion and sold its data storage firm Veritas for $7.4 billion, as it emphasizes cybersecurity.IBD'S TAKE: Palo Alto Networks is one of three top-rated companies near buy points with earnings this week.Cybersecurity stocks struggled for much of 2016, but a few are at or near buy points in addition to Symantec.Meanwhile, Palo Alto Networks (PANW) crashed 13% to 140 in late trading. Palo Alto Networks closed down 0.2% to 161.06.Palo Alto topped earnings forecasts, but missed on sales and gave weak guidance.Analysts expect Palo Alto to post a 51% earnings per share gain to 53 cents, with revenue up 34% to $400 million.Palo Alto broke out on Thursday past a 163.11 buy point, but pulled back to 161.35 on Friday.Proofpoint (PFPT) broke out past a 79.88 buy point on Nov. 11 but is now extended from a sound entry area. Proofpoint rose 1% to 87.44 at the close, but was trading near 66 following Palo Alto's results.CyberArk Software (CYBR) is working on a cup base, finding support at its 200-day line in late October and early November. Since then it's been building the right side of a consolidation, with a buy point of 59.38. CyberArk advanced 0.3% to 54.62 at the close, but dipped to around 53 in late trade.RELATED:Black Friday, Apple, Sina, Weibo In Focus For Investing Action PlanIf Trump Bump Holds, Will Palo Alto, Cybersecurity Stocks Rise?

Stocks started the holiday-shortened week higher Monday, as oil prices, earnings reports and mergers and acquisitions fueled trading.The Dow industrials climbed 0.3%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Nasdaq 0.5%.Markets will be closed Thursday, followed by a half-day session Friday.Exxon Mobil (XOM) rose 1% as oil and energy issues climbed i the stock market today.Tyson Foods (TSN) collapsed 16% after its fiscal fourth-quarter results missed analyst targets by wide margins. Management lowered its full-year earnings guidance, but said the first seven weeks of the year have been "phenomenal" and the best start to a year the company has experienced. Tyson shares have been correcting since September.Novartis (NVS) announced it would pay $665 million for privately held Selexys Pharmaceuticals, following positive trial results for a treatment for pain related to sickle-cell disease. Novartis slipped 1% at the open.IBD 50 stock LifeLock (LOCK) jumped 15% at the open. Antivirus software developer Symantec (SYMC) said Sunday it would acquire the Tempe, Ariz.-based Identity protection service for $2.3 billion in cash. Symantec shares opened 2% lower.Utah-based Headwaters (HW) spiked 17% on news that Boral, based in Australia, would buy the building products firm for $186 billion in cash.International Game Technology (IGT) swung up 4% after a solid third-quarter report. The maker of gaming equipment for casinos and lotteries said the beat was driven primarily by strong lottery sales in North America and Italy. The IBD 50 stock hit a new high.Acorda Therapeutics (ACOR) dropped 7% after clinical trials showed efficiency of the drug compound dalfampridine, a treatment for post-stroke patient mobility, did not support further development.Monday's economic calendar was quiet, aside from a speech by Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer in New York at 8 a.m. ET. Fischer said, among other things, that new government policies, particularly those aimed at productivity, could take some of the pressure off the Fed's stimulus role in supporting the economy.In oil futures, West Texas Intermediate headed north from $46 a barrel, up nearly 2%. Gold ticked up 1% to above $1,215 an ounce. The dollar slipped and bonds climbed, trimming the 10-year yield 4 basis points to 2.32%.Overseas markets were positive, with China's Shanghai Composite and Tokyo Nikkei 225 in Japan ending up 0.8% apiece. The Hong Kong Hang Seng Index added 0.1%.Europe's markets showed uneven gains in afternoon trade. The DAX in Frankfurt added 0.4%, London's FTSE 100 trimmed earlier gains to a fraction. The CAC 40 in Paris was up 0.5%.

All three major indexes rose early Monday morning, following a spate of M&A activity and higher oil prices in the stock market today.The Nasdaq, up 0.7%, was back to record highs after reversing lower on Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were also higher, up 0.2% and 0.5%.Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX) led the Dow.Volume trended lower on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq, which is typical behavior of a holiday-shortened week.The top 10 biggest winners in the S&P 500 were all energy-related, as crude prices rallied higher.Chevron was up over 1.5% as the stock reached a new 52-week high. Despite a lack of current earnings growth, the stock has been outperforming the general market recently as oil prices have rebounded. Although its current earnings prospects are poor, the company's fiscal year earnings are projected to rise 243% to $4.60 per share. The stock is 3% past a flat base entry of 107.68.Mergers and acquisitions were among the highlights of the day.IBD 50 member LifeLock (LOCK) was up 15% after Symantec (SYMC) agreed to acquire the company for $2.3 billion. Symantec hopes the U.S. identity theft protection services company will prop up its Norton anti-virus sales, which have been in decline. Symantec was up slightly on the news.Novartis (NVS) announced it acquired Selexys Pharmaceutical for $665 million after the company's positive trial results of SelG1, a treatment for pain related to sickle-cell disease. Novartis edged 1% lower.Australia's Boral agreed to purchase Utah-based Headwaters (HW) for $1.86 billion in cash. The U.S. building-products firm was up 18%.Facebook (FB) announced a $6 billion buyback, its first repurchase program. The program will begin in Q1 2017. In response, the stock was up over 2.5%.The stock fallen on hard times over the last few weeks as institutional money has rotated out of large-cap technology stocks. Last week, Facebook closed below its 40-week moving average line for the first time since its original breakout back in July 2013. Over the last five weeks, the stock's RS Rating has declined from 85 to 45, signaling drastic market underperformance.Crude prices showed strength this morning and were up 2.5%. Oil futures are set to retake the 50-day moving average line ahead of the OPEC deal decision later this month. The dollar weakened, which would snap the currency's 10-day winning streak.Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer remarked the economy is in "the vicinity" of the Federal Reserve's employment and inflation goals. Fed speakers, over the past couple weeks, have set the stage for an interest rate hike when the central bank meets next month.RELATED:Symantec Will Buy ID Theft Blocker LifeLock; Palo Alto Near Buy Before EarningsFacebook Will Buy Back $6 Billion In Shares As Stock Slide Continues
