Now next-generation firewall provider Palo Alto Networks (PANW) is trying to enter a new buy zone. But keep…

Security software stocks sold off Tuesday on Palo Alto Networks' (PANW) disappointing earnings and Goldman Sachs' downgrade of FireEye (FEYE) to sell based on a weak 2017 outlook.Shares of Palo Alto Networks tumbled 13% to a nearly three-month low, while FireEye skidded 5.5% in the stock market today.Palo Alto Networks blamed its miss for the quarter ended Oct. 31 partly on a longer sales cycle and large deals that did not close in the quarter, some of which it said have since been booked. Last month, Fortinet (FTNT) CEO Ken Xie cited "a moderated spending environment, extended sales cycles and sales execution challenges" as impacting his company's Q3 results.Among other security software leaders, CyberArk Software (CYBR) stock fell 3.1%, Proofpoint (PFPT) 2.9%, and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) a fraction. Proofpoint's fall, though, put it back into buy range from an 80.77 buy point first touched on Nov. 10.Barracuda Networks (CUDA) stock fell just a fraction, though, and Fortinet bucked the trend, rising 1.6%.Symantec (SYMC), which earlier this week agreed to buy LifeLock, rose 2.4% to 25.11, above its 50-day line and approaching a buy point of 25.82.IBD's 25 company Computer Software-Security industry group fell 3.2% Tuesday, falling below its 50-day support line. It was the second-worst performer among IBD's 197 groups. Telecom-Infrastructure, with Dycom Industries (DY) plunging 20% on an earnings miss, was the worst.IBD'S TAKE: The Computer-Software Security group ranks just No. 86 out of 197 industry groups. IBD's Sector Leaders features growth stocks among some better groups, stocks such as Western Alliance Bancorp, Inphi, Essent Group and Gigamon."A second quarter in a row of deteriorating growth likely puts Palo Alto into the penalty box," Morgan Stanley analyst Keith Weiss said in a research report. "However, we still see the company as best positioned to benefit from increasing consolidation of spend in the security space," added Weiss, who maintained an overweight rating on Palo Alto Networks.Meanwhile, Gabriela Borges, a Goldman Sachs analyst, downgraded FireEye to sell from neutral."We recognize that FireEye is taking significant action with product positioning and cost optimization to improve its long-term growth prospects," said Borges in her report. "However, we expect fundamentals to remain pressured in 2017 owing to changes in customer buying patterns, and we believe that FireEye's strategy to move into the midmarket will be difficult to execute."After a slew of high-profile data breaches in 2013-14, many companies rushed to upgrade security technology.That uptick in "crisis spending" drove security software stocks to fresh highs in mid-2015 as valuations soared. Price competition has intensified among providers following a moderation of security spending in late 2015 and into 2016. Cisco Systems (CSCO) push into the security market has also pressured margins, analysts say.One issue, analysts say, is that companies are digesting new technologies acquired the past few years. Some corporate customers are shifting to cloud computing infrastructure, and are reassessing spending priorities. Palo Alto has forecast a pickup in security spending by the latter half of 2017.RELATED:Proofpoint 'Continues To Separate From Security Pack' As Q3 BeatsGrowth-Needy Cisco Aiming To Be Top Dog In Security Vs. Palo AltoCybersecurity "Supercycle" Over? The major averages closed at all-time highs as big-cap techs and oil and gas stocks did the heavy lifting.The Dow Jones industrial average lagged slightly with a 0.5% gain, but Apple (AAPL), IBM (IBM), Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) showed gains of 1% or more. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking lower than Friday's levels in the stock market today.The Nasdaq led the way, rising 0.9%, while the S&P 500 added 0.8%.The Dow, Nasdaq and S&P 500 all hit record highs on Monday, along with various small- and mid-cap indexes.So-called FANG stocks — Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL) — outperformed in the Nasdaq 100, with gains ranging from 1% to 4%.December West Texas intermediate crude oil futures jumped 3.9% to $47.49 a barrel, helping many of IBD's oil and gas-related groups outperform. Oil was strong after Russian President Vladimir Putin said the country is ready to freeze output. OPEC is meeting Nov. 30, and the market is expecting some sort of production cut to stabilize prices.Among oil and gas producers, EOG Resources (EOG) is working on a flat base with a 98.42 buy point. Devon Energy (DVN) is also carving a flat base, not far from a 45.72 buy point.IBD 50 member LifeLock (LOCK) was up 15% after Symantec (SYMC) agreed to acquire the company for $2.3 billion. Symantec rose more than 3%.Separately, Australia's Boral agreed to purchase Utah-based infrastructure firm Headwaters (HW) for $1.86 billion in cash. Headwaters vaulted 17% on the news.Also in the IBD 50, Arista Networks (ANET) soared 7.4% to 94.48. Headed into Monday, Arista's breakout over an 87.72 buy point looked sluggish at best, but big buyers were in the stock Monday.E.l.f. Beauty (ELF) bounced back after a nasty reversal last week. Shares rose more than 3% to 30.31. It's just in range past a flat base buy point of 29.02.Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Jack in the Box (JACK) fell fractionally ahead of their earnings report after the close. Palo Alto is just below a 163.11 buy point, while Jack in the Box is vying for a breakout over a 102.78 buy point. Both names were featured as option plays ahead of earnings in the latest IBD Weekly.The stock market will be closed Thursday for Thanksgiving.RELATED:Symantec Will Buy ID Theft Blocker Lifelock; Palo Alto Near Buy Before EarningsApple Quits Wireless Router Business: ReportFacebook Stock Buyback May Signal Slower Growth As Company Matures

A shortened week of trading kicked off Monday with solid gains for the major stock indexes as the Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite notched all-time closing highs. Oil prices surged, and the Russell 2000 extended its winning streak to 12 sessions. December-delivery West Texas intermediate crude oil futures settled at $47.49 a barrel, up nearly 4%, as traders grew…

U.S. stock indexes sprinted ahead Monday, with the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 scoring new highs.The Nasdaq advanced 0.9%, while the S&P 500 stayed close with a 0.7% gain. The blue chip Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%. The small-cap Russell 2000 trailed with a 0.3% pop. Volume in the stock market today was down about 10% on the NYSE and 5% on the Nasdaq.Oil prices leapt about 4%, and the NYSE energy sector index rose 2.3%.Although the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 both pegged all-time highs, it wasn't clear if that would stick, because the indexes are just barely at new highs.Initial public offering The Trade Desk (TTD) cleared a 29.57 buy point in a double-bottom base. Because the stock debuted Sept. 21 on the Nasdaq, it doesn't yet have a 50-day moving average. But daily dollar volume is more than $20 million, an amount that suggests institutional participation.Trade Desk is a digital ad company. The company grew earnings 100% to 20 cents a share in Q2, on a year-ago basis. In Q3, earnings increased 71% to 24 cents a share. The Street expects earnings to check in at 88 cents a share, a 105% increase, in full year 2016. But 2017 earnings are expected to dip 3%.Strength among IPOs is a good sign for the stock market. Since Jan. 1, the IBD New Issues Index is up 7.3%.Meanwhile, blue chip winners outpaced losers by a 3-1 ratio. The biggest gainer on the 30-stock Dow was IBM (IBM), which rose 1.6% in average volume. The stock cleared a handle, but the handle showed some bearish wedging action. IBM lacks elite ratings. The stock has an EPS Rating of 38, which means 62% of the stocks in IBD's database are growing earnings faster.In the IBD 50, a proxy for top rated stocks, advancing issues led losers by a 7-to-2 ratio. The biggest gainer was financial security specialist LifeLock (LOCK), which jumped 15% on news that Symantec (SYMC) would acquire it for $2.3 billion in cash. Symantec rose 4% in heavy volume.In the S&P 500, the day's biggest gainer was Marathon Petroleum (MPC). The big-cap oil company broke out of a base with an 8% gap up.Economic news was on the slow side. The Chicago Fed National Activity Index fell 0.08, which was at least better than the 0.23 drop expected.Comments from current and former Federal Reserve members suggested that a December interest rate hike is all but certain. In Dallas, former Fed member Richard Fisher told CNBC, "The mantra has become low interest rates for too long is doing enormous damage to the infrastructure, the financial infrastructure." Stanley Fischer, the Federal Reserve's vice chair, appearing before the Council on Foreign Relations, said the right kind of government spending could boost the economy.RELATED:The Trade Desk Gets Back In Gear With Q3 BeatTrade Desk Is The Little Company Taking On Google And Facebook

The main indexes got some elevation in afternoon trading Friday, as the market looked to snap an eight-day losing streak.The Nasdaq climbed 0.6% as Facebook (FB) crept up 1% in big volume. Still, Facebook recovered only a small portion of Thursday's 5.6% rout following its earnings report and cautious outlook.The S&P 500 rose 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3% as General Electric (GE) and Caterpillar (CAT) led with 1.6% gains. Small caps spearheaded the market, with the Russell 2000 surging 1.4%. All four indexes were at session highs.Volume was running moderately higher across the board. Advancers led decliners by a 2-to-1 ratio on the NYSE and by a 12-to-5 ratio on the Nasdaq. Building, metals and some retail stocks were leading the market.Generic-drug companies bounced back a bit -- and were one of the top groups Friday -- after the industry was routed Thursday on a Bloomberg report that the Justice Department is investigating possible price collusion. Of the 14 stocks in the group, four were up more than 5% but all were small caps. Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA), the largest by market capitalization, was up less than 2% after sinking 9.5% Thursday.CBS (CBS) climbed 3%, rising back above the 56.95 buy point of a cup with handle base in active trading. The broadcaster beat profit and sales expectations late Thursday. Adjusted earnings rose 19% to $1.05 a share. Revenue of $3.4 billion rose 4%. The political conventions and competition from NBC's Summer Olympics cut into its Q3 ad revenue, but it also saw higher political spending.Air Lease (AL) jumped 7% after it reported earnings. The airline jet leasing company is forming the right side of a saucer pattern with a possible buy point at 33.20. It's part of a larger consolidation dating back to may 2015. After a meager increase in 2015 profit, Air Lease is expected to increase EPS by 44% this year. It has an EPS Rating 98.Symantec (SYMC) plunged 8%, piercing its 50-day moving average in heavy volume, a break of support for a stock that had been performing well up to now. The maker of the Norton security software beat profit estimates but gave a forecast that some saw as weak.Symantec also announced that Chief Financial Officer Thomas Seifert is stepping down at the end of the month but will stay on longer during a transition period. He's being replaced by Nick Noviello, formerly CFO of Blue Coat, a company Symantec acquired.RELATED:Generic-Drug Makers Crash On Report DOJ Plans Collusion ChargesFireEye Rebound In Making? Imperva To Stay Independent

FireEye (FEYE) stock popped on views the computer security software provider is making progress toward its goal of profitability exiting 2017, while Imperva (IMPV) won four upgrades following a better-than-expected Q3 and management shelving a company sale.FireEye stock ended the day up 12.1% on the stock market today, while Imperva was up 1.3%, after both reported earnings beats late Thursday. Symantec (SYMC) late Thursday posted a mixed report, and its shares ended Friday's session down 7.7%.All this left IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group up 0.4%. But the group has been in a downtrend the past month, and ranks No. 55 of 197 groups. Chips remain No. 1 out of 33 sectors.IBD'S TAKE: Corporate spending on computer security to prevent data breaches remains strong, but priorities are shifting. Learn more from this industry report on cloud cybersecurity trends.FireEye aid it cut its per-share loss minus items to 16 cents from 37 cents in Q3 2015, as sales rose 13% to $186.4 million. Analysts had modeled a 31-cent per-share loss on revenue of $182.6 million."FireEye surprisingly beat the high-end of guidance in Q3, despite the ongoing restructuring, sales leadership changes and product transitions the company is going through," Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski said in a research report.Still, FireEye lowered its Q4 billings and revenue guide."FireEye delivered a solid quarter beating on all metrics despite significant upheaval in the company's sales and marketing organization during the quarter," William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho said in a report. "We view the results as a positive sign that FireEye has reset expectations appropriately and is executing against its plan to stabilize costs."Meanwhile, D.A. Davidson, Evercore, Needham and Macquaries Securities upgraded Imperva to buy.Buyout firms Silver Lake Management and Thoma Bravo, according to reports, have been interested in acquiring Redwood Shores, Calif.-based Imperva. Activist investor Elliott Management disclosed in June that it had amassed about 10% stake in Imperva."Imperva's board concluded its strategic review and believes remaining stand-alone is the best option along with a cost reduction initiative," said Matthew Hedberg, an RBC Capital analyst, in a report. "The company (aims) to bolster profitability and competitiveness by reducing sales, marketing, and general and administrative expenses through reductions in head count and spending."Symantec announced a new chief financial officer along with its September-quarter earnings.Symantec said fiscal Q2 revenue rose 12% to $1.02 billion, including the Blue Coat acquisition, above the consensus estimate of $974.8 million. Symantec left its current quarter and full-year revenue guidance unchanged."Management did not push forward the higher revenue trends and as a result December and fiscal year revenue guide was below Street," said a Citigroup report.CyberArk Software (CYBR) early Thursday posted Q3 EPS ex items of 33 cents, up 27% from the year-earlier quarter and well ahead of the 23-cent estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Sales rose 37% to $55 million, topping views for $52.3 million. CyberArk stock rose 6.4% on the report, but dipped 0.2% Friday.Palo Alto Networks (PANW) reports earnings on Nov. 21.Palo Alto Networks stock finished Friday up 1.7%, while Proofpoint (PFPT) was up 0.6%.Many security firms are having to deal with Cisco Systems (CSCO) as it pushes deeper into the security market, which has increased pricing pressure.RELATED:Security Firms FireEye, Imperva, CyberArk Beat; Symantec MixedCheck Point Software Q3 Earnings Beat Boosts Security StocksCybersecurity 'Supercycle' Ending?Proofpoint 'Separating From Security Pack'Barracuda Networks Q2 Beats Views On Cloud Growth; Fortinet Misses

During an unforgiving earnings season in a weak market, even stocks that post solid quarterly EPS growth can run into resistance. After topping Q3 estimates, Proofpoint, Barracuda Networks and Checkpoint initially jumped, but have since pulled back to varying degrees. In a big day for cybersecurity stocks, Qualys, FireEye (FEYE),…

Major stock indexes were mixed and mostly unchanged near midday Thursday ahead of Friday's jobs report, which economists expect to show nonfarm payrolls rose by 178,000.The Nasdaq composite eased 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 edged higher. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly lower than Wednesday's levels.In currency news, the British pound soared after judges ruled the U.K. can't exit the European Union without approval from Parliament.In the stock market today, Facebook (FB) slumped 4.5% despite another quarter of solid growth across several metrics. Investors focused instead on comments from the company that ad revenue growth is expected to slow in coming quarters.Itron (ITRI) gapped up powerfully, soaring 15% after reporting better-than-expected earnings late Wednesday. The company provides metering solutions to electricity, gas and water utility marketsVolume was heavy in Adobe Systems (ADBE) as shares rose nearly 2%. It's getting support at its 10-week moving average after a breakout in September. The company on Wednesday hosted an analyst meeting and gave preliminary financial targets for its fiscal year 2017.Shares of CyberArk Software (CYBR) soared 8% to 48.77 on earnings, but its still below its 50-day moving average near 50, a potential resistance level to watch.IBD'S TAKE: Good news from CyberArk could be good news for other security software names set to report after the close today, including Symantec (SYMC), FireEye (FEYE) and Imperva (IMPV).Inside the IBD 50, CommScope (COMM) and Masimo (MASI) were big earnings winners, up 6% and 5%, respectively. CommScope is trying to clear a long consolidation with a handle that shows a  32.57 buy point. Masimo gapped up but gave back early gains as it trades below its 50-day moving average.RELATED:Facebook Dives On Forecast For 'Meaningfully' Slower Ad Revenue GrowthCan Triple-Digit Growth Protect This Top Cybersecurity Stock?

Growth-needy Cisco Systems (CSCO) will likely make it a lot tougher on rival security-software providers — at least before it buys more of them.Amid Cisco's disappointing revenue outlook for fiscal Q2 late Wednesday, security remains a bright spot. Cisco's security revenue in its fiscal Q1 ended Oct. 29 rose 11% from the year-earlier quarter, to about $540 million. Security revenue was flat from the previous quarter, though.Cisco, the longtime leader in networking gear, aims to take share vs. security software leaders Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Fortinet (FTNT), FireEye (FEYE) and other security software rivals. Price competition is likely to intensify in corporate firewalls and other areas."Cisco security continues to grow with the firewall market (if not potentially better) making it tougher for competitors, especially the more recent challengers in the market, to take share," said Walter Pritchard, a Citigroup analyst, in a research report.IBD'S TAKE: Cisco stock is up nearly 16% in 2016, owing in part to its dividend. Rival Arista Networks is No. 13 in the IBD 50 ranking of top-performing stocks. Learn more on Arista at IBD Stock Checkup.On Cisco's fiscal Q1 earnings conference call, management said the company added 5,300 new customers for its next-generation firewall offering, bringing its total to over 62,000, with revenue for that product growing 35%."Palo Alto reports results on Nov. 21," added Pritchard, "which based on Cisco's strength likely mutes potential upside as Cisco security continues to show stability and hold on to more installations." The Citigroup analyst says Cisco could also be pressuring Fortinet.Cisco acquired Sourcefire for $2.7 billion in 2013. More recent purchases include OpenDNS, Lancope and CloudLock. Pritchard and other analysts have viewed FireEye as a potential Cisco target."We're the only company with security product revenue exceeding $2 billion annualized run rate with double-digit growth," Cisco CEO Charles Robbins said on the call.Check Point's quarterly revenue recently topped $428 million, with Palo Alto at about $400 million. Fortinet had quarterly revenue of $316 million, with FireEye at $186 million and Proofpoint (PFPT) at $100 million. Symantec (SYMC) has an annual run-rate of over $2 billion, but that includes nonsecurity products. IBM (IBM) also has sizable security software and services revenue."We had strong performance in our advanced threat security, up 100%, as well as web security solutions, which was up 60%," added Robbins on the call.Cisco said fiscal Q1 earnings per share minus items rose 3% to 61 cents from the year-earlier period. Revenue slipped 3% to $12.4 billion. Analysts had modeled EPS minus items of 59 cents on revenue of $12.33 billion.For the current quarter, Cisco forecast non-GAAP EPS of 56 cents. It forecast a revenue drop of 3% at the midpoint of its guidance. Analysts had projected 59 cents and $12.15 billion. That guidance sent shares falling 4.8% in the stock market today, hitting a four-month low below 30.RELATED:Palo Alto Networks Breaks Out Ahead Of Earnings, Price-Target HikedJuniper Set Up To Do Better Vs. Cisco, Arista: Goldman SachsApple, Microsoft, Cisco Eye Trump Overseas Cash Tax PlanCisco Rival Arista Networks Beats On Earnings, Sales, Guidance

Apple (AAPL) approached a buy point and most of the FANG stocks rose modestly Wednesday, now six weekdays since the surprise presidential election of Donald Trump — who has had some pointed criticism for the tech industry — sent big tech stocks tumbling before modestly rebounding the past two days.In fact, Apple and the other large FANG internets — Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL) — had started falling at least two weeks before Election Day (except for Google-owner Alphabet, whose downturn began Oct. 28). All four FANGs had been trading at or near all-time highs, but mixed earnings for Apple, Amazon and Alphabet weighed on the group.But after the election, a sector rotation ensued, with industries such as drugs and banks getting a lift from Trump's win, and techs, alternative-energy and other arenas getting hit.IBD'S TAKE: The biggest tech companies, of course, aren't necessarily the best tech stocks for investors at any given time. Which techs are best? There are tons of opinions and answers when asking that question, but a good source to put on your checklist is IBD's Tech Leaders.But Trump's election-campaign views and expected priorities have good as well as bad connotations for tech industries.William Blair analyst Bhavan Suri summed it up in a research note Wednesday:"Overall, we believe his views on global trade, net neutrality and internet privacy, and immigration could have negative consequences for technology companies, but his tax plan (including reducing the repatriation tax rate to 10%) would be a net positive given the large amount of foreign cash that many technology companies possess."Trump's repatriation tax plan could bring big bucks back to the U.S. for the top five companies with overseas holdings. Besides Apple and Alphabet, the top five include Microsoft (MSFT), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Oracle (ORCL).In his note, Suri was not shy about pointing out what Microsoft, Cisco and Oracle might target with that cash. Microsoft, he said, might go after ServiceNow (NOW), Twilio (TWLO) or Symantec (SYMC). Cisco he sees eyeing FireEye (FEYE), Gigamon (GIMO) and F5 Networks (FFIV). Oracle, he says, might take a run at Veeva Systems (VEEV) or Tableau Software (DATA).In the meantime, Apple, Alphabet, Amazon and Netflix rose for a second straight day. Facebook was the only decliner, falling 0.73% to 116.34, after touching a more than four-month low of 113.55 on Monday.Apple was the big gainer of the bunch on Wednesday, rising 2.7% to 110.04. That was easily its best day since Trump's win, marking its biggest percentage gain since Sept. 14. It is nearing a 118.79 buy point out of a flat base.Netflix stock rose a fraction to 115.17. It's forming a cup-with-handle base, with a buy point of 129.40.Shares of Alphabet and Amazon rose 0.62% and 0.39%, respectively.RELATED:Apple, FANGs Stop The Bleeding Post-Trump

Saying business and other enterprise customers continue to spend to prevent network breaches, Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) early Monday posted Q3 earnings and revenue that handily topped Wall Street estimates, sending shares of Check Point and other security software vendors rising."Customers continue to leverage the Check Point security platform and increase their adoption of our advanced security capabilities which is resulting in higher subscription revenues," company CEO Gil Shwed said in the earnings releases. "We continued to see strong sales of our SandBlast, Zero-Day Protection solutions, resulting in triple-digit growth as customers focus on prevention."The company reported sales of $428 million and EPS ex items of $1.13, where analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had forecast $1.08 and $423 million. Q4 guidance for EPS ex items and for sales also beat analyst consensus, William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho said in a research note.Year-over-year sales growth of 6%, however, was the smallest since Q4 2014, and the 8.7% growth in earnings per share minus items was the smallest rise since Q1 2014. UBS analyst Brent Thill, in a research report this month, said the software cybersecurity industry has been benefiting from a "binge-buying" growth mode after high-profile breaches at Target (TGT) and elsewhere, but that this "supercycle" was ending.IBD'S TAKE: The security group doesn't rank highly at the moment, but to learn about things like the CASB (cloud access security broker) market — where the players include Check Point, keep tabs on the IBD Industry Snapshot, which looks at the hot and potentially hot industry groups.After a slew of high-profile data breaches, many companies rushed to upgrade firewalls that sit between private networks and the internet and invested in threat detection technologies. "We expect the next stage of the spending cycle to intensify competitively, where incumbents — namely perimeter security vendors — are likely to contend with greater discounting tactics," Thill wrote at that time.On Monday, though, William Blair's Ho said Check Point's Q3 "product outperformance was driven by strong adoption of the company's next-generation firewalls ... .""While the environment remains competitive, we believe Check Point can continue to sustain market share when factoring in the revenue impact from the shift from product revenue to subscription revenue," Ho said in his research report, maintaining an outperform rating on Check Point stock.Check Point is No. 1 in firewalls, according to tech research firm Gartner, and also in unified threat management, or UTM.IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security group has rebounded from a big dip early this year, but it's down about 8% for the year and ranks just No. 51 out of 197 groups.Proofpoint (PFPT) is one of the top-rated companies in the group, and its earning beat on Oct. 20 lifted cybersecurity stocks. Its focus is on data loss and email protection, competing more directly with companies such as Symantec (SYMC) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) rather than Check Point.Check Point stock rose 4.4% in the stock market today, to 84.56, hitting a four-month-plus high. Shares of Cisco rose a fraction Monday, while Symantec stock rose 0.60% and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) rose 1.5%.RELATED:Cybersecurity 'Supercycle' Ending?Proofpoint 'Separating From Security Pack'

Proofpoint's (PFPT) Q3 beat and guidance raise earned the security software provider at least two price-target hikes from Wall Street analysts.Proofpoint late Thursday swung to a 19-cent non-GAAP profit in Q3, with revenue surging 44%, both metrics topping expectations, as did its Q4 guidance."Proofpoint continues to separate from the security pack as far as execution and momentum," said Matthew Hedberg, an RBC Capital analyst, in a research report. Hedberg raised his price target on Proofpoint stock to 85 from 80.At Piper Jaffray, analyst Andrew Nowinski raised his PT to 90 from 85."Proofpoint is benefiting from multiple growth drivers (Office365 products, McAfee transition, international expansion and an increase in business email compromise attacks," he said in a report.IBD'S TAKE: The Computer-Software Security group has dropped to No. 46 (out of 197) from No. 25 over the past five weeks. But business spending for some types of security technologies are strong. Proofpoint stock outperformed the group through August, then dipped. With Friday's gains, it's back to summer highs. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Q3 revenue rose 44% to $99.8 million, the company said. Analysts had estimated revenue of $94 million.Proofpoint stock, which touched an all-time high of 80.67 on Sept. 7, popped 11% to 77.39 in the stock market today.Proofpoint competes with Cisco Systems (CSCO), Symantec (SYMC) and FireEye (FEYE). FireEye and Symantec both report earnings on Nov. 3, as does security software firm Imperva (IMPV).Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Proofpoint specializes in email and data loss protection for corporate networks and cloud-computing infrastructure. Its software spots malware-ridden emails before they arrive in inboxes.  Tools identify "spear phishing," emails with personal information or legitimate-sounding requests that target specific accounts."While speculation about a security slowdown has increased following some indications in Q2 results and early Q3 misses, Proofpoint showed no signs that its core opportunity has slowed. In fact, demand-related metrics accelerated during the quarter," said Rob Owen, a Pacific Crest Securities analyst, in his research note late Thursday. Owen maintained a neutral rating on Proofpoint stock.RELATED:Cisco, Palo Alto, Symantec Gear Up For Cloud Cybersecurity Shift'Nimble' Proofpoint Breaks Out As It Takes Share From Cisco, SymantecBarracuda Networks Q2 Beats Views On Cloud Growth; Fortinet Misses

Proofpoint (PFPT) swung to a 19 cent non-GAAP profit in Q3, with revenue surging 44%, both topping expectations, sending shares in the security software provider up in after-hours trading. Its Q4 guidance also beat views.Proofpoint said it earned 19 cents minus items in the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with a 3-cent loss in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 44% to $99.8 million, the company said. Analysts had estimated revenue of $94 million and a 5-cent profit.Proofpoint stock jumped more than 10% in after-hours trading, after its earnings release. Shares rose a small fraction, to 69.78, in the regular session in the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: The Computer-Software Security group has dropped to No. 46 (out of 197) from No. 25 over the past five weeks. But business spending for some types of security technologies are strong, helping Barracuda Networks recently report Q3 results that topped views. Still, no security firms show up among the best-performing stocks over the past 52 weeks, which you can find at the IBD 50.Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Proofpoint specializes in email and data loss protection for corporate networks and cloud-computing infrastructure. Its software spots malware-ridden emails before they arrive in inboxes.  Tools identify "spear phishing," emails with personal information or legitimate-sounding requests that target specific accounts."Our ability to exceed expectations across all key metrics was driven by the strong demand for our advanced threat solutions, ongoing high competitive win rates, robust add-on activity, and consistently high renewal rates," Proofpoint CEO Gary Steele said in the earnings release. "The combination of our commitment to innovation, proven ability to enhance the company's next generation, cloud-based platform through recent acquisitions, and value we are creating with our expanding partner ecosystem, positions Proofpoint to maintain momentum for the remainder of the year and into 2017."For the current quarter, Proofpoint forecast revenue of $104 million and non-GAAP profit of 12 cents at the midpoint of its guidance vs. consensus estimates of $101 million and 6 cents.Proofpoint competes with Cisco Systems (CSCO), Symantec (SYMC) and FireEye (FEYE). FireEye and Symantec both report earnings on Nov. 3, as does security software firm Imperva (IMPV).Proofpoint's software provides email protection for Microsoft's (MSFT) cloud-based Office 365 productivity tools. Proofpoint might get a lift from Intel (INTC) spinning off its McAfee security business in a deal with private equity firm TPG, analysts say, if some McAfee users switch over to Proofpoint.RELATED:Cisco, Palo Alto, Symantec Gear Up For Cloud Cybersecurity Shift'Nimble' Proofpoint Breaks Out As It Takes Share From Cisco, SymantecBarracuda Networks Q2 Beats Views On Cloud Growth; Fortinet Misses

Three providers of computer network security software — Symantec (SYMC), FireEye (FEYE) and Imperva (IMPV) — reported earnings after the close Thursday, with Symantec posting mixed results and FireEye and Imperva posting solid beats.CyberArk Software (CYBR), meanwhile, early Thursday posted a Q3 beat on the top and bottom lines, and shares rose.All hoped to add to the momentum from earnings and sales beats posted in October by Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), Proofpoint (PFPT) and Barracuda Networks (CUDA).Fortinet's (FTNT), however, last month preannounced a Q3 profit warning that sent security stocks down amid worries over price competition.Another of the security leaders, Palo Alto Networks (PANW), reports earnings on Nov. 21.Since the earnings cycle began with Barracuda after the close Oct. 11, IBD's Computer Software-Security group is down 6%, falling a fraction Thursday.IBD'S TAKE: The 26-company Computer Software-Security group has rebounded from a big dip early this year, but ranks just No. 55 out of 197 groups. The security market is changing as customers shift computing resources to public cloud infrastructure. Lean more from this industry snapshot on cloud and security.CyberArk posted Q3 EPS ex items of 33 cents, up 27% from the year-earlier quarter  and well ahead of the 23-cent estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Sales rose 37% to $55 million, topping views for $52.3 million. CyberArk stock jumped 6.4% in the stock market today to 47.80. The IBD Software-Security group, however, dipped a fraction as tech stocks retreated once again.Symantec said earnings per share minus items for its fiscal Q2 ended Sept. 30 rose 3% to 30 cents, well ahead of the 20 cents analysts expected. But sales of $979 million only met expetations, and its EPS ex items guidance for fiscal Q3 of 27-29 cents was a shade less than the 30 cents analysts had modeled.The company also said CFO Thomas Seifert had resigned and would be replaced by Nick Noviello, CFO of recent acquisition Blue Coat Systems.Symantec stock was down 1.7% in after-hours trading, after its release.FireEye beat on the top and bottom lines, and with its Q4 guidance, sending its shares up 14% after hours. The company said it cut its per-share loss minus items to 16 cents from 37 cents in Q3 2015, as sales rose 13% to $186.4 million.Analyst had modeled a 31-cent per-share loss on revenue of $182.6 million.For Q4, FireEye guided to per-share loss minus items of 16-18 cents, where analysts had estimated a 20-cent loss.Imperva said Q3 revenue rose 7.9% to $68.4 million, where analyts had modeled $63.2 million. Earnings per share minus items fell 58% to 8 cents, but that was well about the 16-cent loss expected by analysts. And for Q4, Imperva guided to EPS ex items of 1-4 cents, where analysts had expected a 16-cent loss. Shares were flat after hours.Check Point on Oct. 31 reported sales of $428 million and EPS ex items of $1.13, where analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had forecast $1.08 and $423 million.Proofpoint late last Thursday swung to a 19-cent non-GAAP profit in Q3, with revenue surging 44%, with both metrics topping expectations, as did its Q4 guidance. And the Security-Software group rose 1.4% the next day.Editor's Note: Corrects to include CyberArk's Q3 earnings report released early Thursday.RELATED:Check Point Software Q3 Earnings Beat Boosts Security StocksCybersecurity 'Supercycle' Ending?Proofpoint 'Separating From Security Pack'Barracuda Networks Q2 Beats Views On Cloud Growth; Fortinet Misses

With cyberattacks becoming increasingly sophisticated and frequent, demand for cybersecurity solutions from firms like Proofpoint (PFPT), Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), Barracuda Networks (CUDA) and Symantec (SYMC) is on the rise. But will demand for cybersecurity stocks match the demand for cybersecurity products, especially in what's been an unforgiving earnings season and volatile market? Triple-Digit Earnings Growth Proofpoint beat estimates…

A U.S. software cybersecurity "supercycle" is on its last legs as corporate America rethinks spending priorities to prevent data breaches, says a UBS analyst."We are three years-plus into the cybersecurity spending 'supercycle,' where indiscriminate budgets and 'binge-buying' seen in 2014/2015 appear to be firmly behind us," said UBS analyst Brent Thill in a research report Thursday.After a slew of high-profile data breaches, many companies rushed to upgrade firewalls that sit between private networks and the internet and invested in threat detection technologies. Firewalls block unauthorized traffic from entering a private network."We expect the next stage of the spending cycle to intensify competitively, where incumbents — namely perimeter security vendors — are likely to contend with greater discounting tactics," said Thill.The UBS analyst contends that Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Symantec (SYMC), and CyberArk Software (CYBR) are still well-positioned as spending shifts to "data, app, endpoint, identity, and behavioral analytics initiatives."IBD's TAKE: While the IT security "supercycle' may be ebbing, some analysts say a supercycle is just beginning for suppliers of fiber-optic technology, such as Lumentum. Learn more from this industry snapshot. Optical stocks, though, have cooled lately. You can look for other fast growing companies at IBD Sector Leaders. Fortinet (FTNT) warned late Tuesday that it would miss Q3 consensus estimates, sending security stocks down on Wednesday. Shares of many security vendors fell again in the stock market today, though Fortinet rose 1.7% after crashing 10% on Wednesday, and Proofpoint (PFPT) rose a fraction.Barracuda on Tuesday reported Q3 earnings that topped estimates. Proofpoint reports earnings on Oct. 20.Cisco Systems (CSCO) stock, Barracuda Networks (CUDA) and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) all fell a fraction Thursday. Palo Alto Networks stock fell 1.9%, Symantec tumbled 2.7% , CyberArk Software fell 2.2% and FireEye (FEYE) fell 1.8%.Corporate spending on security appears to have slowed as more companies outsource business workloads to cloud computing service providers such as Amazon Web Services, part of Amazon.com (AMZN). Analysts say that price cutting among security software firms has intensified as spending on legacy products slows.RELATED:Barracuda Networks Q2 Beats Views On Cloud Growth; Fortinet MissesCisco, Palo Alto, Symantec Gear Up For Cloud Cybersecurity Shift

Proofpoint (PFPT) kicks off earnings for security software providers on Thursday, with the sector under scrutiny in the wake of Fortinet's (FTNT) profit warning last week.Security firms are dealing with intensified price competition as Cisco Systems (CSCO) pushes into the market, startups gain more market share, and IBM (IBM) makes under-the-radar customer pickups.A beat by Proofpoint might ease some worries, with Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) slated to report on Oct. 31. On Nov. 3, four security firms are expected to report earnings: CyberArk Software (CYBR), FireEye (FEYE), Imperva (IMPV) and Symantec (SYMC).IBD'S TAKE: The Computer-Software Security group in the past four weeks has dropped to No. 37 from No. 25 out of 197 industry groups. Its top-rated stocks include Barracuda Networks, which reported Q3 results that topped views, and Palo Alto Networks. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Proofpoint specializes in email protection and cloud-data loss protection. Proofpoint's revenue is expected to jump 36% to $94 million, with EPS of 5 cents compared with a 6-cent loss in the year-earlier quarter.Proofpoint stock closed up 0.9% at 70.91 in the stock market today, after touching a nearly three-month low of 68.04 on Wednesday."Proofpoint has a number of new or accelerating growth drivers in 2016 and 2017, including McAfee share gains, new partnerships such as Palo Alto, social media security adoption, and continued Microsoft Office 365 adoption," said Melissa Gorham, a Morgan Stanley analyst, who has a buy rating on Proofpoint stock.Citigroup analyst Walter Pritchard also is bullish on Proofpoint. "Investors will need to be 'choosy' in the security space. We like Proofpoint, where we see stable demand and company-specific drivers, as well as Symantec," Pritchard said in a research report.Joel Fishbein, an analyst at BTIG, expects a Q3 revenue beat. "We believe Proofpoint is in pole position to take advantage of businesses moving to the cloud via Microsoft's Office 365 applications," he wrote in a report.Matthew Hedberg at RBC Capital is another fan. "Proofpoint is coming off what we viewed as an inflection quarter as operating margins turned positive and should remain so…," he wrote in a report. "Proofpoint remains in front of a number of potential opportunities into 2017, while social media protection remains an additional call option."Other analysts are looking at other security companies for upside."We are generally more optimistic regarding CyberArk, Check Point Software, and Palo Alto Networks (PANW)," Jonathan Ho, an analyst at William Blair, said in a report. "We are more cautious on FireEye, as the company continues to work through a transition in its business."Barclays analyst Raimo Lenschow is looking at CyberArk, which has a number of governmental customers. "Tactically, we like the setup for CyberArk this quarter as September is the fiscal year-end for U.S. federal spending."Andrew Nowinski, a Piper Jaffray analyst, surveyed software security resellers in September. "We noted a modest decline in pricing pressure and an overall improvement in demand trends," said Nowinski. "From a vendor perspective, Palo Alto had the strongest demand trends and Check Point's results were largely in line, while trends for FireEye deteriorated."RELATED:Barracuda Networks Q2 Beats Views On Cloud Growth; Fortinet MissesPalo Alto Networks 'Deceleration' Worries Investors; Stock Down

Fortinet's (FTNT) Q3 profit warning sent software security stocks Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Proofpoint (PFPT),  falling Wednesday, as worries over price competition mounted.Fortinet stock plunged 10.1% to close at 30.66 on the stock market today. Shares of Palo Alto pared a near-4% loss to just 0.8%, ending the day at 154.22. Proofpoint lost more than 2% to 69.52.Shares of Cisco Systems (CSCO) slid more than 2%, while Symantec (SYMC) fell 0.2%, CyberArk Software (CYBR) 3.1% and FireEye (FEYE) 2.3%. and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) rebounded to trade fractionally higherIBD'S TAKE: Security stocks will be pressured throughout the Q3 earnings period, analysts say, with management commentary on the outlook for 2017 IT spending key. Learn more about other industries where spending is projected to grow, such as fiber-optical network gear, at IBD Sector Leaders.Late Tuesday, Fortinet management said Q3 results were negatively impacted by sales execution issues in North America, macroeconomic pressure in the U.K. and Latin America, and longer sales cycles in the enterprise and service provider markets.But security vendor Barracuda Networks (CUDA) late Tuesday reported better-than-expected results. And tech research firm IDC on Wednesday said  worldwide revenue for security-related hardware, software, and services would grow from $73.7 billion in 2016 to $101.6 billion in 2020, a compound annual growth rate of 8.3% that it said is more than twice the expected rate of overall IT spending growth in that span.Barracuda Networks stock was up 8.4% in afternoon trading Wednesday, touching a one-year high intraday.Proofpoint reports its Q3 earnings on Oct. 20., which might be the next indicator of trends in the security market.Some analysts speculate that Cisco and Palo Alto Networks have gained share vs. Fortinet. Privately-held security software firms also have been gaining share, analysts say.Fortinet late Tuesday said it expects Q3 earnings per share minus items of 15 cents to 16 cents a share, compared with its prior guidance of 17 cents to 18 cents. It lowered revenue guidance to $311 million-$316 million from $319 million-$324 million. Fortinet lowered Q3 billings guidance by 8%.Morgan Stanley downgraded Fortinet to equal weight, while at least six other Wall Street firms lowered their price targets.Fortinet competes in the data center and government markets. Telecom companies are also big customers.After a slew of high-profile data breaches in 2013-14, many companies rushed to upgrade firewalls that sit between private networks and the internet and invested in threat detection technologies. Firewalls block unauthorized traffic from entering a private network.Corporate spending on security appears to have slowed as more companies outsource business workloads to cloud computing service providers such as Amazon Web Services, part of Amazon.com (AMZN)."Given the Fortinet results, we are incrementally more cautious on the firewall market but not the overall security market," said Matthew Hedberg, an RBC Capital analyst, in a research report. "Ultimately, we are more concerned that share gains for firewall vendors could be harder to come by these days, as many vendors in the space end up competing on price."To us, Cisco has cleaned up its execution and Palo Alto has the opportunity to consolidate spending in the firewall space."Gabriela Borges, a Goldman Sachs analyst, maintained a buy rating on Fortinet. "We continue to believe Fortinet is well positioned to gain share and outgrow peers, and we see the potential for a capital allocation, restructuring, or M&A event (given 20% of its market cap is in cash)," she wrote in a report.Citigroup analyst Walter Pritchard said in a report that price cutting among security software firms has intensified, with relatively new entrant Cisco being aggressive.But Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski, in his research note, said some security vendors are doing well."Based on a recent round of channel checks, we believe the issues Fortinet experienced are company-specific," he wrote. "We noted strong demand for Palo Alto and modestly improved results for Check Point."William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho, however, said corporate America is rethinking security priorities amid the shift to cloud computing."Fortinet's commentary around a slowing spending environment undergoing more digestion and more strategic spending are consistent with other vendors comments regarding the market environment," Ho said in a report. "We continue to see robust growth from private companies that may be capturing more mind share, as well as planning pauses tied to a structural shift from on-premise infrastructure to the cloud."RELATED:Cisco, Palo Alto, Symantec Gear Up For Cloud Cybersecurity ShiftPalo Alto Networks 'Deceleration' Worries Investors; Stock Down

Barracuda Networks (CUDA) late Tuesday reported fiscal Q2 profit and revenue that topped views, but Fortinet (FTNT) preannounced a Q3 miss, sending shares of the security software vendors in opposite directions in after-hours trading.Barracuda said fiscal Q2 non-GAAP EPS, minus items, jumped 110% to 21 cents from the year earlier period. Revenue rose 12% to $87.9 million in the three months ended Aug. 30, the company said. Analysts had projected 13 cents per share profit and revenue of $85 million.Shares of Campbell, Calif.-based Barracuda was up 7% in after-hours trading Tuesday. During the regular session, the stock fell 3% in the stock market today.Barracuda did not provide guidance in its earnings release. For the current fiscal Q3, analysts estimate 7% revenue year-over-year growth to $85 million, and EPS growth of 68% to 12 cents.Barracuda focuses and small and medium-sized businesses. It has been transitioning to cloud-based security from network appliances."We continue to innovate and bring new solutions to market that fortify the security fabric across public, private and hybrid cloud deployments and can be centrally managed from a single pane of glass," Barracuda CEO BJ Jenkins said in the company's earnings statement. "We believe Barracuda is well positioned to build on our momentum and be a market leader in our targeted focus areas as customers look to adopt new application and network deployment models and move workloads to the cloud."IBD'S TAKE: Corporate spending on security has been growing at about a 6% annual rate while IT budgets have been flattish. Some companies are reassessing security spending amid a shift to cloud computing. Cisco Systems is likely to continue buying security firms and M&A has been a driver of security stocks over the years.  Barracuda has ramped up email protection and next-generation firewalls that support Amazon Web Services, part of Amazon.com (AMZN), and Microsoft (MSFT) Azure, the leading cloud computing services. Barracuda also provides support for Microsoft's Office 365 cloud products.Rival Fortinet has shifted its focus to the SMB market, where Symantec (SYMC) and U.K.-based Sophos Group also compete.Fortinet late Tuesday said it expects EPS ex items of 15-16 cents for Q3, where it had guided to 17-18 cents, and it sees revenue of $311 million to $316 million where it had guided to $319-$324 million. It is slated to release full Q3 earnings after the close Oct. 27."Our third-quarter results were primarily impacted by the lengthening of deal cycles as enterprises are becoming more strategic with their purchasing decisions and buying with less urgency than last year," Fortinet CEO said in a statement. "We remain confident in the underlying strength of our business and long-term growth opportunity, and committed to delivering returns to our shareholders."The company also said directors had authorized a $100 million increase to its existing share repurchase program, bringing the amount authorized under the current program to $300 million. During Q3, the company said it repurchased $25 million of common stock.Fortinet stock was down 13% in after-hours trading, after the announcement.RELATED:Cisco, Palo Alto, Symantec Gear Up For Cloud Cybersecurity ShiftFortinet Upgraded On Profitability; Imperva Tanks On Lacking Suitors

[New York Times]Meanwhile, spending on cloud cybersecurity is expected to grow as businesses are shifting more of their workloads to cloud computing. That means a lot of M&A among Cisco Systems, (CSCO), Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Symantec (SYMC) and the like. [Investor's Business Daily]"Facebook at Work"? Isn't that just known as "Facebook"? The social networking titan's business-communication tool makes its debut Monday. [Wall Street Journal]Digital butlers are all the rage. Devices like Amazon (AMZN) Echo and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google Assistant can be handy around the home as a helper -- or as a buddy. [Wall Street Journal, Investor's Business Daily]Are we all doomed? Part 1: The International Monetary Fund trimmed its growth outlook amid a "renaissance of populist authoritarianism", and many worry about the world economy stepping into "unexplored and dangerous territory," says Harvard University President Emeritus Lawrence Summers, who opines that central banks don't have the wiggle room for recession-squashing rate cuts. [Washington Post]Are we all doomed? Part 2: Goldman Sachs (GS) says there's "more potential for shocks" and is "a bit more bearish" on European and U.S. stocks. High valuations on U.S. stocks are a concern. [Bloomberg]In case you missed it on Sunday, Tesla Motors (TSLA) head Elon Musk's tweets make news again, even Samsung's replacement phones are too hot to handle, and Alibaba's (BABA) studio arm is teaming up with Steven Spielberg's Amblin Partners to make movies. [Investor's Business Daily]Now that you've done your homework, get caught up on the stock market today.

Cloud computing is reshaping the market for network security technologies. While corporate America fretted over moving data to public cloud computing infrastructure a few years ago, many companies are now fine with it. In fact, in most high-profile cyberattacks, cloud platforms were not part of the IT infrastructure breached. As more business workloads shift to Amazon Web Services, part of Amazon.com[ticker…

Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski was bullish Tuesday on No. 1 cybersecurity firm Symantec (SYMC), which he says could grow earnings by 12%-14% beyond fiscal 2018 even without new acquisition Blue Coat Systems.With Blue Coat, though, Symantec could hurdle its $1.70-$1.80 view for fiscal 2018 earnings per share ex items. That forecast doesn't account for Symantec's $4.7 billion Blue Coat buy, Nowinski wrote in a research report.The consensus of 27 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters sees Symantec hitting $1.73 EPS ex items in fiscal 2018, ending on or near April 1, 2018, up 54.5% from the $1.12 view for fiscal 2017. Symantec's fiscal 2017 will include three quarters of Blue Coat impact. That deal closed Aug. 1.IBD'S TAKE: Symantec is No. 1 in terms of market share among its cybersecurity rivals, but CyberArk Software has an industry-topping IBD Composite Rating of 98, meaning it performs in the top 2% of all stocks. Still, CyberArk's sales beats are getting smaller.Symantec expects to cut $150 million in operating expenses as it exits fiscal 2018. Those cuts will come from eliminating Blue Coat's administration expenses and Kaspersky Labs' threat intelligence feed, and consolidating cloud-infrastructure buildouts.But the primary synergy will be in cross-selling opportunities to Symantec's 370,000 and Blue Coat's 15,000 enterprise bases. Symantec expects to sell Blue Coat's secure web gateway into its base and its data loss prevention solution into Blue Coat's base.In the enterprise segment, Symantec added 115 customers in fiscal Q1 ended July 1 to its advanced threat protection offering, bringing the total up to 270. It also expects renewal rates to improve on an auto-renew function in the U.S. and abroad.Further stoking the enterprise segment, Symantec expects to launch enhancements to its ATP suite in October, including a machine-learning function. On the consumer side, Symantec has plans for new Wi-Fi privacy, identity protection and Internet of Things product launches.Nowinski has an overweight rating and 27 price target on Symantec stock. On the stock market today, Symantec stock rose 0.55% to 23.87. Shares are up 40% for the year even as IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security group is down 8%.RELATED:

FireEye (FEYE) is more likely to be acquired in the wake of company founder and tech visionary Ashar Aziz resigning from the company's board of directors, says Nomura Securities.FireEye stock closed 0.1% lower in the stock market today, and it's down 60% in the past year. But after hours, shares rose 1.6%.In a regulatory filing Wednesday, the computer software security firm said that Aziz had resigned from the board effective Aug. 31."With the loss of the company's founder, we believe this could position FireEye as a more willing seller," said  Nomura analyst Frederick Grieb in a research report.IBD's Computer Software-Security group ranks No. 24 out of 197 industry groups, way up from No. 164 just eight weeks ago.Companies on the prowl for security acquisitions, analysts say, might include Dell Technologies, the new name for the company created by Dell's just-completed acquisition of EMC; security vendor Symantec (SYMC); and network gear leader Cisco Systems (CSCO), which is focusing more on security.IBD's TAKE: FireEye's stock has been falling since mid-2015. Top-ranked security stocks include CyberArk Software, a member of IBD's Leaderboard and the IBD 50; Proofpoint, another takeover candidate; and Barracuda Networks.Aziz founded Milpitas, Calif.-based FireEye in 2004. FireEye in August announced a restructuring plan, including a sales shake-up. In May, the company named a new CEO, Kevin Mandia."The (security) market is becoming crowded, and given the company's operating losses and a very specialized product, we believe that FireEye may look to evaluate its strategic options more readily," added Nomura's Grieb in the report.RELATED:CyberArk Topples On $10 Million Billings Lag, Smallest Ever Beat

Proofpoint (PFPT) isn't your daddy's spam protector.The highly-rated cybersecurity firm jumped to the cloud in 2008. And within three years of its April 2012 initial public offering, Proofpoint launched social and mobile products that, today, are swiping share from rivals Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Symantec (SYMC).CEO Gary Steele credits Proofpoint's nimble nature, which he says hasn't changed since it was a venture capital-backed Silicon Valley newbie in 2002 with 10 employees. Now, Proofpoint boasts more than 1,300 staffers."In a world where you're in an ongoing war against bad actors, we have to be nimble and responsive to the changes we see in the marketplace," he told IBD. "And I think that's one of the things that has truly distinguished the company."Proofpoint on Friday cleared a 76.93 buy point from a short consolidation, climbing 0.9% to 77.20 on the stock market Friday, but in light volume. Proofpoint rose 0.4% to 77.50 in Monday trade in above-average volume.Proofpoint stock has surged 19% year to date, outplaying IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group, down nearly 8%. But the group, too, is seeing a resurgence and ranks No. 30 out of 197 industries tracked, up from No. 191 over 13 weeks.IBD'S TAKE: Proofpoint is ranked No. 4 in IBD's security software group. Go to IBD Stock Checkup to find the top three cybersecurity stocks -- and how they stack up vs. Proofpoint.That's because cybersecurity spending is taking a larger-than-expected chunk of total IT spending, Dougherty analyst Catharine Trebnick says. Panic spending forced valuations to rocket in 2015 and the first half of 2016 couldn't keep up.But the second half is turning out to be a different story, Trebnick told IBD."You're seeing in IT spending, security is still a No. 1 priority," she said. "And in this whole security area, email is the No. 1 threat vector. It's also the place where people feel they have control over their network."And that's where Proofpoint is winning, she says.Proofpoint got its start as a spam-blocker. But today's hackers are less interested in selling a "Rolex" and more interested in credential theft. Thus, social engineering is at the heart of most attacks.Such was the case in February and March when Seagate Technology (STX) and Snapchat were duped into dispensing thousands of W-2 forms. Seagate's breach came down to a phishing attack whereas Snapchat was duped by a spoofed email.Both are nascent email cons. Phishing emails contain legitimate-sounding requests for information. Spoofing changes a key figure in an email address. So in Snapchat's case, CEO Evan Spiegel's last name could have been spelled with the number 1."The email threat vector is really vulnerable," Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski told IBD. "It's easier to trick a human into clicking a link than it is to write sophisticated malware."Since January 2015, businesses lost a collective $3.1 billion in email compromise schemes across the globe, the FBI found. Last year, 30% of targeted people opened a malicious email, according to a recent Verizon study.Proofpoint's targeted attack protection (TAP) aims to solve that equation by filtering out malware-ridden emails before they arrive in the inbox. And for spear-phishing and spoofing, last Wednesday Proofpoint announced the $18 million acquisition of Return Path's email fraud protection business.Last year, industry tracker Gartner predicted TAP, data loss prevention and encryption would continue driving secure email gateway (SEG) growth. Overall, the SEG segment is expected to sustain 2%-4% growth annually over the next several years."The SEG market is mature. The penetration rate of commercial SEG solutions is close to 100% of enterprises," Gartner wrote. "Despite the market maturity, companies can't do without SEG solutions. ... Despite the low overall growth, we do see individual vendors that are taking market share."A Piper Jaffray survey of resellers found Proofpoint is most often beating out Cisco and Symantec, with FireEye's (FEYE) on-premises solution trailing, Nowinski told IBD. Mimecast (MIME), which filed its IPO last year, targets small and midsize businesses (SMBs), while Proofpoint's focus is larger companies and enterprises.Proofpoint is outgrowing Cisco and Symantec. In 2015, Proofpoint grew its sales 31%, leading 16% growth in Cisco's security segment. Symantec shrank 10%, though its Blue Coat Systems acquisition will likely help it grow this year."Cisco is really pushing their security angle," Dougherty's Trebnick said. "They're trying to establish a bundle, but I wouldn't say they have any new function or features. Only Proofpoint and Mimecast have whaling (spoofing) detection. ... Cisco is late to the game."The proof is in the pudding for Proofpoint, Rosenblatt analyst Marshall Senk said in an Aug. 1 research report. During Q2, Proofpoint hit "an inflection point," crushing Wall Street's sales, earnings, billings and free cash flow projections, and hitting profitability two quarters ahead of time.Revenue growth accelerated for a second straight quarter, to 41%, its best gain in seven quarters.Beyond that, Proofpoint expects to hit $1 billion in annual sales by 2020. To do that, the company would have to maintain a 20%-32% compound annual growth rate. Since 2013, Proofpoint has grown an average 37% annually. Sales have grown by more than a third for the past 11 quarters.It's also beaten sales expectations by an average of 4.3% for the past eight quarters. It has met or topped EPS minus items views for the last seven of eight quarters. Nowinski credits Proofpoint's keen forecasting skill to the fact 97% of its sales stem from subscriptions."The average contract length is between 15 and 22 months," he said. "They have two years of visibility already from all the contracts they've been signing."Perhaps the biggest tailwinds for Proofpoint stem from cooperation. Earlier this summer, Proofpoint announced partnerships with Palo Alto Networks (PANW), Splunk (SPLK), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Imperva (IMPV) for technical integration.The partnerships open Proofpoint up to nonoverlapping customer bases like Palo Alto Networks' 26,000 customers, Wells Fargo analyst Gary Powell wrote in a July 25 research report. Meanwhile, Intel (INTC) McAfee is obsoleting its services and recommending customers to Proofpoint.Nowinski models an $80 million to $100 million McAfee opportunity for Proofpoint. Steele wouldn't put a dollar-figure on the potential windfall. Dougherty's Trebnick expects it to be a five-year push.On top of that, the transition to Microsoft (MSFT) Office 365 adds another three- to four-year charge. Microsoft launched its cloud-based Office 365 in 2011. But only about 13% of all publicly listed firms have made the switch to cloud-based office systems, Trebnick says. It has online threat protection built in, and offers sandboxing on its enterprise model, but doesn't include spoofing protection."CIOs (chief information officers) say that there's too much latency with (Microsoft's) new products, so they'd rather choose the (enterprise) version with either the Mimecast piece of it or install the Proofpoint piece," she said. "They work in conjunction."RELATED:Palo Alto Seen Tightening 2017 Guidance On Cisco RivalryProofpoint Battens Against Spoofers, Phishers With $18 Million BuyProofpoint Hits Stratosphere On EPS Beat, First-Ever ProfitCisco Tests Palo Alto, Check Point; CyberArk, Proofpoint Niches Safe

Stocks opened higher Monday, as brisk overseas action drew a sharp contrast to the sedate U.S. premarket session.The Dow industrials, and S&P 500 were up 0.4% and the Nasdaq added 0.3% at the open of the stock market today. Markets in China also posted a quiet session, ending with narrow losses.But in Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 surged 2.3%, apparently buoyed by speculation of a possible Federal Reserve rate hike. Japan is scheduled to release monthly official household spending and unemployment data Monday evening U.S. time.In Europe, stocks moved sharply lower, with the CAC 40 down 0.7% in Paris, and Frankfurt's DAX 0.5% lower at midsession. The London Stock Exchange was closed for a one-day bank holiday.Gainers and decliners ran about even in the Dow's premarket session. Verizon Communications (VZ) and Merck (MRK) opened less than 1% higher.Most of the IBD 50 list stocks remained flat ahead of the open. Broadcom (AVGO) was up 0.3%.Drugmaker Mylan (MYL) climbed nearly 2% at the open.  The stock fell 12% last week, hurt by controversy over price increases of the company's EpiPen allergy treatments.  The Netherlands-based company said Monday it would release a lower-priced generic EpiPen alternative.Symantec (SYMC) rose 1%.  A Barron's article Saturday estimated that cost-cutting measures and the software maker's recent acquisition of Blue Coat Systems could point to a 25% upside in its share price.Fiber-optic networking gear maker Oclaro (OCLR) flashed 3% higher. The San Jose, Calif.-based company was among the networking leaders discussed in an IBD article outlining trends in the fiber-optic networking market that also included Acacia Communications (ACIA),  Inphi (IPHI) and others. Oclaro shares are priced below 10. Both Inphi and Acacia are IBD 50 stocks. Acacia shares rose 1% at the open.Personal income chugged ahead 0.4% in July, in line with consensus expectations The Commerce Department also revised its initial 0.2% increase estimate for June upwards to 0.3%. Personal spending rose 0.3%, also inline with projections. Commerce also revised its June spending estimate from a 0.5% gain downward to a 0.3% increase.The Core PCE Price Index ticked up 0.1%, in line with views and equal to its gain for June.The Dallas Federal Reserve Bank delivers its regional manufacturing survey for August at 10:30 a.m. ET.Oil futures slumped more than 1%, but West Texas Intermediate crude continued to find support at $47 per barrel. Gold dipped a fraction to near $1,323 an ounce. The dollar gained ground against the euro and the yen. The 10-year Treasury yield slipped 3 basis points to 1.60%.

The country's leading mutual funds for the past three months continued to add building stocks and fabless chip stocks to their portfolios in their latest reporting periods.Many of these stocks had strong run-ups this summer, though most got hit Friday as the stock market outlook turned to under pressure.Stock purchases made by top-performing mutual funds in the building sector include Drew Industries (DW), Trex (TREX), Universal Forest Products (UFPI), Thor Industries (THO), A.O. Smith (AOS) and Patrick Industries (PATK), in their latest reporting periods. As of Thursday, IBD's Bldg-RV subgroup was ranked No. 6 among 197 industries.Click Here To See A List Of New Buys Of Top Mutual FundsAll banged to near or below their 50-day moving averages Friday.Fabless chipmakers Nvidia (NVDA), Inphi (IPHI) and Silicon Motion Technology (SIMO) have all performed well and have notched new 52-week highs. Telecom stocks Lumentum (LITE) and Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) were also heavily bought by leading funds in their latest reporting periods.Of those, Lumentum and Ubiquiti remained the furthest above their 50-day lines.Computer software stocks NetEase (NTES), Paycom Software (PAYC), Ebix (EBIX), Veeva Systems (VEEV)and CyberArk Software (CYBR) are worth consideration for your stock watch list.All but CyberArk stayed above their 50-day lines.IBD eyed 27 best-performing funds that have latched on to Patrick Industries, investing an estimated $43.4 million. The $1.2 billion PNC Small Cap Fund (PPCIX) added shares as of its latest reporting period.The Elkhart, Ind.-based firm makes building products and materials for manufactured homes and RVs. It also supplies many of its products to the industrial market that includes customers for kitchen cabinets, office and household furniture, fixtures, and commercial furnishings.Patrick Industries was a finalist for the 2016 Indiana Public Company of the Year, along with fellow RV makers Drew Industries and Thor Industries.After clearing a long consolidation in April, the stock ran up 45% to a 52-week high of 69.53. Since then, it's pulled back and is working on the right side of a second-stage flat base.It dropped below it's 50-day line Friday, but remains in a flat base.Earnings growth has been in the double digits in the past five quarters.A handful of recent leaders among retailers also found institutional support in the past three months. Of those Burlington Stores (BURL), Jack In The Box (JACK) and Wingstop (WING) remained above their 50-day lines, while Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI), Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) fell below.Top-performing funds have been unloading medical giant Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), in their latest reporting periods. The $6.4 billion Fidelity Equity-Income Fund (FEQIX) reduced its shares of the Band-Aid maker.Leading funds also took profit from computer software firm Symantec (SYMC) and workforce-uniform provider Cintas (CTAS).Click Here To See A List Of Latest Sells Of Top Mutual FundsRELATED:Top Mutual Fund Stock Buys: Ollie's, Five Below On Shopping Lists

The median salary for a cybersecurity job is 2.7 times that of average wages in Australia, France, Germany, Israel, Japan, the U.K. and the U.S., yet 82% of organizations in those countries are experiencing a shortage in skilled cybersecurity workers, chipmaker Intel (INTC) found in a poll by its Intel Security business.More than half (53%) of respondents say the cybersecurity skills shortage is worse than talent deficits in other IT professions.Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski agrees. Cybersecurity firms "can't hire people fast enough," he told IBD.A major challenge is that cybersecurity jobs require much more than a degree and applicable coding abilities, says Candace Worley, vice president of enterprise solutions marketing for Intel Security. Some of the best cybersecurity workers, she says, have hacking backgrounds, a skill with a questionable reputation in the industry. But it's a skill she calls crucial.IBD'S TAKE: Most stocks make their biggest gains fairly early in their publicly-traded lives, so IBD's IPO Leaders list is worth tracking. Security firm CyberArk Software is on the current list, making its IPO in September 2014 at $16 a share and now trading near 55."Computer science and math degrees provide a certain intellectual skill set, but (they) don't necessarily hone the hunting and detective skills required for this industry," Worley told IBD. "Coding, incident response ... there are a lot of skills required to play in the cybersecurity space."Over the course of May, Intel Security teamed up with market research specialist Vanson Bourne to survey security staff at 775 companies and other organizations of 500-plus employees, in eight countries.Some jobs are especially hard to fill, Worley said. Jobs in intrusion detection, attack mitigation and software development -- creating software that is less susceptible to hacking -- are the ones that most often go begging, she says. Those skills are rarer than less-technical abilities like communications and management.To that point, Intel Security noted the highest technical security job last year in the U.S. paid $233,333 annually. That's $8,000 more than most chief information security officers (CISOs) make, according to job tracker Dice.Last year, the U.S. left 209,000 unfilled security jobs on the table, Intel said, citing a Peninsula Press analysis of U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics data. That's about $41.8 billion in unpaid salaries, assuming a $200,000 average wage for each position. Nearly three-quarters of respondents (71%) say the shortage in skills left their organizations vulnerable to attack.The trend is continuing this year, but perhaps at a slower pace, according to Piper Jaffray's Nowinski. In June, there were 2,843 unfilled jobs at 13 cybersecurity firms in the U.S., according to job-postings information examined by Piper Jaffray. At, say, $200,000 a head, that's roughly $570 million in unfilled salaries. Among those with the most total open positions were KEYW Corp. (KEYW) (658), Fortinet (FTNT) (459) and Symantec (SYMC) (431).Overall, however, the number of unfilled positions at those 13 firms fell 28% in June vs. June 2015, and they fell 25% in May vs. a year earlier. In April, though, the number of unfilled jobs had risen 14%.Nowinski credits the fewer unfilled posts in June and May not just to companies filling slots, but also to some layoffs. Such was likely the case for Symantec. It had 71% fewer technical job openings this June vs. June 2015, but in May it announced 1,200 layoffs."Cybersecurity firms can't hire people fast enough," he said.Networking companies such as Brocade Communications (BRCD), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Juniper Networks (JNPR) can fill technical jobs more easily because the required skills are similar, Nowinski says. "But (jobs at) Fortinet, Palo Alto Networks (PANW) (and) Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) are all vastly different," requiring multiple specialists, he said.Organizations aren't all on the same page in terms of hiring practices, says Intel's Worley. The lion's share of respondents (68%) to the survey say hands-on experience is critical to developing cybersecurity skills. And though more than half require at least a bachelor's degree, 23% say education isn't properly preparing students.There is a lack of master's programs for cybersecurity, says Tim Ashford, IT director for Ashford Capital Management, an independent research and analysis firm. Ashford is working toward his master's of science in information security engineering with the SANS Institute.The SANS Institute provides cybersecurity training for more than 165,000 security professionals worldwide, and it offers two cybersecurity master's programs. Two summers ago, Ashford, a 19-year veteran of the IT industry, began looking for cybersecurity programs."I hit up websites like MIT (Massachusetts Institute of Technology) and Stanford (University) and saw courses here and there, but as far as programs for preparing people with hacking techniques, managed qualitative skills, I saw next to none of that," he told IBD.In December 2014, the SANS Institute had just six graduates of its program, Ashford says. But breaches like those of Target (TGT), Home Depot (HD) and LinkedIn (LNKD), dating back to 2013, have spiked interest, he says. Like Worley, he says there's a need for cybersecurity professionals who can "break stuff."Also like Worley, Ashford cites a need to reach younger minds."You've got to find a way to get kids to think about cyber," Ashford said. "It's part deconstruction, breaking things down. But there's always a delicate risk with kids. Let's teach them how to break stuff, but also educate them on the heart and soul of cybersecurity."Workers at cybersecurity companies such as Palo Alto Networks, Check Point and Fortinet try to hunt down the origins of a breach, close it and then remedy the potential fallout."That takes ability to deduct, it takes problem-solving, and it takes logic," Worley said. "We're unlikely to see a decline in hacking and malware, so we're seeing the industry work with high schools and universities to build the curriculum."Government also has a role to play. But 76% of respondents say their governments aren't investing enough in cybersecurity talent, and the same percentage say the laws and regulations surrounding security infrastructure in their nations are insufficient.In the U.S., Obama has pledged $19 billion for fiscal 2017, which starts Oct. 1, to bolster the government's aging security infrastructure. That could boost spending, but Piper Jaffray's Nowinski says that won't necessarily produce more qualified folks to fill cybersecurity jobs.Yet, 9 in 10 respondents say technology can help organizations fill the hole in skilled security workers. More than half (55%) say technology like automation and managed security service offerings will advance sufficiently in five years to meet the majority of a firm's security needs.Worley isn't as bullish on the rapid advance of security automation, but she says the idea is getting greater acceptance. Automation is a relatively nascent tool, relying on supercomputers like IBM's (IBM) Watson to hunt needle-in-the-haystack security abnormalities or automate update deployments."If you go back a decade, most people were extremely uncomfortable with automation," she said. "But now, and most companies are more tolerant of automation."Still, she emphasized, "skills that require significant analysis will continue to require human intervention."RELATED:

Proofpoint (PFPT) is displacing Symantec (SYMC) and Intel (INTC) McAfee as headline-making breaches like that of the Democratic National Committee drive its $10 billion thesis, Summit Redstone analyst Srini Nandury said Tuesday.Nandury relaunched coverage of Proofpoint stock with a buy rating and a 90 price target, calling email security the "biggest threat vector" for the industry. There, Proofpoint competes with the likes of Symantec, FireEye (FEYE) and Mimecast (MIME).IBD'S TAKE: Resellers in a Piper Jaffray survey say Proofpoint is displacing Cisco Systems, Intel, Symantec, FireEye and Mimecast in the email segment.A "constant barrage" of high-profile breaches has helped Proofpoint top sales views by an average 5% for the past 18 quarters, Nandury wrote in a research report. Its email and social media security, privacy and archiving products rank high in the industry."Not surprisingly, the company has been taking share from incumbents," he wrote. Among those, he identified Symantec and Intel. Intel's security arm is phasing out its email service and recommending customers to Proofpoint.Industry tracker IDC pegs the Intel opportunity at $92 million, but Nandury sees $200 million to $300 million given the cross-selling opportunity for Proofpoint's targeted attack protection (TAP), archiving, privacy, governance and emerging products.Only 46% of Proofpoint customers use multiple products, meaning the company has a massive runway for growth, Nandury wrote. It could also expand internationally. The U.S. accounts for 82% of Proofpoint's sales today."Proofpoint is addressing and large and growing (total addressable market) of $10 billion by 2019, up from the $5 billion TAM quoted at its (initial public offering) in April 2012," Nandury wrote. "With only 4% market penetration, Proofpoint has a long runway for growth.:For 2017, Nandury models 30% growth. During its June analyst day in San Francisco, Proofpoint guided to 28%-32% growth over the next three years. Proofpoint has grown at a 35% compound annual growth rate since its IPO in 2012.Proofpoint stock closed down 0.55% at 75.68  on the stock market today. But shares are up about 17% for the year -- on Monday touching an all-time high of 77.16 -- even as IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group has fallen 10%.
