CyberArk Software (CYBR) is expected late Tuesday to report decelerating Q2 sales that, for the eighth consecutive quarter, still grow by at least a third vs. the year-earlier period as the broader industry struggles with tough 2015 comparisons.Shares of CyberArk fell 1.1% to 55.59 on the stock market today. Shares are up 23% for the year, as IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group has fallen about 10%.IBD'S TAKE: CyberArk stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 98, meaning it has performed in the top 2% of all stocks in terms of earnings power and sales growth. The company tops the Computer Software-Security industry group. Get more CyberArk data at the IBD Stock Checkup.For Q2, the consensus of 17 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expects CyberArk to report $48.3 million in sales and 20 cents earnings per share ex items, up a respective 33% and 5% vs. last year.Under the forecast, sales would decelerate from 42% year-over-year growth in the prior two quarters, and EPS is expected to slow from seven consecutive quarters of at least double-digit growth. For the September quarter, sales are seen braking again as EPS falls vs. last year.CyberArk's earnings will follow Symantec (SYMC) and Imperva (IMPV). Last week, Symantec reported fiscal Q1 sales that fell 3%, but EPS ex items that grew 12%. For Q2, Imperva's sales grew 8%, slowing to single digits for the first time, with Imperva also reporting losses.Symantec's fiscal Q1 followed three days after the company's completed its acquisition of Blue Coat Systems for $4.65 billion. Symantec stock shot up as much as 9% after its fiscal Q1 report, before settling up 4%. Shares are up 35% since January.

Palo Alto Networks (PANW) is displacing Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) to compete against Cisco Systems (CSCO), Dougherty analyst Catharine Trebnick said Tuesday ahead of Palo Alto's fiscal Q4 earnings report, due out Aug. 30.But fears of deceleration are likely to come to fruition: Palo Alto is expected to report 37% year-over-year growth to $389.9 million in sales, slowing for the fourth straight quarter. It would be the first time its quarterly sales growth dipped below 40%.For its fiscal Q4 ended in July, analysts model Palo Alto bringing in 49 cents earnings per share ex items, up 75% vs. the year-earlier period. That's big growth, but that metric would also mark a deceleration for the fourth consecutive quarter.The consensus of 41 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expects Palo Alto to wrap up fiscal 2016 with $1.37 billion in sales and $1.66 EPS ex items, up 47% and 93%, respectively. It would be Palo Alto's first year topping $1 billion in sales and $1 EPS minus items.Palo Alto Networks stock is down 5% since its May 26 fiscal Q3 earnings release sent shares falling 12% the next day. For that quarter, product sales declined 4.6% sequentially, sparking concerns of a slowdown for blowout-earner Palo Alto. Meanwhile, IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group is up 9% in that span."We believe investors will scrutinize product revenue performance on the (fiscal Q4) print, as many are looking for a rebound after (fiscal) Q3 when product revenue declined," Trebnick wrote in a research report.IBD'S TAKE: Palo Alto Networks stock is ranked eighth in its industry group. CyberArk Software stock tops its rivals, with an IBD Composite Rating of 98, meaning it performs in the top 2% of all stocks. The industry group is in an uptrend, ranked No. 41 out of 197 groups tracked, up from No. 191 one quarter ago. See IBD Stock Checkup to get a better handle on stocks.Palo Alto stock closed up 3.3% at 142.11 on the stock market today. Shares are down more than 20% for the year, though, underperforming Palo Alto's industry group, which is down 8%. Still, Trebnick is bullish on the company's upcoming fiscal Q4."Our checks from industry professionals and resellers indicated that they experienced a robust performance domestically, offsetting bits of continued disruption abroad," she wrote. Namely, Palo Alto's fiscal Q4 will have a full month of Brexit impact, unlike the case for Check Point and Fortinet (FTNT).Competitively, Palo Alto is persisting against Check Point, Trebnick wrote. In a number of RFPs (requests for proposals), Palo Alto is edging out Check Point to become a finalist against Cisco and the incumbent, she said. And Palo Alto is withstanding Cisco's renewed firewall focus, she added.Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski saw similar demand in a round of checks with resellers and distributors, who noted demand is up. Customers are working through end-of-2015 purchase digestion, Palo Alto still has a runway in Europe, and virtual firewall sales are increasing, he said.On the subscription side, Nowinski and Trebnick both expect keen demand for Palo Alto's Traps product, for endpoint security, and Aperture, its cloud access security broker (CASB). The latter competes with Symantec (SYMC) following the No. 1 cybersecurity firm's recent acquisition of Blue Coat Systems.Still, Traps and Aperture are seeing some challenges from privately held rivals, Dougherty's Trebnick wrote. Traps remains "dwarfed" in competitive deployments vs. Cylance and Crowdstrike, and Aperture isn't yet a challenge for CASB leaders Netskope and Skyhigh Networks.RELATED:Symantec Tops Views; FireEye Dives Late On Layoffs, OutlookHackers Playground: Security Lapse Cited By 82% Of Firms, Says Intel.

Cybersecurity companies Symantec (SYMC) and FireEye (FEYE) both reported earnings late Thursday, but one set of results was much more well-received by investors than the other.CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) also moved in late trade.Symantec, which has now completed the acquisition of Blue Coat, said revenue declined 3% to $884 million in Q1 2017, topping estimates for $877 million. Adjusted profit of 29 cents a share pulled ahead of views by 4 cents.And the company projected full-year 2017 guidance well above estimates. It sees $1.08-$1.14 in diluted EPS on $4.04 billion to $4.12 billion in revenue for the year vs. current consensus for $1.08 a share on $3.53 billion.For Q2, Symantec is guiding for 18 to 21 cents a share on $960 million to $990 million in sales vs. views for 26 cents EPS on $878.2 million.Shares perked up nearly 5% after hours after closing the day up 0.6% at 21.03 on the stock market today. Symantec likely will clear recent resistance Friday morning, possibly rising to its best levels since the end of 2004.Meanwhile, FireEye shares sank 16% in extended trade after news emerged that the company would cut 300 to 400 positions."We'll do our best to go after infrastructure costs, discretionary spending and things like that, but unfortunately we will have to reduce employees as well," CFO Michael Berry told MarketWatch, which first reported the layoffs.The company reported a narrower-than-expected 33-cent-per-share loss but revenue growth that fell short of estimates for $181.7 million, up 19% to $175 million. That's by far the smallest revenue gain in at least the last four years.For 2016, FireEye said it now sees a per-share loss of $1.28 to $1.32 on revenue of $716 million to $728 million, down from prior guidance for a loss of $1.20 to $1.27 per share and revenue of $780 million to $810 million.That compares with analyst expectations for a $1.24 per-share loss and $793.7 million in revenue for the year.FireEye's Q3 guidance also fell short.CyberArk fell 3% in late trading after closing up 0.4% to 56.38. Palo Alto Networks dipped 1% after rising 1.4% to 131.44.

Social media leader Facebook (FB), electric car maker Tesla Motors (TSLA), 3D printer maker 3D Systems (DDD) and membership retailer Costco (COST) all had their price targets raised while coverage was initiated on Symantec (SYMC).Facebook had its price target raised to 170 by Jefferies, which maintained a buy rating. Last week, Facebook reported Q2 revenue of $6.43 billion, up 59%, and EPS of 97 cents, up 94%, shattering consensus for 82 cents. It was the fourth straight quarter of accelerating earnings growth.Facebook shares finished trading up 0.6% to 125.15.Tesla had its price target raised to 275 from 260 by FBN Securities. Tesla reported Q2 earnings on Wednesday that missed estimates but showed improvements in electric-car production. Tesla delivered fewer cars in Q2 than originally planned. Its production is on track to support about 50,000 deliveries in the second half of 2016, which reaffirmed previous guidance.Shares dipped 0.3% to 230.03.3D Systems had its price target raised to 15 from 13 by Jefferies, which maintained a hold rating. The 3D printer maker on Wednesday posted adjusted EPS that doubled Wall Street expectations, sending its shares soaring 18% at the close. But illustrating the ongoing struggles in the 3D printer market, the company also reported its fourth consecutive quarter of year-over-year revenue declines. Q2 revenue fell 7% to $158 million, missing estimates.Shares jumped 3.6% to 14.77.Costco had its price target raised to 170 from 160 at Cowen, which reaffirmed an outperform rating on the membership warehouse operator. The consensus price target on Costco is 172.Shares edged up 0.7% to 167.70.Coverage was initiated on Symantec by Barclays with an equal weight rating and price target of 24. Symantec reported Q2 earnings Thursday that beat estimates. Revenue fell 3% to $884 million, as adjusted EPS rose 12% to 29 cents.Shares jumped 4.1% Friday to 21.89.

Simone Biles, Katie Ledecky and Michael Phelps are on the road to Rio, but so are cybercrooks looking to bilk some of the bucks entering Brazil and hacktivists with an ax to grind.During the 2012 Olympics, the London Organizing Committee reported 166 million security-related "events," including a half-dozen "major" attacks. And Japan is already prepping to spend $190 million to hire cybersecurity professionals ahead of the 2020 Games.So for the 2016 Games host Brazil, which Symantec (SYMC) cites as the source of 2% of all internet crime in 2015, cybersecurity is at the forefront, says Samir Kapuria, Symantec senior vice president of cybersecurity. Symantec says cybercrooks pull in $8 billion a year in Brazil. And the country is languishing in a deepening recession, already its worst in 25 years.Symantec, the No. 2 cybersecurity firm by market cap behind Check Point Software (CHKP), is among the companies tapped to help digitally secure the Rio Games. Planning started practically the day after the London Olympics ended, Kapuria told IBD."We're thinking about all the vectors, what we learned from the (previous) event, what are the emerging threats," he said, looking "to recognize the velocity in which the threat landscape is evolving."Kapuria and Symantec have their work cut out for them. In 2012, London brought in about $988 million from tourists in town for the Games. That's an attractive target for organized crime, which accounts for 80% of digital thievery, says IBM's (IBM) vice president for security, Caleb Barlow.Hacktivists, too, could be looking for their 15 minutes of fame, Kapuria said. After all, Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff is at the center of a political scandal, Rio's crime rate is notoriously high, and the Zika virus had infected more than 1 million people.Says Stephen Boyer, chief technology officer of security vendor BitSight: "You hear a lot about China being the Wild West of cybersecurity. You just don't hear as much about Brazil." The Games could change that.If you think swimming star Michael Phelps' world-record butterfly is impressive, you ought to see the plethora of consumer- and fan-oriented scams circling the Olympics, experts say. Privately-held Kaspersky Lab found the first spam emails mentioning the 2016 Games early last year."Major events attract spammer attention because they are a good opportunity to earn money from credulous people," Kaspersky researchers wrote in a May blog post. "Spammers are attempting to convince victims that their email address has been chosen randomly from a large list."To receive a prize -- often purported to be a free Olympic ticket -- users are prompted to send their personal information. Malicious websites backed by cheap SSL (secure sockets layer) certification attempt to do the same. SSL certification shows up as "https" in the address bar and so adds to the supposed legitimacy of the site.So, even before you've hit "buy" on your Rio de Janeiro airfare, you're being targeted by fraudsters.IBM's Barlow says events like the Olympics, World Cup, Super Bowl and World Series draw a lot of cash. With a few search engine optimization tricks, cyber gangs can attract victims to malicious fake-ticketing sites, he says."Bad guys are opportunistic," he told IBD. "They're trying to fish you in. And they're always looking for that opportunity when someone's security guard is going to be down and be willing to click on something they might normally ask some questions about."To that end, digital hucksters will send phishing emails containing malicious links, hijack media including photos and videos of Olympians and embed malware in phony apps to worm their way into your devices, Barlow says. And it's easy, he says."Five to 10 years ago, you had to be a cyber-sleuth to figure out how to make an attack work," he said. "Nowadays, you don't need any of that. You can rent these attacks. It's not difficult, and it doesn't take a lot of time to put an attack together. ... Cybercrime is being outsourced."Brazilian thieves aren't the only ones stepping up their games for the 2016 Olympics. The globe's hackers will be armed to the teeth with digital weapons in preparation for the Olympics, says Symantec's Kapuria. Likewise, the white coats plan to bring their own A game."Attackers don't wear a flag on their shirts," he said. "The infrastructure is global. It might be applied locally, but it's really global capabilities that are being used. All the security and maturity that are established will be applied (in Brazil)."Kapuria, Symantec and Olympic officials have had years to plan for the 2016 Games. Scams, fake tickets, credit card theft and hacktivism are givens. But the biggest threats may be unseen, says RiskIQ lead developer Brandon Dixon. The Olympic Committee might make public Wi-Fi available, but that means some extra work will be needed to make it invulnerable to digital eavesdropping."When you go into another country, you're looking to get connectivity, and one of the first things people do is try to find the internet," he told IBD. "Having that public Wi-Fi available is something the Olympics will likely put an investment into."Noted Barlow: "You never know if someone is listening in on Wi-Fi." And that's particularly true of public access points, says Private Giant CEO Shaun Murphy. It takes minimal skill to set up a Wi-Fi network and only a $50 device available on Amazon (AMZN) to listen in.EMV-backed credit cards -- also known as chip-and-pin cards -- are more secure. But the U.S. lags in adoption, which could hurt U.S. tourists looking to cheer on 16-year-old New Jersey high school track star Sydney McLaughlin in the 400-meter hurdles next month."These are the same threats you have all the time, but it's more amplified and over a shorter period of time," Murphy told IBD. If a hacker's effort only pays off once, it was worth it, he says.To combat against the array of unknowns, Symantec has a three-prong strategy that includes information and threat protection from a variety of collaborators, woven into a broad security platform called the IQ layer. Kapuria likens the planning process to standing up a startup ... in a much smaller time frame."How do you keep the good stuff in and protect it with encryption or data-loss prevention?" he asked. "How do you keep the bad guys out, how do you stop malware, how do you protect the endpoints involved, how do you protect the web interfaces, how do you protect the email?"And then there's the IQ layer -- weaving various entities' expertise to forge that protection. Symantec's piece of the puzzle lies in its global security operation centers (SOCs), which monitor emerging threats daily. So although planning began years ago, the threat information backing it is dynamic.Says Kapuria, "Your plans start the day after, but your execution and implementation is done daily."

Symantec (SYMC) completed its $4.65 billion acquisition of Blue Coat Systems on Monday, three days ahead of new CEO Greg Clark's first quarterly earnings report with the No. 2 cybersecurity firm. Symantec is slated to post its fiscal Q1 earnings after the close Thursday.On the stock market today, Symantec rose 0.6% to 20.55. Shares are up 20% this year following a $400 million cost-cutting plan announced in May that included 1,200 layoffs and closing a quarter of the company's offices.The Blue Coat acquisition sent Symantec shares rocketing. In the nine days following that June 12 announcement, Symantec stock rose 23% and hit a year high at 21.28. Since then shares have been consolidating.IBD'S TAKE: Symantec has a middling Composite Rating of 61, meaning it outperforms nearly two-thirds of all stocks in terms of key metrics. CyberArk Software leads the industry group with a CR of 97.Clark headed up Blue Coat, a cloud security firm, until its acquisition by Symantec. Then he stepped in to replace Michael Brown, the former Symantec CEO."At a time when the world faces more threats than it's ever encountered before, I couldn't be more confident in our ability to deliver what our customers need," Clark said in a statement Monday announcing the closing of the Blue Coat acquisition.Symantec Chairman Dan Schulman says Blue Coat dovetails with Symantec's two-year-old goal of becoming the leading pure player in the cybersecurity space. Symantec is No. 2 to Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) in terms of market cap among cybersecurity firms.Check Point's $13.1 billion market capitalization leads Symantec and Palo Alto Networks (PANW), which carry $12.6 billion and $11.5 billion values, respectively. IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group ranks No. 66 out of 197 groups tracked.For its fiscal Q1 ended on or near June 30, Symantec is expected to report $877 million in sales and 22 cents earnings per share ex items, according to the consensus of 23 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Both metrics would be flat sequentially.Symantec spun off its data storage unit Veritas in January for $7.4 billion.

Symantec (SYMC) stock is leveling off after rocketing 23% in nine days last month on its $4.65 billion plan to acquire cloud security firm Blue Coat Systems. Still, Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski has reiterated an overweight rating on shares.Nowinski also kept his 24 price target on Symantec stock, in a research note Tuesday. Shares have fallen 4% since hitting a 17-month high at 21.24 on June 23, but still are up 20% for the year, where IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group is down 17% and ranks just No. 163 out of 197 groups tracked by IBD.On Wednesday, Symantec ended trading up a fraction, to 20.38, on the stock market today.Symantec expects its Blue Coat acquisition to add $1.70 to $1.80 earnings per share in fiscal 2018, Nowinski wrote. The Wall Street consensus view is $1.39. Blue Coat will add a secure web gateway (SWG) and cloud access security broker (CASB) tools to Symantec's product portfolio.SWGs function like next-generation firewalls in that they provide URL/web traffic filtering, threat prevention and SSL encryption. SWGs also go deeper into app security/control, policy compliance, certificate verification and data loss prevention.Blue Coat's SWG, called ProxySG, accounts for more than half of its total sales and will likely replace Symantec's small SWG product, which has generated less than $5 million in annual sales, Nowinski wrote. He says CASB will be a big market in 2020."Gartner has forecasted that 85% of large enterprises will use a CASB by 2020, up from just 5% today," Nowinski wrote. Symantec will likely integrate Blue Coat's CASB into its data loss prevention product, he says.Symantec will also use Blue Coat to create a threat intelligence "data lake" by gathering information via ProxySG and the duo's CASB products. As is, Symantec tracks 175 million endpoints and 2 billion emails daily.

Proofpoint (PFPT) late Thursday reported a 13-cent earnings beat and its first-ever quarter in the black, on double-digit Q2 sales growth, launching shares into the stratosphere Friday though analysts were somewhat mixed on the firm's future.Proofpoint stock jumped 10.5%, closing at 72.15 on the stock market today and hitting an eight-month high as it approached an all-time high of 75.46 touched last November.But shares are flat since December, and Proofpoint stock has a weak IBD Composite Rating of 41, meaning it underperforms nearly 60% of all stocks in terms of key metrics such as earnings power.IBD'S TAKE: Proofpoint is in IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group, which is led by CyberArk Software. CyberArk has a CR of 90, but it has slipped from 94 over the last week. The industry group ranks a low No. 160 out of 197 groups tracked. Check out Proofpoint's Stock Checkup here.For Q2, Proofpoint reported $89.9 million in sales, up 41% year over year, and 6 cents earnings per share ex items, swinging from a 9 cent per-share loss. Billings came in at $101.2 million, up 34%.Sales and EPS crushed the consensus model of 24 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $84.2 million and a 7 cent per-share loss ex items.Q3 guidance for $93.5 million to $94.5 million in sales would be up 36% at the midpoint, topping analysts' estimate of $90.7 million. Proofpoint also guided to 4-6 cents EPS ex items, which would swing from a 6 cent loss. Billings of $114 million to $116 million would be up 35%.For 2017, Proofpoint guided to 28% sales growth and 31% billings growth.Emerging products (social, mobile and threat response/intelligence) grew by half in Q2 vs. last year, William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho said in a research note. Its Targeted Attack Protection accounted for half of all new and add-on business in Q2, Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski said.Proofpoint also saw higher win rates in Q2, Ho wrote. That jives with a recent Piper Jaffray survey of resellers that showed the company is frequently displacing Cisco Systems (CSCO), Intel (INTC), Symantec (SYMC), Mimecast (MIME) and FireEye (FEYE)."Disruptive threats from business email compromise, malware, APTs and ransomware are likely to accelerate transition away from legacy solutions," Ho wrote. "The migration of email infrastructures to (Microsoft (MSFT)) Office 365 will likely drive even further market share gains."To that point, Proofpoint's imposter email security product is rivaled only by Mimecast, and a partnership with Intel's McAfee unit is starting to contribute to the pipeline, Ho says. Intel is ending its McAfee email security and transitioning clients to Proofpoint.Ho reiterated his outperform rating on Proofpoint stock. But Pacific Crest analyst Rob Owens downgraded shares to sector weight, even while acknowledging Proofpoint's strong Q2 on market demand, weak competition and cloud adoption.Owens wrote, however, that Proofpoint stock is now too expensive. Owens has an 85 bull price target and a 39 bear price target on Proofpoint stock."Should Proofpoint reset on a market pullback or worsening security sentiment, we would become more proactive on the name as we are still believers in the story/opportunity," he wrote.

Here's your Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the coming week. Alibaba (BABA), Walt Disney (DIS) and Nvidia (NVDA) headline quarterly earnings reports, while tech leaders Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOGL) and Microsoft (MSFT) will start the week in buy range. More drugmakers will report, and top department store chains could signal more trouble in…

The country's best-performing funds for the past three months have been building their portfolios with market-leading stocks in a variety of sectors, including building, metals, medical and retail.Building stocks include A.O. Smith  (AOS), Fortune Brands Home & Security (FBHS), Lennox International (LII), Drew Industries (DW), Martin Marietta Materials (MLM) and Masco (MAS) in their latest reporting periods.Other industrial stocks performing well include metal fabricators Insteel Industries (IIIN) and Gibraltar Industries (ROCK).A handful of medical issues also saw heavy buying by the best-performing funds, including Vascular Solutions (VASC), Edward Lifesciences (EW), Align Technology (ALGN) and Ligand Pharmaceuticals (LGND).The market outlook has been in a confirmed uptrend since June 30.Click Here To See A List Of New Buys Of Top Mutual FundsRetailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA) contoured its way into top funds' portfolios. Fifty-five top funds have added the cosmetic and fragrances store, investing an estimated $1.38 billion. The $114.7 billion American Funds Growth Fund of America recently added shares in its latest reporting period. Managers of leading funds also shopped for shares at discount retailers Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI) and Five Below (FIVE). Other retailers worth shopping for include Burlington Stores (BURL) and Pool (POOL).IBD found 17 top-performing funds adding Ollie's Bargain Outlet, investing an estimated $77.7 million. The $1.3 billion Pioneer Select Midcap Growth added shares.The newly issued company runs a chain of bargain warehouse-style stores, where you buy "good stuff cheap." The Harrisburg, P.A.-based firm has 216 stores selling closeouts, excess inventory and salvage merchandise. Everything you buy at Ollie's has a 30-day "No Hard Time" guarantee. If customers aren't happy with their purchase, they can return it within 30-days of purchase for a full refund with sales receipt.Ollie's stock cleared the 26.65 buy point of a double-bottom base on Aug. 1, but has straddled that level since then. The bargain store has been growing steadily, racking up solid double-digit earnings growth over the past five quarters. For the same period, revenue growth was more subdued, slightly under the 20% range.Other notable stocks on the new buys list acting well include gun maker Smith & Wesson (SWHC), Hawaiian Holdings (HA) and Edward Lifesciences (EW). Each of these stock are currently etching the handle part of the cup-with-handle base pattern. Make sure to put these stocks on your watch list.The nation's leading funds have been taking profit from online retailer giant Amazon.com (AMZN). Computer software firms Symantec (SYMC), Electronic Arts (EA) and Aspen Technology (AZPN) were also sold by top-performing funds in their latest reporting periods.Top funds also unloading beverage companies, Monster (MNST) and Constellations Brands (STZ). Monster reported second-quarter earnings results of 0.99 cents, missing views by 4 cents, but revenue of $827.5 million beats expectations.Click Here To See A List Of Latest Sells Of Top Mutual Funds

Symantec's (SYMC) $4.65 billion acquisition of Blue Coat Systems isn't "a silver bullet," but it was enough Monday to garner Symantec stock an upgrade to a buy rating from UBS analyst Brent Thill, who sees "a new story here."Thill sees an additional 20% upside to Symantec stock after the Blue Coat deal closes in Q3. Blue Coat CEO Greg Clark will replace Mike Brown as Symantec's CEO. Shares have rocketed 15% in the five trading days since Symantec announced its agreement to buy the cloud security firm."While the deal is not a silver bullet for either party, we believe it will drive favorable near-term financial optics and that it reinvigorates Symantec's strategic relevance with enterprises, especially with a highly technical and respected CEO at the helm," Thill said in his research report.On the stock market today, Symantec stock ended the day up 2.5% to 20.47 while major indexes that lifted on a rosier outlook regarding Britain's vote Thursday on whether it will exit the European Union. IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group was up more than 0.8%.Thill previously rated Symantec stock a sell. On Monday, he also upped his price target to 24 from 16. That matched RBC analyst Matthew Hedberg, who on Monday kept an outperform rating but boosted his price target on Symantec stock to 24 from 23.Hedberg's price target boost boils down to the "engaging, confident yet realistic and most of all believable" Clark. Clark is deeply rooted in security tech, but he also knows how to scale a business on product and cost sides, Hedberg wrote in a research report.Symantec assumes $550 million in cost savings after acquiring Blue Coat, Hedberg wrote. Symantec could weave together its malware intelligence and Blue Coat's network- and cloud-security products, and integrate Blue Coat's ProxySG Web Gate information with Symantec's endpoint product.Symantec could also cross-sell Blue Coat's cloud access security broker and web-access firewall into Symantec's installed base for deeper penetration at small-business and midsize-business customers, he wrote."The biggest risk is sales integration and execution," Hedberg wrote.But "management doesn't see a problem with the current security demand environment and will likely take a deep look at the extensive product family to see where it makes sense to push growth or harvest cash flow," he said.

Cisco Systems (CSCO), IBM (IBM) or Symantec (SYMC) could make a play for database-monitoring firm Imperva (IMPV), RBC analyst Matthew Hedberg said Monday, responding to reported rumors that Imperva is under pressure from activist investor Elliott Management.Imperva shot up during the regular session, but wiped out those gains and more after releasing preliminary Q2 earnings and revenue far short of its earlier guidance and Wall Street expectations.Elliott owned 10.9% of Imperva stock as of June 27, according to the company's most recent filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Elliott is seeking to work with Imperva on "strategic and operational opportunities," it said.But Imperva could seek a financial advisor as early as this week to help it review options, including a potential sale, and to help it deal with Elliott, Reuters reported Friday, citing anonymous sources.After the close, Imperva said it now expects to post a Q2 per-share loss minus items of 20 cents to 22 cents, on sales of $57.5 million to $58 million. It earlier had guided to a per-share loss ex items of 2 cents to 4 cents on sales of $65.5 million to $66.5 million.Imperva clsoed up 7.6% to 48.41 Monday after spiking as high as 51.70, a 5-month best. But shares tumbled nearly 12% in after-hours trading."We are disappointed with our second-quarter financial results, which were primarily impacted by extended sales cycles across most geographies and verticals predominantly relating to larger deals," Imperva CEO Anthony Bettencourt said in the company's press release. "During the quarter, we also experienced a reduction in size of several large purchases."Hedberg, in his note released early Monday well before Imperva's release, kept his 55 price target and outperform rating on Imperva stock. He sees a bid of $55 to $78 per share, about $1.76 billion to $2.5 billion, as a fair bid on Imperva. That would be a 23%-75% premium to Friday's closing price at 44.76."Overall this shouldn't come as a surprise to investors given activist pressure and uneven results in Q1," Hedberg wrote in a research report. During Q1, Imperva's Europe/Middle East/Africa sales stalled, prompting the firm to remove its EMEA head of sales.Imperva's bread-and-butter database activity monitoring offers opportunities and the potential for replacing IBM. That piece could be strategic for Cisco, IBM, Oracle (ORCL) or Symantec, Hedberg says. Symantec is planning to acquire Blue Coat Systems and reportedly tried to buy FireEye.Imperva's cloud assets might interest Microsoft (MSFT) Azure or Amazon.com's (AMZN) Amazon Web Services, Hedberg wrote.

Everything is for sale in tech markets -- with giants such as Apple (AAPL) among those actively looking -- though little is actually being sold, according to the latest report from M&A research firm Mergermarket, part of financial news and analysis provider Mergermarket Group.Mergermarket's overview of the first half of 2016 tracked the fewest number of tech, media and telecom (TMT) mergers and acquisitions, and the lowest deal value, since the first half of 2013.This is a "rebalancing" that follows a record 2015, the deal tracker said in its report, released Wednesday.China's Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) led the way in the first half of the year, with its $8.6 billion deal to acquire 84% of Finland's Supercell, the maker of such popular games as "Clash of Clans." Japan's SoftBank (SFTBY) was the seller.Symantec's (SYMC) $4.6 billion agreement to acquire privately held Blue Coat Systems from Bain Capital was also among the few big deals for the period. Blue Coat CEO Greg Clark will become Symantec's CEO.But there were no "megadeals" of $10 billion-plus in the TMT sectors in the first half, compared with a record nine such deals in the year-earlier period, Mergermarket said. The firm counted 1,363 M&As in these fields in the first half of this year, down 16% from 1,580 in the year-earlier period. And the value of the deals fell 42%, to $223.1 billion.Telecom deal value plummeted 82% to $27.1 billion, Mergermarket said, the sector's lowest six-month tally since the first half of 2009. The numbers of deals fell to 78 from 100 in the first half of 2015.The IPO market, similarly, has been in the doldrums, with activity hitting a seven-year low in Q1, though Q2 did see some pickup.One reason for the decline noted by Mergermarket is that many tech companies are "at the beginning of their innovation life cycle, and as a consequence, less mature businesses are coming to market commanding smaller price tags."Indeed, Apple's deals so far this year were all small enough as to be immaterial, so the company didn't release terms for its acquisitions of such companies as Emotient, LearnSprout, Flyby Media and LegbaCore. Apple CEO Tim Cook, however, has said the company is actively looking for M&A opportunities.Apple, with a hoard of cash and equivalents worth more than $200 billion, can at times go big on M&As, such as its $3 billion acquisition of Beats Electronics, announced in 2014.The research firm also said European activity slowed in part because of the run-up to the Brexit vote.The report quoted Jennifer Nason, global chairman of TMT banking at JPMorgan, as saying Oracle (ORCL) is among companies that might be active in M&A for cloud software companies. "A lot of tech companies are picking verticals to focus on," Nason said in the report.On Thursday, security software maker AVG Technologies (AVG) announced an agreement to be acquired by privately held Avast Software for $1.28 billion.

Microsoft (MSFT) will end support for its Windows XP operating system on April 8, which could lead to security problems for personal computers running the 12-year-old software. Despite that threat, the deadline is not expected to spark a last-minute rush of PC upgrades.
Businesses and other enterprises have been aware of the cutoff for quite some time. Still, about 30% of PCs in use run the venerable XP operating system.

Many consumers and businesses using XP simply will roll the dice and continue using those PCs until they break down, analysts say. But they might not replace them with Microsoft Windows PCs when they do, despite hopes late last year that corporate sales were stabilizing.

"I was in one warehouse location where they had fixed terminals that were on XP and they're now going to iPads," said Victor Janulaitis, CEO of tech consulting firm Janco Associates. "So they're never going to do anything with those PCs. They're just sitting there. It's like an old-time punch-card time clock in a factory."

Many Windows XP machines, especially at small and midsize businesses, are running particular legacy applications, Janulaitis said. For instance, they could be running a payroll application in accounting or an inventory application in the warehouse, he said.
No More Windows?

When those PCs break down, they'll get new machines, but they might not be Windows-based PCs, he said. In addition to Apple (AAPL) iPads and Google (GOOG) Android-based tablets, computer makers now are selling low-cost computers running Google Chrome OS and even Android.
Windows XP debuted in October 2001. And most PC users stuck with it after the release of Microsoft's problem-plagued Windows Vista in January 2007.

When Microsoft came out with its well-received Windows 7 in October 2009, businesses and consumers started to switch. But upgrades stalled when Microsoft released Windows 8 in October 2012. Customers rejected Windows 8 because of its radical redesign, which made use of touchscreens even though few PCs at the time had them.
Barely 'Move The Needle'

With the clock ticking down for Windows XP support, "a good chunk of people who haven't upgraded yet probably will over the next couple of months," said Loren Loverde, an analyst with market research firm IDC. "But that volume won't be enough to radically move the needle for the PC industry."
About 70 million to 80 million Windows XP machines will be upgraded or replaced this year, Loverde said. That would be about half of new commercial PC shipments.
The main reason for upgrading is the security risk associated with running Windows XP after Microsoft no longer issues bug fixes and security patches for the OS, he says.

"There have been major security advancements since Windows XP that make later operating systems safer," said Brian Burch, vice president of global consumer and small business segment marketing for security software firm Symantec (SYMC). "As vulnerabilities are discovered, patches can be purchased but will be very expensive."
Fortinet (FTNT) predicted an increase in malware attacks targeting Windows XP machines this year after April 8.

"We predict hackers, already in possession of zero day exploits, will wait until the 8th in order to sell them to the highest bidder," the network security firm said in its 2014 predictions. "Because of their expected high price tag, these zero days will likely be used to launch targeted attacks against high-value businesses and individuals rather than deployed by common cybercriminals in order to propagate mass infections."
Personal computer security issues could spur more businesses and individuals to consider cloud-based alternatives like Google Chrome OS machines.
Research firms Gartner and IDC reported last week that PC shipments tumbled 10% in 2013, the industry's worst annual decline ever in 2013. Both blamed the growth of tablet devices.

"Strong growth in tablets continued to negatively impact PC growth in emerging markets," Gartner analyst Mikako Kitagawa said. "In emerging markets, the first connected device for consumers is most likely a smartphone, and their first computing device is a tablet. As a result, the adoption of PCs in emerging markets will be slower as consumers skip PCs for tablets."
Global shipments of traditional PCs will decline 7% in 2014 and 3% in 2015, Gartner predicts.

Meanwhile, Microsoft is hoping its next version of Windows, code-named "Threshold" and likely to be called Windows 9, will erase the memory of Windows 8. Windows 9 is rumored to return the PC operating system to the traditional look and feel of the computer desktop, last seen in Windows 7. Microsoft is currently targeting an April 2015 release, according to media reports.
Microsoft will preview the new OS at its Build conference, which will take place in San Francisco on April 2-4, just days before it pulls the plug on XP.
The negative PC forecasts from Gartner and IDC came despite reports that some sectors of the market, especially corporate PC sales appear to be stabilizing.
In late November, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) shares gapped up on its fiscal Q4 report and guidance that beat Wall Street's views. PC sales were better-than-expected and showed signs of stabilizing.
Last month, Citi Research analyst Glen Yeung raised his rating on PC chipmaker Intel (INTC) to buy, based on research showing improved corporate PC demand.

Also in December, Richard Pzena, CEO of Pzena Investment Management, said corporate PC sales appeared to be stabilizing, boosting HP's prospects.Microsoft (MSFT) will end support for its Windows XP operating system on April 8, which could lead to security problems for personal computers running the 12-year-old software. Despite that threat, the deadline is not expected to spark a last-minute rush of PC upgrades.Businesses and other enterprises have been aware of the cutoff for quite some time. Still, about 30% of PCs in use run the venerable XP operating system.Many consumers and businesses using XP simply will roll the dice and continue using those PCs until they break down, analysts say. But they might not replace them with Microsoft Windows PCs when they do, despite hopes late last year that corporate sales were stabilizing."I was in one warehouse location where they had fixed terminals that were on XP and they're now going to iPads," said Victor Janulaitis, CEO of tech consulting firm Janco Associates. "So they're never going to do anything with those PCs. They're just sitting there. It's like an old-time punch-card time clock in a factory."Many Windows XP machines, especially at small and midsize businesses, are running particular legacy applications, Janulaitis said. For instance, they could be running a payroll application in accounting or an inventory application in the warehouse, he said.No More Windows?When those PCs break down, they'll get new machines, but they might not be Windows-based PCs, he said. In addition to Apple (AAPL) iPads and Google (GOOG) Android-based tablets, computer makers now are selling low-cost computers running Google Chrome OS and even Android.Windows XP debuted in October 2001. And most PC users stuck with it after the release of Microsoft's problem-plagued Windows Vista in January 2007.When Microsoft came out with its well-received Windows 7 in October 2009, businesses and consumers started to switch. But upgrades stalled when Microsoft released Windows 8 in October 2012. Customers rejected Windows 8 because of its radical redesign, which made use of touchscreens even though few PCs at the time had them.Barely 'Move The Needle'With the clock ticking down for Windows XP support, "a good chunk of people who haven't upgraded yet probably will over the next couple of months," said Loren Loverde, an analyst with market research firm IDC. "But that volume won't be enough to radically move the needle for the PC industry."About 70 million to 80 million Windows XP machines will be upgraded or replaced this year, Loverde said. That would be about half of new commercial PC shipments.The main reason for upgrading is the security risk associated with running Windows XP after Microsoft no longer issues bug fixes and security patches for the OS, he says."There have been major security advancements since Windows XP that make later operating systems safer," said Brian Burch, vice president of global consumer and small business segment marketing for security software firm Symantec (SYMC). "As vulnerabilities are discovered, patches can be purchased but will be very expensive."Fortinet (FTNT) predicted an increase in malware attacks targeting Windows XP machines this year after April 8."We predict hackers, already in possession of zero day exploits, will wait until the 8th in order to sell them to the highest bidder," the network security firm said in its 2014 predictions. "Because of their expected high price tag, these zero days will likely be used to launch targeted attacks against high-value businesses and individuals rather than deployed by common cybercriminals in order to propagate mass infections."Personal computer security issues could spur more businesses and individuals to consider cloud-based alternatives like Google Chrome OS machines.Research firms Gartner and IDC reported last week that PC shipments tumbled 10% in 2013, the industry's worst annual decline ever in 2013. Both blamed the growth of tablet devices."Strong growth in tablets continued to negatively impact PC growth in emerging markets," Gartner analyst Mikako Kitagawa said. "In emerging markets, the first connected device for consumers is most likely a smartphone, and their first computing device is a tablet. As a result, the adoption of PCs in emerging markets will be slower as consumers skip PCs for tablets."Global shipments of traditional PCs will decline 7% in 2014 and 3% in 2015, Gartner predicts.Meanwhile, Microsoft is hoping its next version of Windows, code-named "Threshold" and likely to be called Windows 9, will erase the memory of Windows 8. Windows 9 is rumored to return the PC operating system to the traditional look and feel of the computer desktop, last seen in Windows 7. Microsoft is currently targeting an April 2015 release, according to media reports.Microsoft will preview the new OS at its Build conference, which will take place in San Francisco on April 2-4, just days before it pulls the plug on XP.The negative PC forecasts from Gartner and IDC came despite reports that some sectors of the market, especially corporate PC sales appear to be stabilizing.In late November, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) shares gapped up on its fiscal Q4 report and guidance that beat Wall Street's views. PC sales were better-than-expected and showed signs of stabilizing.Last month, Citi Research analyst Glen Yeung raised his rating on PC chipmaker Intel (INTC) to buy, based on research showing improved corporate PC demand.Also in December, Richard Pzena, CEO of Pzena Investment Management, said corporate PC sales appeared to be stabilizing, boosting HP's prospects.

FireEye (FEYE) stock, which fell 5.7% in Thursday's regular session, was up 21.5% in after-hours trading Thursday, after the company announced a big acquisition. The company said it acquired privately held Mandiant in a deal valued at about $1 billion. Next-generation security firm FireEye aims to hone its focus on preventing and dealing with advanced kinds of cybersecurity threats. Mandiant,…

The spiraling growth of the Internet has helped companies strengthen their relations with customers and vendors. It has also provided a haven for criminal hackers seeking new ways to steal customer credit card numbers, bank account numbers and other sensitive data. Recent breaches at big-name retailers have only scratched the surface of the problem, says Frederick Ziegel, an analyst for…

2013: A Look Back And Ahead Computer attacks evolved in 2012 to target far more than Windows PCs, as risks rose from people using unmanaged mobile devices with their work networks, and as adoption of cloud computing changed cybersecurity needs. Meanwhile, organized crime networks honed their skills and automated attack tools, raising the ante. So what threats will 2013 bring?…

Security firm Symantec (SYMC) confirmed Friday that the hacker group Anonymous has just posted some of its product source code, but strongly downplays any risk, because it's old code from a 2006 version of Norton security software. "Symantec can confirm that the source code for 2006 versions of Norton Antivirus posted by Anonymous is authentic," Symantec spokesman Cris Paden said…

AVG Technologies (AVG) stock rocketed to a 10-month-high early Thursday on news that privately held antivirus-maker Avast Software plans to acquire it in a $1.28 billion, all-cash bid to tap the global cybersecurity market.AVG also announced preliminary Q2 results. It sees June-quarter sales coming in at $104 million to $106 million vs. the consensus of six analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $108.9 million. At the midpoint, revenue would be down 3% vs. the year-earlier quarter.Avast's offer comes to $25 per share, a 33% premium to AVG's Wednesday closing price of 18.79. AVG shot up 30.8% to 24.58 on the stock market today, touching an 11-month high after spending the last eight months below 22. AVG has a middling IBD Composite Rating of 46, meaning it underperforms more than half of its rivals in terms of earnings and growth.Czech Republic-based Avast aims to add AVG's mobile and PC security products to its portfolio of antivirus products."Avast is pursing this acquisition to gain scale, technological depth and geographical breadth so the new organization can be in a position to take advantage of emerging growth opportunities in internet security, as well as organizational efficiencies," the company said in a statement.Together, Avast and AVG will have a network of more than 400 million endpoints, of which 160 million are mobile, "that act as de facto sensors" to provide information about malware threats. Avast says the deal will help it take advantage of nascent Internet of Things opportunities.Cybersecurity companies have keyed in on the IoT opportunity and the idea that billions of devices could be connected to the internet -- and are therefore at risk of compromise -- within the next decade.Both boards have approved the offer, Avast said. The transaction is expected to close between Sept. 15 and Oct. 15, depending on regulatory review.M&A within the cybersecurity sector has been relatively quiet in the first half of 2016. Symantec (SYMC) plans to spend $4.65 billion to acquire Blue Coat Systems, though was earlier said to be eyeing FireEye (FEYE). Palo Alto Networks (PANW) was reportedly considering a bid on Proofpoint (PFPT) earlier this year, an analyst told IBD.

Proofpoint (PFPT) is displacing Cisco Systems (CSCO), Intel (INTC), Symantec (SYMC), FireEye (FEYE) and Mimecast (MIME), according to a Piper Jaffray survey of 28 resellers, released Tuesday ahead of the email-security firm's Q2 earnings slated for release late Thursday.The investment bank said the U.K.'s decision to exit the European Union didn't greatly impact demand in Q2, but it found that 43% of resellers cited "above average" discounting in the quarter, up from 27% in Q1.But demand for Proofpoint is increasing. Nearly a third (29%) of resellers said Proofpoint's sales were above its plan, vs. 18% in the prior quarter.For Q2, Proofpoint is expected to report $84.2 million in sales, up 32% vs. Q2 2015, and a 7 cent per-share loss ex items, improving from a 9 cent loss in the year-earlier quarter. Proofpoint models $94 million to $96 million in billings, up 26%.Proofpoint's quarterly sales have topped analysts' expectations for the past two years, and losses have either beat or met Wall Street's models for the past four quarters.IBD'S TAKE: Proofpoint has a middling IBD Composite Rating of 45, meaning it underperforms more than half of all stocks in terms of earnings power and key metrics. IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group is led by CyberArk Software, which has a CR of 94.Almost three-quarters of Palo Alto Networks (PANW) resellers surveyed (71%) said demand was in line during Q2, improving from 41% in Q1. Similarly, 33% of resellers said Fortinet (FTNT) was above its plan vs. 8% in the prior quarter.Symantec, on the other hand, was more mixed -- 17% of resellers were above plan vs. 8% in Q1, but Symantec's net results were still negative, signaling a continued decline in demand. FireEye declined markedly to 56% below plan vs. 31% in Q1.IBD's Computer Software-Security group was down a fraction at the close on the stock market today, though Palo Alto Networks stock was up more than 1.2% to 125.46. Proofpoint stock was down 1.1% to 66.27, while CyberArk Software (CYBR) lost 1.4% to 53.37 and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) dropped 1% to 81.19.

Britain's withdrawal from the European Union could slug 39% of Mimecast's (MIME) fiscal Q2 sales on the recently devalued British pound, but it might also help U.K.-bound R&D expenses, Dougherty analyst Catharine Trebnick said Wednesday.Trebnick, however, retained her buy rating and 12 price target on Mimecast stock. Nearly 40% of Mimecast's sales are tied to the U.K., but "beyond exchange-rate headwinds, management at this time does not expect any forward impact on new business generation," Trebnick said.Mimecast stock closed down 0.9% at 9.96 on the stock market today, just below its November IPO pricing. It competes in the email-security market against Proofpoint (PFPT), Symantec (SYMC), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Barracuda Networks (CUDA).Mimecast's $9,000 order-average is likely small enough to avoid delays on macro uncertainty, Trebnick wrote in a research report. And Mimecast doesn't expect a significant change in its gross profit margins, which are somewhat forex-buffered, she said.Broadly, Mimecast competes with Proofpoint in North America and in deployments with more than 1,000 seats, but it doesn't see FireEye (FEYE) as competitive. Microsoft (MSFT) Office 365 could be a major tailwind, Trebnick says.Six months since its IPO, Mimecast hinted that acquisitions might not be imminent but that deal-making is something they "wouldn't say no to," she wrote. She expects them to look at companies that provide email-specific solutions, as well as those that target malicious URLs and data leak prevention.

FireEye (FEYE) stock jumped late Wednesday on a Bloomberg report that it had snubbed a pair of lowball takeover bids, including one from Blue Coat Systems-acquirer Symantec (SYMC), according to unnamed sources.Wednesday, FireEye stock rose 4%, to 16.05, after earlier rising as much as 7.6% on the report of the two bids that FireEye reportedly rebuffed this year. Still, FireEye stock is down 21% for the year amid a CEO transition and struggling sales.Both offers were below the $30 per share that FireEye expected when it hired Morgan Stanley to seek bids, the sources said. In March, the second bidder suspended negotiations, the sources told Bloomberg.FireEye and Symantec reportedly ended their negotiations in February. This week, Symantec agreed to pay $4.65 billion to acquire cloud security firm Blue Coat.In an email, a FireEye spokesman said, "Our fiduciary responsibility is to create shareholder value. We never lose sight of that. FireEye is an exciting company and we're always in discussions evaluating opportunities vs. our organic growth strategy. We feel very confident in our strategy."Symantec, via email, said it doesn't comment on rumors or speculation.FireEye stock is 84% off its all-time high of 97.35, achieved in March 2014, and now trades much closer to its February record low of 11.35. A $30 per share bid would be an 87% premium to FireEye's closing price of 16.05 Wednesday.Last month, FireEye CEO David DeWalt announced his plan to step down and, starting Wednesday, he was replaced by Mandiant founder Kevin Mandia. FireEye acquired Mandiant in 2014.DeWalt made his announcement in conjunction with FireEye's third consecutive sales miss. FireEye reported better-than-expected Q1 losses, but the company has never been profitable.

Imperva (IMPV) stock rocketed to a seven-week high Tuesday after billionaire Paul Singer's Elliott Associates revealed a nearly 10% stake in the cloud security firm, but Needham kept a hold rating on shares, questioning how much Imperva can pick up the pace later this year.At the close on the stock market today, Imperva stock finished up 12.4% to 45.46, leading IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group, which was up 1%. CyberArk Software (CYBR) climbed 3% to 49.77 and Symantec (SYMC) lifted 2.2% to 20.92.Elliott acquired 9.8% in Imperva stock late Monday, according to a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. In the filing, Elliott argues Imperva stock is "materially undervalued."Imperva "operates in a highly strategic area of the technology industry with an attractive competitive position and a compelling product set in both the web-application firewall (WAF) and database activity monitoring markets," Elliott wrote.But Needham analyst Scott Zeller kept a hold rating Tuesday on Imperva stock. Zeller had downgraded shares in May after Imperva's June-quarter sales guidance for $65.5 million to $66.5 million missed views for $70.2 million, although sales would rise a solid 23% vs. last year at the midpoint of Imperva's forecast.For the year, Imperva guided to $304 million to $307 million in sales, up 30%. That would require a major second-half ramp. The consensus of 20 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters models 10.5%, 23% and 20% quarter-over-quarter growth for the next three periods, respectively, to edge the midpoint of Imperva's guidance."We continue to have reservations about the 'back-end loaded' year-end estimates," Zeller wrote in a research report. Europe/Middle East/Africa sales stalled in Q1, prompting Imperva to remove its EMEA head of sales, further risking Q2 and full-year sales.Elliott's guidance could be a boon, Zeller acknowledged. Elliott has been involved with Blue Coat, Riverbed, BMC Software, Qlik Technologies (QLIK), Novell and Compuware.And Imperva is in a sweet spot for cybersecurity spending, which has trudged below 2014-2015 levels."The hysterical buying patterns in security software over the 2014-2015 time frame are showing signs of cooling, and growth rates are showing signs of deceleration," Zeller wrote. But he said that "Imperva remains an attractive asset because of its scarcity value and position in security spending pockets which still get funding."WAF (web application firewall) and database sales comprise about 40% and 45%, respectively, of Imperva's total revenue, leaving a 5% chunk for fast-growing cloud security. No. 2 cybersecurity firm Symantec last week announced an agreement to acquire cloud-security player Blue Coat for $4.65 billion. That deal is expected to close in Q3.Imperva's rivals are few and far between, Zeller notes. It competes minimally with F5 Networks (FFIV) in WAF and faces off with IBM (IBM) Guardium in database security.

Symantec (SYMC) is preparing to acquire Blue Coat Systems for about $4.65 billion in cash, a deal that will add to its cyberdefense technology and fill a high-turnover chief executive officer position.Blue Coat CEO Greg Clark will take the helm of the combined corporation and join its board after the deal closes in the third quarter, both companies said in a statement. Clark will become Symantec’s fourth CEO in as many years, fulfilling its search for a leader with experience running a cybersecurity company and providing what investors hope will be much-needed stability. He replaces Michael Brown, who had overseen the January sale of Symantec’s Veritas data-storage division for $7.4 billion to the Carlyle Group (CG).The Mountain View, California-based company is in the midst of a major transition as it tries to recapture its momentum in the fast-growing cybersecurity market. The world’s largest developer of security software -- which reduced its sales and earnings forecasts in April -- is trying to re-invent itself for an industry that’s now vastly different from the antivirus software arena it helped pioneer.“With this transaction, we will have the scale, portfolio and resources necessary to usher in a new era of innovation designed to help protect large customers and individual consumers against insider threats and sophisticated cybercriminals,” Dan Schulman, chairman of Symantec, said in the statement.Clark will assume leadership of a company that’s fallen behind Palo Alto Networks (PANW), FireEye (FEYE), and other younger rivals in developing technologies to detect more advanced threats. Blue Coat brings a suite of products that can make Symantec more competitive in areas such as protecting customers’ data in the cloud, performing digital forensics in the hunt for hackers, and managing encrypted network traffic.Symantec had been in advanced talks to acquire FireEye earlier this year, according to a person familiar with the matter. But discussions broke down over Symantec’s concerns about FireEye’s future growth potential, the person said, declining to be identified because the discussions were private. Like Symantec, FireEye is struggling with competition and had also recently cut revenue forecasts.Talks with Blue Coat then accelerated, the person said. As part of the deal, Bain Capital LLC, which controls the target company, will put $750 million of its proceeds from the sale into the combined company. Private equity firm Silver Lake will double its investment to $1 billion. The Blue Coat transaction should help Symantec realize another $150 million in annual net cost savings, on top of a previously announced $400 million yearly reduction in expenses, they said.The Wall Street Journal first reported on the acquisition Sunday.

Stocks opened modestly lower Monday, but resisted the heavy overseas selling amid Brexit and central bank worries. Microsoft (MSFT) agreed to buy LinkedIn (LNKD), while  Apple (AAPL), Symantec (SYMC) and Smith & Wesson Holding (SWHC) also made headlines.The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.1%, already off session lows. The S&P 500 fell less than 0.1%, briefly turning positive.Microsoft announced it would buy LinkedIn for $26.2 billion, or $196 a share. Microsoft shares were down 3% intraday. LinkedIn, the leading professional networker, soared 47% to 193. That leaves LinkedIn shares around where they were before the Feb. 5 plunge of 44% that followed an earnings report.How healthy is Microsoft stock, and how does it compare to rivals? Find out at IBD Stock Checkup Apple shares fell 1.3%. Apple today begins its Worldwide Developers Conference, which could include new product features.Smith & Wesson jumped 6% as it climbs from support at the 200-day moving average. Sturm Ruger (RGR) was up more than 7%. Gun makers rose in the aftermath of the Orlando terrorist shooting Sunday, as gun stocks typically do following mass shootings and renewed calls for greater gun controls.Symantec shares rose nearly 5%. On Sunday, the company announced it would acquire cybersecurity rival Blue Coat for about $4.65 billion in cash. The deal was approved by both companies' boards and was expected to close in the third quarter, Symantec said in a press release. Blue Coat CEO Greg Clark will become chief executive of Symantec.The acquisition would give Symantec a cloud-based cybersecurity service that it says has the fastest growth in Web security market share. As part of the transaction, private equity group Silver Lake will invest an additional $500 million, and Bain Capital will invest $750 million more in Symantec convertible notes.Markets globally were jittery ahead of the Brexit vote and meetings of major central banks.In Europe, the FTSE 100 was down 0.7% in London, while the Paris CAC 40 was down 1.5% and the German DAX was 1.43 lower.Asian stocks sold off. The Nikkei average plunged 3.5%, the Shanghai composite lost 3.2%, and the Hang Seng index dropped 2.5%.

No. 3 cybersecurity firm Symantec (SYMC) could overtake rivals Check Point Software Technology (CHKP) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) in terms of market cap, thanks to its $4.65 billion plan to acquire privately held Blue Coat Systems, a cloud security firm.Symantec on Sunday announced its agreement to acquire Blue Coat, whose CEO, Greg Clark, will become Symantec's CEO. Last month, Symantec CEO Mike Brown announced he would step down, as the company reported fiscal Q4 sales that missed expectations and announced it would cut 1,200 jobs and close a quarter of its offices.Symantec CFO Thomas Seifert and Chairman Dan Schulman will remain in their positions. Blue Coat is owned by Bain Capital, and Bain managing director David Humphrey will join Symantec's board. Under the agreement, members of Blue Coat's management team will join Symantec and transition a portion of their cash and options into the combined entity.Symantec stock ended trading up 5.3% on the stock market today, to 18.21. Shares are up 17% over the past six months vs. a 16% decline in IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group. The group ranks just No. 183 out of 197 groups tracked.Blue Coat was previously considering an IPO, William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho wrote Monday in a research report. It's the market leader in secure web gateway products, he said, and is an emerging player in cloud access secure brokering, cloud data encryption and secure sockets layer (SSL) encryption."The combination of Symantec and Blue Coat shifts the landscape of cybersecurity, based on the consolidation of two of the largest stand-alone players in the space," Ho wrote. The acquisition gives Symantec better cross-sell and up-sell opportunities, he says.Symantec is third in market value, at $10.59 billion, behind Check Point's $14.98 billion and Palo Alto's $11.76 billion.Symantec will fund its Blue Coat bid with $2.8 billion in debt, a doubled investment by Silver Lake Partners to $1 billion, and a $750 million convertible debt investment by Bain. Thoma Bravo took Blue Coat private in 2012 for $1.3 billion before selling it to Bain in 2015 for $2.4 billion.Symantec management expects the deal to be "nicely accretive" and sees $1.70 to $1.80 earnings per share ex items for fiscal 2018 vs. expectations for $1.39. But Symantec reiterated fiscal Q1 guidance for $865 million to $895 million in sales and 24-26 cents EPS ex items, which would be down 4% at the midpoints.The acquisition is expected to drive $150 million in synergies. William Blair's Ho and Baird analyst Steven Ashley expect those synergies in general administration and sales.The deal could spur a wave of cybersecurity M&A, Ho says. He sees CyberArk Software (CYBR), Imperva (IMPV), Proofpoint (PFPT) and Rapid7 (RPD) as potential takeover targets. Legacy players like Symantec have struggled recently to launch competitive next-generation tools.Ho kept his market perform rating on Symantec stock. Ashley maintained his neutral rating.

No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) is parsing the sale of its McAfee security unit less than three months after it announced a 12,000-job cut on weakening PC sales, according to anonymous sources cited Monday by the Financial Times.Intel bought McAfee antivirus software for $7.7 billion in 2010 with the goal of interlacing the security software into its chips. That plan hasn't come to fruition. Intel is now reportedly in talks with bankers for what could be a record security deal, the FT reported.Representatives of Intel declined comment to IBD.Last year, chip sector M&A hit a fever pitch, topping $100 billion. But 2016 hasn't been huge for semiconductor or cybersecurity deals.In chips, Apple (AAPL) supplier Broadcom (AVGO) sold its Internet of Things unit to Cypress Semiconductor (CY) and its wireless infrastructure unit to MaxLinear (MXL).On the security side, Symantec (SYMC) is acquiring Blue Coat Systems, and IBM (IBM) bought incident response firm Resilient Systems. Symantec also reportedly put in a low-ball offer on FireEye (FEYE).The Blue Coat deal will help Symantec gain market cap, where it trails Check Point Software Technology (CHKP) but leads Palo Alto Networks (PANW).For Intel, the potential sale of its McAfee unit -- renamed Intel Security -- follows disappointing Q1 sales and a plan to cut 11% of its workforce globally, as the longtime No. 1 maker of computer chips redirects away from the slowing PC segment.PC sales comprised 55% of Intel's Q1 sales, but those sales have struggled in recent quarters as tablets and two-in-ones gain popularity. Now, Intel is pivoting to focus on high-growth areas like data centers, the Internet of Things and memory.Intel stock closed down 2.7% at 30.71 on the stock market today, after plunging 4.4% Friday as stocks markets worldwide reeled from the U.K.'s vote to exit the European Union. On Thursday, Intel stock topped its 32.85 buy point from a flat base, but shares are now in sell territory.

Palo Alto Networks' (PANW) low 18% exposure to Europe, Middle East and Africa earned it a top spot alongside Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) on FBN's list of tech stocks to scoop up in the wake of the U.K.'s vote to exit the European Union."Although we still like Google (GOOGL) very much, it does have a higher exposure to EMEA (30%) and the U.K. (10%)," FBN analyst Shebly Seyrafi wrote in a research report. "Amazon (AMZN) remains a top pick of ours, but its exposure to EMEA (28%) and the U.K. (8%) are not insignificant."The market toppled broadly Friday following the 52%-48% Brexit vote to leave the EU, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 3.4% and the Nasdaq composite off 4.1%. IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group was among groups hard hit, down 5.3%, despite the vote of confidence for Palo Alto.Palo Alto Networks stock, though, was down as much as some others in its group, down 3.85% on the stock market today. Rivals Symantec (SYMC) and Check Point Software Technology (CHKP) were down a respective 3.8%. Harder hit Imperva (IMPV) and Fortinet (FTNT) stocks were down 5.4% and 7%, respectively.Seyrafi suggests that investors look at stocks with higher sales growth, free-cash-flow yields and strong EMEA moats. On those factors, Seyrafi suggests that investors dig their heels in on Facebook, Salesforce.com (CRM), Palo Alto, Cisco, Apple and FitBit (FIT) stocks.In terms of sales growth, Palo Alto Networks is likely to trail Facebook. Their estimates call for 28% and 33% growth in 2017, respectively. Palo Alto's sales have slowed recently from its typical 50%-plus rate. Seyrafi expects Cisco and Apple to see the slowest growth rates, at 3% and 2%, respectively.FitBit and Salesforce have the smallest EMEA exposure at 15% and 17%, to Palo Alto's 18%, among the companies that FBN reviewed. More than 20% of Apple, Facebook, Cisco, Twitter (TWTR), Tableau Software (DATA) and Splunk (SPLK) sales are tied to EMEA. Hewlett Packard Enterprises (HPE) and Microsoft (MSFT) tip the boat with a 30%-plus exposure across the pond.However, Apple has the strongest free-cash-flow yield at 11%, leading Palo Alto at 10%, Cisco at 9.2% and FitBit at 7.6%. Salesforce and Facebook yield less than 4% apiece, says FBN.

Palo Alto Networks' (PANW) fiscal Q4 and full-year sales will decelerate again in July, William Blair analyst Jonathan Ho predicted Tuesday as he broadly cut estimates for the No. 3 cybersecurity firm.Palo Alto stock closed down 1% at 126.87 on the stock market today. Shares of top rivals Check Point Software Technology (CHKP) rose 0.3% and Symantec (SYMC) gained 2.2%.Palo Alto stock has been finding resistance at its 10-day line this month, and it's traded below its 50-day moving average every day but one over the past six weeks.For fiscal Q4 ending in July, Ho expects Palo Alto to report 37.1% year-over-year sales growth (about $389.2 million), braking from 48% growth in fiscal Q3. Last quarter was Palo Alto's first in eight that its sales had risen less than 50% year over year. For the year, Ho forecasts 34% growth, down from 55% last year and 51% the previous year.Ho's fiscal Q4 model is in line with the consensus of 42 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $389.4 million, up 37.2%, but other analysts are more bullish on Palo Alto's full-year sales. For the year, the consensus models 47.4% growth.Palo Alto's fiscal Q4 will shift toward services vs. products, Ho says. He cut his fiscal Q4 and full-year product sales growth projections to 21.5% and 20.6%, but upped his services views to 55.6% and 46.7% growth, respectively.Ho cut his fiscal Q4 billings model to $560.3 million from $581.6 million, and now sees full-year billings growth of 37.2% vs. earlier expectations for 42.7% growth.Still, he reiterated his outperform rating on Palo Alto Networks stock.

Symantec's (SYMC) enterprise unit will take the brunt of the company's $400 million cost-cutting plan, Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski said Wednesday as he reiterated an overweight rating and 24 price target on Symantec stock.The No. 3 cybersecurity firm announced the cost cuts in May after reporting fiscal Q4 sales that missed expectations. A month earlier, Symantec CEO Michael Brown said he would step down as soon as a new CEO is hired.Nowinski expects Symantec's board to fill the CEO slot over the next six months and sees a "clear roadmap" for its two-year cost-cutting strategy."We believe the company is looking for a CEO that possesses both a software and operational background, needed to drive the $400 million in operating expense cut," Nowinski wrote in a research report.Most of the cuts are expected to hit the enterprise unit, which last quarter accounted for 53% of the company's total $929 million in revenue. The company's 25% operating margin ex items, meanwhile, was largely driven by the consumer segment.The company's five-step cost-cutting plan includes 1,200 layoffs and closing a quarter of its offices.Symantec also anticipates savings through the streamlining of its enterprise portfolio and cutting of some services it shared with Veritas. Symantec completed the sale of data-storage unit Veritas in January.Nowinski says Symantec's advanced threat protection products can gain traction. In March, Symantec said it sold 1.2 million ATP endpoint subscriptions, just 1% of the 110 million total endpoints in its installed enterprise base.This suggests "the remaining market opportunity is significant," Nowinski wrote. "Management also said they have a sales pipeline for ATP products well over $100 million, which represents roughly 5.2% of the expected enterprise revenue for fiscal 2017."But sales are expected to fall this fiscal year. Symantec models a 3%-6% dip in consumer sales, and flat to a 2% decline in enterprise sales.Symantec stock ended down 0.3% on the stock market today. Shares fell 6.9% on April 28 after Brown announced his departure and the company trimmed its fiscal Q4 guidance. Since then, shares have edged up and are higher by 3% for 2016.Shares of top rivals Check Point Software Technology (CHKP) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) are up 4% and down 25%, respectively, for the year. IBD's 26-company Computer Software-Security industry group is down 16% since Dec. 31 and ranks just No. 184 out of 197 groups tracked.

The Federal Reserve signaled rate hikes are off the table, but Brexit and growth fears hit stocks. Microsoft (MSFT) is buying LinkedIn (LNKD). Net neutrality rules were upheld in a big win for the FCC, Alphabet (GOOGL) and Netflix (NFLX). American Airlines (AAL) and other carriers fell sharply. Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) unveiled software and services updates at its developers conference, while hardware dominated the E3 video game expo.For the week, the Nasdaq fell 1.9%, hurt by big techs such as Apple, Alphabet and Microsoft. The S&P 500 lost 1.2% and the Dow 1.1%. The Federal Reserve took a more dovish stance on rate hikes, but was still more hawkish than markets. Meanwhile, Brexit fears sent bond yields tumbling worldwide. The German 10-year bund went negative for the first time and the 10-year Treasury yield hit 2012 levels, though both closed well off those lows. The S&P 500 joined the Nasdaq and Dow in undercutting its 50-day line. The Nasdaq fell below its 200-day average.  Energy stocks fell with oil prices, while American Air and global peers tumbled on Brexit and terror fears.The Federal Reserve left interest rates alone, as expected, in the wake of the weak May jobs report and concerns over the looming Brexit vote. Policymakers turned more dovish. Six officials now see just one rate hike this year vs. just one official previous. Still, 11 are betting on two hikes. Yet markets, which have priced out expectations for a hike until next year, sold off following the Fed meeting. The Bank of Japan's decision to stand pat also hit markets, even though no BoJ action was expected.Meanwhile, industrial output fell 0.4% in May, but two regional manufacturing reports were positive in June. Retail sales were stronger than expected in May, while housing starts were in line. Consumer inflation remained tame.Microsoft said Monday that it will acquire LinkedIn for $26.2 billion cash, or $196-per-share, surprising many investors and analysts. The transaction is seen closing this year. The buy brings LinkedIn's user data and sales tools to the tech giant. Canaccord Genuity said the move might prompt more cloud-computing M&A. Microsoft stock fell 2.6% for the week. LinkedIn shot up 45.6% to 190.80.Net neutrality rules were upheld by the U.S. Court of Appeals, D.C. Circuit, delivering a big win to the Federal Communications Commission, as well as Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) and Netflix. AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ) and Comcast (CMCSA) had hoped the three-judge panel would at least strike down net neutrality rules applied to wireless networks. AT&T and others plan an appeal to the Supreme Court. But the one judge who dissented did agree in part that the agency had the authority to reclassify broadband internet as a telecom service under Title II of the 1934 Communications Act.Apple unveiled software improvements for the iPhone, Apple Watch, Apple TV and Mac computers during a keynote event at its Worldwide Developers Conference. The company also revamped its Apple Music service, introduced a wider range of expressions in its Messages app, and brought Siri and Apple Pay to the Mac. Apple Watch software enhancements included new health and fitness functions and an SOS feature for calling 911 by holding down a button.Some analysts cut price targets following WWDC. Meanwhile, a Beijing intellectual property rights regulator said the Apple iPhone 6 violates patents of a local rival. But Apple smartphone sales will continue pending an appeal.Apple shares fell 3.5% so far this week.Hardware news stole the show at E3, with Microsoft announcing it's launching the Xbox One S later this year and confirming it's also working on a high-end console dubbed "Scorpio" for the 2017 holiday season. Meanwhile, Sony (SNE) set an Oct. 13 release date for PlayStation VR.Analysts say Electronic Arts (EA) games "Battlefield 1" and "Titanfall 2" captured the most positive buzz, though EA was not on E3's show floor but at its own event across the street. Take-Two Interactive (TTWO) shares fell amid the absence of new game title announcements. Analysts said the lack of major game titles for new virtual-reality headsets was a letdown, but publishers don't want to devote their resources until the VR market becomes more established.Meanwhile, Chinese messaging giant Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) reportedly is close to a $9 billion takeover deal for "Clash of Clans" creator Supercell. Tencent owns Riot Games, which runs the popular "League of Legends" game.Oracle (ORCL) reported fourth-quarter earnings per share minus items of 81 cents, up 4% from a year earlier, meeting views and ending a four-quarter string of year-over-year EPS declines.Revenue fell 1% to $10.6 billion, the fifth straight quarterly decline but slightly above the consensus of $10.47 billion.  The business software powerhouse is shifting from on-premise software licensed for the long term to software-as-a-service delivered via the cloud. Oracle cloud revenue in Q4 reached $859 million, up 49%.Oracle stock rose 2.4% for the week, with all of the gains coming Friday after its late Thursday earnings report.China e-commerce giant Alibaba (BABA)  sees revenue rising 48% in the year ending in March 2017, well above the consensus estimate of 38.6%.
