There's $14 billion up for grabs in fiscal 2016 cybersecurity spending by the sector's biggest customer — the federal government — and Palo Alto Networks (PANW), FireEye (FEYE), Fortinet (FTNT) and CyberArk Software (CYBR) are vying for their respective chunks of cash.
But some are doing better than others.

FireEye stock plunged to a record low 21.75 on Nov. 5 after reporting Q3 sales that missed Wall Street views and guiding below consensus expectations. The resulting 23% sell-off drew CyberArk stock into the fray.

CyberArk, which beat-and-raised on its Q3, dropped 4% after a stellar quarterly report that included 10 new federal customers within the executive and legislative branches. Since then, both companies have suffered continued losses on Wall Street.
Despite their opposite-ends-of-the-spectrum reports, both companies acknowledge that federal spending on cybersecurity is ramping up as headline-making breaches drive awareness across all spheres.

In the latest big case, the Justice Department announced charges Nov. 10 against three men for what it termed "massive computer hacking crimes against U.S. financial institutions, brokerage firms and financial news publishers." The financial sector hacks involved stealing the personal information of over 100 million customers, and a maze of other cyberattacks are said to amount to one of the largest thefts of financial-related data in history.
Attacks Skyrocket
Between fiscal years 2006 and 2014, cyberattacks on federal agencies increased nearly 12 times over, from 5,503 to 67,168, according to a recent report by the U.S. Government Accountability Office.
Federal spending isn't keeping up.

Between 2014 and 2016, federal cybersecurity spending grew 40% — compared with the 1,100% increase in attacks over the past eight years. The GAO report didn't provide figures for attacks occurring in individual years.
Inarguably, though, the biggest attacks occurred on the back end of that eight-year period.
In May, hackers accessed about 334,000 taxpayer accounts.
A month later, an Office of Personnel Management (OPM) breach resulted in the release of 21.5 million employee records.
More recently, in October, the U.S. Postal Service was targeted. The scope of that hack is still under investigation.

In November, U.S. officials suggested that Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps was responsible for a recent surge in cyberattacks against American government employees, the Wall Street Journal reported.

The Obama Administration has been hyperfocused on cybersecurity protections, FBR analyst Daniel Ives told IBD. Earlier this fall, China and the U.S. appeared poised to sign a peace treaty centered on cybersecurity.
It's a small step, Ives said.

"But ultimately, it's still a game of high-stakes poker, and there's still a high threat level in terms of cyberespionage," he said. "I think that's why the U.S. government can't just sit there and hope it's going to go away, because these threats are as pervasive and sophisticated as we'll ever see."
'The Writing On The Wall'
So where does that leave cybersecurity companies?
Potentially with a huge sales runway, Ives says.
"There's a limited pool of companies that can handle this type of work," he said.

Ives sees FireEye, Palo Alto Networks, Imperva (IMPV), Fortinet, Symantec (SYMC) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) taking huge chunks of the federal cybersecurity spending market. Ives estimates the market opportunity at $20 billion over the next three years.
The "rip-and-replace" age of legacy cybersecurity systems is still in its infancy, Ives said, and it's going to drive deal sizes to unforeseen numbers.
Perhaps the perfect cautionary tale, however, is FireEye — which recently plunged on disappointing sales and a week Q4 outlook.

FireEye was dealing with a tough comparison quarter, CFO Michael Berry told analysts during the conference call. In Q3 2014, FireEye signed a five-year, eight-figure deal with a federal agency. No such deal emerged in Q3 2015. The company's average contract length slipped to 30 months from 34 months in the year-earlier quarter.
FireEye was specifically hurt by depressed European sales on the strengthened U.S. dollar.
On a nine-month basis, federal sales are great, CEO David DeWalt told analysts on the call.
"The federal sales model has been a shining star for the company," he said. "(But) when you look at Q3, maybe (we're) not quite where we had hoped to be."
FireEye representatives didn't return a request from IBD for comment by press time.
During Q3, Palo Alto Networks swiped FireEye's head of federal sales, Nick Urick. FireEye hired David Ramirez of L-3 National Security Solutions to take Urick's post.

"You can see the writing on the wall here, where Palo Alto Networks just hired away the head of FireEye's federal sales team," Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski told IBD. "They're building up their sales representatives, and we're starting to see a lot of security vendors trying to move into that space."
Rogue Credentials
The recent onslaught of attacks buoyed other companies.

For its Q3, Israel-based CyberArk reported sales and earnings that trounced Wall Street's expectations, assisted by 10 new contracts within the federal executive and legislative branches, CEO Udi Mokady told analysts during the conference call.
The federal government's Sept. 30 fiscal year-end typically means bolstered fall-quarter sales for companies like CyberArk.

But it was the OPM breach and the government 30-day Cybersecurity Sprint initiative that really increased awareness, Mokady said. U.S. Chief Information Officer Tony Scott launched the Sprint in June, forcing federal agencies to examine and better their cybersecurity practices.
Privileged-account policies, CyberArk's specialty, was No. 3 on the list of issues that federal agencies had to address.

A privileged account has administrative access to a computer system. On average, every organization — the federal government included — has three to four times the number of privileged accounts as employees, CyberArk Chief Marketing Officer John Worrall told IBD.
To put that number in perspective, "One bank told us they stopped counting at 1 million," he said.
The motivation to protect those accounts is clear. But attackers can be nimbler than the enterprises that they target.

"One of the biggest challenges organizations face is the attackers can often be more agile than the organizations," he said. "(CyberArk software) adds the ability to detect anomalous behavior ... that helps level the playing field."

From a federal government perspective, CyberArk must protect rogues from getting in and insiders from going rogue, Worrall said. He cited Edward Snowden's release of thousands of National Security Agency documents as an example of the latter.
To the former point, he said: "Once the outsider comes in, he's going to steal the credentials of an insider, and at that point, honestly, you won't know the difference."
Risk Aversion Runs Deep
Cybersecurity firms are hesitant to break out specific numbers.

Neither CyberArk nor Palo Alto Networks would delve deeper into the percentages of total revenue that federal sales comprise. Last month, Fortinet said that it received 12% of its Q3 sales from the government sector — but that figure includes international revenue as well.

During Symantec's Q3 earnings call this month, CEO Thomas Seifert would say only that Symantec's U.S. federal business "did very well." Last month, Qualys CEO Philippe Courtot told analysts that a tiny 1% of the company's sales in Q3 derived from federal contracts.
"So, as you can see, it's probably negligible," he said.
All taken, there's still a lot of room for growth, Palo Alto Networks' Vice President of Government Affairs and Policy Ryan Gillis told IBD.

The federal government lags the enterprise and private sectors in terms of next-generation technology adoption, he said. Procurement processes are slower, and certification processes often snag quick adoption.

Palo Alto Networks allows potential customers to trial its software, Gillis said. Between 80% and 90% of trial runners evolve into customers. But risk aversion within the government runs strong, and federal players generally spurn Palo Alto's offer.
"It's not an environment conducive to upgrading to the newest and greatest," he said. "It stems from understandable places but disadvantages the network in some cases."

That being said, the federal government realizes its precarious position as an international target, and some early adopters within the government have made mass headway into cybersecurity initiatives, Gillis said.

"The government certainly is a recipient of a range of attacks from run of the mill to very sophisticated stuff," he said. "You certainly get some demanding customers in the government that recognize the nature of the threats."

Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.There's $14 billion up for grabs in fiscal 2016 cybersecurity spending by the sector's biggest customer — the federal government — and Palo Alto Networks (PANW), FireEye (FEYE), Fortinet (FTNT) and CyberArk Software (CYBR) are vying for their respective chunks of cash.But some are doing better than others.FireEye stock plunged to a record low 21.75 on Nov. 5 after reporting Q3 sales that missed Wall Street views and guiding below consensus expectations. The resulting 23% sell-off drew CyberArk stock into the fray.CyberArk, which beat-and-raised on its Q3, dropped 4% after a stellar quarterly report that included 10 new federal customers within the executive and legislative branches. Since then, both companies have suffered continued losses on Wall Street.Despite their opposite-ends-of-the-spectrum reports, both companies acknowledge that federal spending on cybersecurity is ramping up as headline-making breaches drive awareness across all spheres.In the latest big case, the Justice Department announced charges Nov. 10 against three men for what it termed "massive computer hacking crimes against U.S. financial institutions, brokerage firms and financial news publishers." The financial sector hacks involved stealing the personal information of over 100 million customers, and a maze of other cyberattacks are said to amount to one of the largest thefts of financial-related data in history.Attacks SkyrocketBetween fiscal years 2006 and 2014, cyberattacks on federal agencies increased nearly 12 times over, from 5,503 to 67,168, according to a recent report by the U.S. Government Accountability Office.Federal spending isn't keeping up.Between 2014 and 2016, federal cybersecurity spending grew 40% — compared with the 1,100% increase in attacks over the past eight years. The GAO report didn't provide figures for attacks occurring in individual years.Inarguably, though, the biggest attacks occurred on the back end of that eight-year period.In May, hackers accessed about 334,000 taxpayer accounts.A month later, an Office of Personnel Management (OPM) breach resulted in the release of 21.5 million employee records.More recently, in October, the U.S. Postal Service was targeted. The scope of that hack is still under investigation.In November, U.S. officials suggested that Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps was responsible for a recent surge in cyberattacks against American government employees, the Wall Street Journal reported.The Obama Administration has been hyperfocused on cybersecurity protections, FBR analyst Daniel Ives told IBD. Earlier this fall, China and the U.S. appeared poised to sign a peace treaty centered on cybersecurity.It's a small step, Ives said."But ultimately, it's still a game of high-stakes poker, and there's still a high threat level in terms of cyberespionage," he said. "I think that's why the U.S. government can't just sit there and hope it's going to go away, because these threats are as pervasive and sophisticated as we'll ever see."'The Writing On The Wall'So where does that leave cybersecurity companies?Potentially with a huge sales runway, Ives says."There's a limited pool of companies that can handle this type of work," he said.Ives sees FireEye, Palo Alto Networks, Imperva (IMPV), Fortinet, Symantec (SYMC) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) taking huge chunks of the federal cybersecurity spending market. Ives estimates the market opportunity at $20 billion over the next three years.The "rip-and-replace" age of legacy cybersecurity systems is still in its infancy, Ives said, and it's going to drive deal sizes to unforeseen numbers.Perhaps the perfect cautionary tale, however, is FireEye — which recently plunged on disappointing sales and a week Q4 outlook.FireEye was dealing with a tough comparison quarter, CFO Michael Berry told analysts during the conference call. In Q3 2014, FireEye signed a five-year, eight-figure deal with a federal agency. No such deal emerged in Q3 2015. The company's average contract length slipped to 30 months from 34 months in the year-earlier quarter.FireEye was specifically hurt by depressed European sales on the strengthened U.S. dollar.On a nine-month basis, federal sales are great, CEO David DeWalt told analysts on the call."The federal sales model has been a shining star for the company," he said. "(But) when you look at Q3, maybe (we're) not quite where we had hoped to be."FireEye representatives didn't return a request from IBD for comment by press time.During Q3, Palo Alto Networks swiped FireEye's head of federal sales, Nick Urick. FireEye hired David Ramirez of L-3 National Security Solutions to take Urick's post."You can see the writing on the wall here, where Palo Alto Networks just hired away the head of FireEye's federal sales team," Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski told IBD. "They're building up their sales representatives, and we're starting to see a lot of security vendors trying to move into that space."Rogue CredentialsThe recent onslaught of attacks buoyed other companies.For its Q3, Israel-based CyberArk reported sales and earnings that trounced Wall Street's expectations, assisted by 10 new contracts within the federal executive and legislative branches, CEO Udi Mokady told analysts during the conference call.The federal government's Sept. 30 fiscal year-end typically means bolstered fall-quarter sales for companies like CyberArk.But it was the OPM breach and the government 30-day Cybersecurity Sprint initiative that really increased awareness, Mokady said. U.S. Chief Information Officer Tony Scott launched the Sprint in June, forcing federal agencies to examine and better their cybersecurity practices.Privileged-account policies, CyberArk's specialty, was No. 3 on the list of issues that federal agencies had to address.A privileged account has administrative access to a computer system. On average, every organization — the federal government included — has three to four times the number of privileged accounts as employees, CyberArk Chief Marketing Officer John Worrall told IBD.To put that number in perspective, "One bank told us they stopped counting at 1 million," he said.The motivation to protect those accounts is clear. But attackers can be nimbler than the enterprises that they target."One of the biggest challenges organizations face is the attackers can often be more agile than the organizations," he said. "(CyberArk software) adds the ability to detect anomalous behavior ... that helps level the playing field."From a federal government perspective, CyberArk must protect rogues from getting in and insiders from going rogue, Worrall said. He cited Edward Snowden's release of thousands of National Security Agency documents as an example of the latter.To the former point, he said: "Once the outsider comes in, he's going to steal the credentials of an insider, and at that point, honestly, you won't know the difference."Risk Aversion Runs DeepCybersecurity firms are hesitant to break out specific numbers.Neither CyberArk nor Palo Alto Networks would delve deeper into the percentages of total revenue that federal sales comprise. Last month, Fortinet said that it received 12% of its Q3 sales from the government sector — but that figure includes international revenue as well.During Symantec's Q3 earnings call this month, CEO Thomas Seifert would say only that Symantec's U.S. federal business "did very well." Last month, Qualys CEO Philippe Courtot told analysts that a tiny 1% of the company's sales in Q3 derived from federal contracts."So, as you can see, it's probably negligible," he said.All taken, there's still a lot of room for growth, Palo Alto Networks' Vice President of Government Affairs and Policy Ryan Gillis told IBD.The federal government lags the enterprise and private sectors in terms of next-generation technology adoption, he said. Procurement processes are slower, and certification processes often snag quick adoption.Palo Alto Networks allows potential customers to trial its software, Gillis said. Between 80% and 90% of trial runners evolve into customers. But risk aversion within the government runs strong, and federal players generally spurn Palo Alto's offer."It's not an environment conducive to upgrading to the newest and greatest," he said. "It stems from understandable places but disadvantages the network in some cases."That being said, the federal government realizes its precarious position as an international target, and some early adopters within the government have made mass headway into cybersecurity initiatives, Gillis said."The government certainly is a recipient of a range of attacks from run of the mill to very sophisticated stuff," he said. "You certainly get some demanding customers in the government that recognize the nature of the threats."Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Proofpoint (PFPT) stock soared Thursday to a two-month high after the cybersecurity firm late Wednesday posted Q3 revenue that jumped 37% vs. the year-earlier quarter and reduced its per-share losses by a nickel, beating views.The Sunnyvale, Calif.-based company also announced a partnership with Intel (INTC) Security, formerly McAfee, that lets the chipmaker use Proofpoint's threat intelligence information in a "joint go-to-market collaboration," CEO Gary Steele told analysts during the company's Q3 earnings conference call.Proofpoint reported $69.2 million in sales for the quarter and a per-share loss minus items of 6 cents.Both metrics bested the consensus estimate of 21 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, which called for sales of $66 million and an 11-cent loss.Proofpoint stock rose as much as 18% in early trading on the stock market today and was up 13%, near 55.50, in midday trading.Proofpoint guided Q4 revenue up to $72.5 million-$73.5 million, up 28% at the midpoint vs. the year-earlier quarter. The company guided to a per-share loss minus items of 11-12 cents, vs. 9 cents in Q4 2014.For the year, Proofpoint models a 35% increase in revenue to $263 million-$264 million, and 35-36 cents losses per share vs. 40-cent losses in 2014. The company also preliminarily guided revenue up 29-30% for 2016.The company's billings were "white-hot," helped by a 90% subscription renewal rate, FBR analyst Daniel Ives wrote in a research report. Billings rose 37% year over year to $85 million, vs. the consensus forecast for $77.6 million and Proofpoint guidance for $77 million."Proofpoint posted an impressive billings/revenue performance as it penetrated further into its existing installed base with solid cross-sell/upsell execution," Ives wrote.Ives rates Proofpoint stock outperform and maintained an 80 price target.Gaining Vs. HP, SymantecSummit Research analyst Srini Nandury sees Proofpoint overtaking competitors Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Symantec (SYMC) in email archiving market share.And Proofpoint messaging security software will swipe customers from rivals Microsoft (MSFT), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Symantec, Nandury wrote.Tech research firms Gartner and Forrester both consider Proofpoint the best in email protection, he wrote.This status "confirms our belief that Proofpoint's core protection will continue to gain market share from established on-premise players," he wrote. "At present, only 49% of Fortune 100 and 24% of Fortune 1000 (companies) use Proofpoint protection, presenting the company with large headroom to grow its install base," Nandury wrote.Nandury rates Proofpoint stock a buy, with a price target of 80.CEO Steele didn't say much about the partnership with Intel Security, but Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski called it a positive."Management also hinted at several other partnerships that will be announced in 2016," he wrote in a research report. He added that the company's "guidance already factors in a contribution from these partnerships."Nowinski rates Proofpoint stock overweight, with a price target of 76.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

CyberArk's  (CYBR) late Thursday Q3 beat-and-raise wasn't enough to pull it out of FireEye's  (FEYE) tornado, and shares fell again Friday. FireEye sent security software stocks falling Thursday after the company late Wednesday posted disappointing earnings and gave disappointing guidance. CyberArk stock fell 4.5% Thursday and, even after its beat and upward nudge to its 2015 estimates after…
Better-than-expected results couldn't help Red Hat (RHT) stock Tuesday, with shares of the enterprise software company succumbing to concerns over billing as well as a sharp market downturn.

Red Hat shares were trading down almost 2% to near 72 in the stock market today, virtually wiping out gains from the prior day. Investors had bid up shares Monday ahead of the after-hours earnings report.

Some analysts attributed the losses to the market's general downturn. The Nasdaq was down about 2%, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 fell more than 1.5% as they approached midday trading.

But it wasn't just that, some said, as Red Hat also disappointed with its billing numbers. Oppenheimer's Brian Schwartz noted that although currency changes affected valuations by 8%, billing growth of 9% still fell short of expectations.
"Billings (at) 9% is not enough to excite investors and it is the slowest growth for them in eight quarters with tougher year-to-year billings comparisons lying ahead," Schwartz said.

On Monday, Red Hat reported second-quarter earnings of 47 cents a share, up 15% from a year ago and 3 cents ahead of forecasts from analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 13% to $504 million, ahead of views for $494.7 million.

The maker of open-source Linux operating systems also predicted full-year earnings and revenue that were ahead of estimates. Red Hat expects fiscal 2016 earnings of $1.85 to $1.87 a share, up from the $1.83 forecast and 12% ahead of 2015 at the midpoint. Sales are also expected to reach $2.03 billion to $2.04 billion, slightly ahead of views and up 14% from 2015 at the midpoint.
While Schwartz was concerned about billing figures for Red Hat, other analysts said it may not be worth worrying about.

"Billings fell short of consensus expectations but Street modeling has been inconsistent here and billings were impacted by currency and lower contract duration, issues that will likely reverse going forward," BTIG analyst Joel P. Fishbein said in a note to clients. "Overall, we believe Red Hat is one of the best-positioned infrastructure providers in software, with strong execution, a product portfolio that is well-aligned with prevailing technology trends, solid and consistent growth, and continued operating leverage."
Jason Ader, an analyst at William Blair, echoed a similar tone in his research note to clients.
"Red Hat looks optimally positioned to take advantage of the larger trend toward enterprise adoption of open source software and hybrid cloud technology, in our view," Ader wrote.
Red Hat's rivals include Oracle (ORCL), Intel's (INTC) Wind River Systems, Symantec (SYMC), Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), CA (CA) and Citrix Systems (CTXS).

Big-box retailers, investment banks, health insurers, governments, universities: No enterprise seems immune from cyberattacks. That is bad news for victims, but it means more work for cybersecurity companies such as the fast-growing Palo Alto Networks (PANW).

This year alone, hackers gained access to millions of personal records, including Social Security numbers from the U.S. Office of Personnel Management and other personal data from Anthem (ANTM), one of the nation's largest health insurers. More than 30 million e-mail addresses were infamously stolen from extramarital-affairs website Ashley Madison.
Even Apple (AAPL) got hacked: popular Chinese names in its App Store were infected with malicious software.

And these were just high-profile examples this year. They followed a long list of headline-making breaches, including attacks on Sony Pictures (SNE), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Target (TGT) and Home Depot (HD). Untold others suffered breaches outside the spotlight.
"There will be more," said Jonathan Ho, an analyst with William Blair & Co.
Santa Clara, Calif.-based Palo Alto Networks is one of the fastest growing of all the cybermilitia forces and claims to be the fastest growing in next-generation network firewall security.

It launched its first next-generation network firewall security product in 2007 and has since expanded to encompass advanced threats, endpoints and the cloud. Meanwhile, it keeps enhancing existing products and rolling out new ones.
Palo Alto competes with established names in network security such as Cisco Systems (CSCO), Check Point Software (CHKP), Juniper Networks (JNPR) and Fortinet (FTNT).
Disrupting The Legacy Players

"We were a disruptive company," said Palo Alto Chief Marketing Officer Rene Bonvanie in an interview with IBD. Legacy players "did not understand apps, new mobile devices and the cloud. So they couldn't make it safe (everywhere). Our technology makes the use of applications safe no matter where they live."

Palo Alto's next-generation firewall platform is still core to the company's mission: to make it safe for people working in private or public enterprises to use any application from any kind of device.

The company has more than 26,000 customers worldwide and says that it's added at least 1,000 new ones every quarter for the last 15 quarters. It sells to private enterprises, governments and service providers.

In the last quarter, the U.S. government comprised 13% of its business, spread across civilian, intelligence and defense sectors. More than 10% came from service providers, with the rest largely enterprise accounts.
The problem with traditional firewall products was that they became obsolete over time as hackers found ways around them, Ho says.

Next-generation firewall solutions have more and better defenses, including analytics, intrusion prevention and anti-malware to thwart "lots of different bad things that affect your computer," he said.

Legacy players are adapting, but it takes longer for big companies to change course than small ones. Meanwhile, Palo Alto is "rapidly catching up" to the leaders in network security, Cisco and Check Point, Bonvanie says.
"We are now the third-largest player in the enterprise security market after Cisco and Check Point," he said, adding that his firm's share is around 9%.

Palo Alto has been growing revenue more than 50% on average the last two years. In its fiscal fourth quarter, ending in July, revenue jumped 59% to $283.9 million, billings 69% to $393.6 million — both well above analysts' estimates.
Excluding items, it earned 28 cents per share in Q4, 3 cents above views, up from 11 cents last year.

Revenue is expected to slow some from a robust 50%-plus rate, but it's still seen growing in strong double-digit percentages. Palo Alto expects revenue to increase 46%- 48% in the current Q1, ending in October, to $280 million-$284 million. Analysts expect revenue for full fiscal 2016, ending next July, to increase 39% to $1.29 billion.
Earnings for the new year are seen rising 99% to $1.71 per share, according to Thomson Reuters.
Investors Are Beneficiaries
Shares have climbed about 49% this year and are up 336% since the company went public in July 2012.
Firewall solutions still make up "(the) vast majority of our business," Bonvanie says.
Ho says that Check Point has lost "the least (market) share," while Fortinet is still early in next-generation firewall products.
Cisco started stemming market-share losses starting late last year as it integrated products from its acquisition SourceFire in late 2013, according to Nomura Securities analyst Frederick Grieb.

Based on a recently published Nomura survey of 30 security professionals asked about their buying plans for this year and next, Palo Alto and rival FireEye (FEYE) could be expected to gain the most in spending dollars.

The survey indicated that the No. 1 priority for security spending this year is for advanced persistent threat protection, which plays into Palo Alto's WildFire product. WildFire's customer base increased 140% by the fourth quarter vs. a year ago to more than 7,000.

Endpoint protection — whether for a desktop, laptop, tablet, smartphone, cash register, ATM or other computerized hardware — was the second priority. Target, for example, was attacked at the endpoint — through its cash registers.
Palo Alto's even newer Traps product, which addresses endpoint security, ended the last quarter with 150 customers.
FireEye competes with Palo Alto in both advanced persistent threat protection and endpoint security.
Wild West Exotic Tech

Endpoint security "has become the Wild West of security," attracting startups with "exotic technology," said Palo Alto's Bonvanie. "Everybody has figured out that the original products are not very useful."
Palo Alto's large installed base of customers using its firewall products "gives us a competitive advantage over the smaller guys" in endpoint security, he said.
Other endpoint security players include privately held Bit9 + Carbon Black, Invincea and Bromium.

Symantec (SYMC) and McAfee dominate endpoint security. Nomura's survey of security professionals was "generally negative" for Symantec, Grieb noted in the survey report, "with customer perception of the company and its road map continuing to deteriorate over the past 12 months."
Similar Endpoint Opportunities
Said Ho: "Palo Alto is the main beneficiary of the next-generation transition on the firewall side, and we think they could have similar opportunities in the next-generation endpoint side."
Nomura's survey suggested that IT security spending will grow 14% this year and 17% next year.

In a recent research note, JPMorgan analyst Sterling Auty said that Palo Alto's platform "is increasingly resonating with customers" and that demand for its products "remains robust."Big-box retailers, investment banks, health insurers, governments, universities: No enterprise seems immune from cyberattacks. That is bad news for victims, but it means more work for cybersecurity companies such as the fast-growing Palo Alto Networks (PANW).This year alone, hackers gained access to millions of personal records, including Social Security numbers from the U.S. Office of Personnel Management and other personal data from Anthem (ANTM), one of the nation's largest health insurers. More than 30 million e-mail addresses were infamously stolen from extramarital-affairs website Ashley Madison.Even Apple (AAPL) got hacked: popular Chinese names in its App Store were infected with malicious software.And these were just high-profile examples this year. They followed a long list of headline-making breaches, including attacks on Sony Pictures (SNE), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Target (TGT) and Home Depot (HD). The No. 1 provider of Linux open-source operating system software reported earnings per share minus items of 47 cents, up 14.6% from the year-earlier period and 3 cents above the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.

Revenue for the quarter ended Aug. 31 rose 13% to $504 million, where analysts had modeled $494.7 million.Red Hat (RHT) said it expects fiscal 2016 EPS excluding items of $1.85 to $1.87, vs. the $1.83 expected by analysts. The company forecasts revenue of $2.03 billion to $2.04 billion, ahead of views. At the midpoints, EPS would be up 12% and sales up nearly 14%.

"Despite currency headwinds, the company exceeded expectations," Al Hilwa, an analyst with tech research firm IDC, told IBD. "What is really impressive is the synergy they are getting out of their (application development) and operating system business through cross deals.

"The growth in the (application development) subscription business, at 48%, is really hitting it out of the ballpark compared to how the rest of the industry is doing in this space. That this segment has now reached 16% of Red Hat's business drives the point home that they are not just an operating systems company."
Red Hat stock, though, was down 1% in after-hours trading, after the company released its results, after at first seesawing between slightly up and slightly down.
The company is making strides in making many of its applications cloud-based, Red Hat CEO Jim Whitehurst said in the company's earnings release.
Up 21% In Constant Currency

"Strong execution in Q2 contributed to total revenue results that exceeded 21% year-over-year growth on a constant currency basis. We were pleased with the progress of our technologies that address cloud deployments across multiple footprints," Whitehurst said in the release. "We are also thrilled to be the first open-source company to achieve an annualized run-rate of $2 billion in revenue this quarter.
"In addition, we believe Red Hat is well-positioned for the second half of the fiscal year as we continue to benefit from delivering innovation to our customers."

The leader in Linux systems hit a 15-year, post-dot-com-boom high of 81.49 when it reported Q1 earnings in June, but shares fell as much as 18% from that high this month when the market retreated. Red Hat stock rose 2.3% in Monday's regular session, to 72.72.
Red Hat's all-time high, adjusted for stock splits, is 151.31, reached in December 1999, at the height of the dot-com craze.
Red Hat's competitors include Oracle (ORCL) and Intel's (INTC) Wind River Systems, as well as Symantec (SYMC), Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), CA (CA) and Citrix Systems (CTXS).
Red Hat has been getting mixed reviews of late, as the company looks beyond Linux to the cloud and other areas for growth.
The company has received two price-target hikes in the last quarter, and had one investment firm initiate coverage with a buy rating, according to 24/7 Wall St.

But stock analysis firm ValuEngine on Monday said in a research report that it expects Red Hat's earnings to lag its sector's growth over the next year. Compared with Check Point, Symantec, CA and Citrix, it will rank last in return on investment over the next year, said ValuEngine.
But Red Hat will outpace both its sector and the S&P 500 over the next five years, the report says.

Researcher firm New Constructs called for investors to sell Red Hat shares, in a report issued over the weekend, giving Red Hat stock its second-lowest "dangerous" rating. The research firm says Red Hat's levels of price-to-economic-book-value and growth appreciation are considered to be "very dangerous," but it also said its free-cash-flow yield is "attractive."The No. 1 provider of Linux open-source operating system software reported earnings per share minus items of 47 cents, up 14.6% from the year-earlier period and 3 cents above the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Revenue for the quarter ended Aug. 31 rose 13% to $504 million, where analysts had modeled $494.7 million.Red Hat (RHT) said it expects fiscal 2016 EPS excluding items of $1.85 to $1.87, vs. the $1.83 expected by analysts. The company forecasts revenue of $2.03 billion to $2.04 billion, ahead of views. At the midpoints, EPS would be up 12% and sales up nearly 14%."Despite currency headwinds, the company exceeded expectations," Al Hilwa, an analyst with tech research firm IDC, told IBD. "What is really impressive is the synergy they are getting out of their (application development) and operating system business through cross deals."The growth in the (application development) subscription business, at 48%, is really hitting it out of the ballpark compared to how the rest of the industry is doing in this space. That this segment has now reached 16% of Red Hat's business drives the point home that they are not just an operating systems company."Red Hat stock, though, was down 1% in after-hours trading, after the company released its results, after at first seesawing between slightly up and slightly down.The company is making strides in making many of its applications cloud-based, Red Hat CEO Jim Whitehurst said in the company's earnings release.Up 21% In Constant Currency"Strong execution in Q2 contributed to total revenue results that exceeded 21% year-over-year growth on a constant currency basis. We were pleased with the progress of our technologies that address cloud deployments across multiple footprints," Whitehurst said in the release. "We are also thrilled to be the first open-source company to achieve an annualized run-rate of $2 billion in revenue this quarter."In addition, we believe Red Hat is well-positioned for the second half of the fiscal year as we continue to benefit from delivering innovation to our customers."The leader in Linux systems hit a 15-year, post-dot-com-boom high of 81.49 when it reported Q1 earnings in June, but shares fell as much as 18% from that high this month when the market retreated. Red Hat stock rose 2.3% in Monday's regular session, to 72.72.Red Hat's all-time high, adjusted for stock splits, is 151.31, reached in December 1999, at the height of the dot-com craze.Red Hat's competitors include Oracle (ORCL) and Intel's (INTC) Wind River Systems, as well as Symantec (SYMC), Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), CA (CA) and Citrix Systems (CTXS).Red Hat has been getting mixed reviews of late, as the company looks beyond Linux to the cloud and other areas for growth.The company has received two price-target hikes in the last quarter, and had one investment firm initiate coverage with a buy rating, according to 24/7 Wall St.But stock analysis firm ValuEngine on Monday said in a research report that it expects Red Hat's earnings to lag its sector's growth over the next year. Compared with Check Point, Symantec, CA and Citrix, it will rank last in return on investment over the next year, said ValuEngine.But Red Hat will outpace both its sector and the S&P 500 over the next five years, the report says.Researcher firm New Constructs called for investors to sell Red Hat shares, in a report issued over the weekend, giving Red Hat stock its second-lowest "dangerous" rating. The research firm says Red Hat's levels of price-to-economic-book-value and growth appreciation are considered to be "very dangerous," but it also said its free-cash-flow yield is "attractive."

A marriage that at the time left many in Silicon Valley scratching their heads will be a thing of the past, as Symantec (SYMC) said Tuesday that it would sell its Veritas data storage business to private equity firm Carlyle Group, valuing the deal at $8 billion.The security software maker's purchase of Veritas in 2004 for more than $13 billion left many on Wall Street wondering about the synergies, as many analysts viewed the two businesses as incompatible, though Symantec stock did hit its all-time high that December, above 34.Last year, Symantec said it would split into two companies, the Symantec and Veritas businesses, but rumors of a possible deal with Carlyle surfaced last month."While this potential transaction has been discussed in recent media reports, today's news should come as a relief to investors as Symantec finally unloads this 'decade of agita' since the Veritas acquisition was done and now can laser-focus efforts on beefing up its legacy security platform through aggressive M&A with cash from this transaction," FBR analyst Daniel Ives said in a research note. "The Veritas acquisition, in our opinion, remains one of the most head-scratching transactions we have seen in the tech space over the last 15 years and has been a black cloud around the Symantec story, as the company has struggled to reinvigorate its security segment while integrating this square peg in a round hole."Privately held Carlyle will be joined by GIC, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, in the purchase. The deal is expected to close this year.The deal includes $6.3 billion in net cash proceeds that go to Symantec. The rest involves increases in share-repurchasing programs.In a statement, Symantec CEO Michael Brown said the sale paves "the way for Symantec to grow its security business and increase its lead as the world's largest cybersecurity company."Symantec early Tuesday also reported earnings for its fiscal Q1 ended July 3 that missed Wall Street expectations.Symantec stock was down 4.5% in early afternoon trading Tuesday, near 22.The company reported adjusted net income of 40 cents a share, down 11% from the year-earlier quarter and missing the 43 cents predicted by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue fell 14% to $1.5 billion.Gray Powell, an analyst at Wells Fargo, said in a research note that Symantec's fiscal Q2 guidance fell below street estimates, with revenue guided at $1.49 billion to $1.53 billion vs. consensus projections of $1.54 billion, and EPS ex items at 40 cents to 43 cents vs. the 45-cent analyst forecast.

Stock futures skidded lower ahead of Tuesday's open, as global currencies, markets and commodities reacted to a policy shift in China.

Dow futures appeared to be feeling for a bottom around 140 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were down 22.41 points. S&P 500 futures were off a stiff 14.2 points. Small caps looked to be particularly hard hit, with Russell 2000 futures down more than 11 points.

The stock market today sees the Nasdaq and S&P 500 at least briefly back above their 50-day moving averages. Monday's gains were broad, spurred by a Precision Castparts (PCP) acquisition and Federal Reserve assurances that interest rates wouldn't change until inflation hit 2%.

But the advance carried in weak volume, suggesting the enthusiasm didn't run too deep. Traders suspect this may be the case through the rest of the August vacation season, suggesting markets will stick to their tightly bound trading ranges through Labor Day.

U.S. economic news opened with the Labor Department's preliminary estimate on Q2 productivity, up 1.3% and a healthy jump from Q1's 1.1% slip. But the Q2 number was below economist consensus expectations for a 1.6% increase. Unit labor costs rose 0.5%, down from Q1's 6.7% surge and in line with forecasts.
The Commerce Department reports wholesale business inventory data for June at 10 a.m. ET.
The bigger economic news came from China's central bank, which on Tuesday freed the yuan up to 2% with market forces. The move sent the currency down 2% in its biggest one-day adjustment since 1994.

It was the currency's first major downward adjustment since the Chinese government began a decade ago to dismantle its policy of holding the yuan artificially low vs. the dollar, a strategy that gave China exports an advantage on international markets.

The People's Central Bank of China move followed data last weekend showing China's exports slumped unexpectedly in July and the country's producer price index saw its biggest drop in more than five years.

The change was the most recent by a Chinese leadership that has become increasingly erratic in its effort to brake its slowing economy and manage its burgeoning stock markets. Despite the scale of the maneuver, China's markets showed little reaction, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index ending down 0.1% and the Shanghai Composite off a fraction.

Oil prices backed off a bit less than 2%, giving back most of Monday's gains. Copper dumped 3%. Gold rose a fraction. Europe's markets rounded down to notable losses, with Frankfurt's DAX slipping 1.8%, Paris' CAC-40 1.2% lower and the FTSE 100 in London showing a 0.8% decline heading into the lunch hour.
In U.S. premarket trade, mining issues reacted to the currency change, with Freeport McMoRan (FCX), Vale (VALE), BHP Billiton (BHP) and Arcelor Mittal (MT) all sharply lower.
Company news was also moving stocks, with Google (GOOGL) up 6% after announcing late Monday it would restructure, creating a new publicly traded parent company named Alphabet.
Google will operate as a subsidiary under Alphabet. The company also named a new chief executive to Google, Sundar Pichai. Google co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin will manage Alphabet.

Symantec (SYMC) climbed 2% after agreeing to sell its data management unit Veritas for $8 billion to an investors led by Carlyle Group and including Singapore sovereign-wealth fund GIC. Symantec shares have been struggling against a deepening decline since January.

On the earnings front, Vipshop (VIPS) slumped 6% in premarket action after reporting late Monday its second-quarter earnings and revenue topped expectations, and operating margins expanded by two-thirds over year-ago levels.

But Q3 revenue guidance was on the weak side — at the low end of analyst estimates and slower than second-quarter growth. Vipshop has been fighting to retake its 10-week moving average, in a consolidation that ended Monday's session 32% below its late April high.Stock futures skidded lower ahead of Tuesday's open, as global currencies, markets and commodities reacted to a policy shift in China.Dow futures appeared to be feeling for a bottom around 140 points below fair market value. Two top-rated IBD 50 tech stocks report second-quarter financial results Tuesday, cybersecurity company CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Zebra Technologies (ZBRA), whose suite of advanced technology helps companies track products.
CyberArk is a small but fast-growing Internet security company.

The Israel-based firm, which reports after the market closes Tuesday, focuses on providing security for privileged accounts — key executives and others with access to confidential data within an organization. Its software works inside a company's network to protect and defend against attacks.
Analyst consensus is for CyberArk to report Q2 earnings per share of 6 cents on $32.38 million in revenue. No comps are available for the September 2014 IPO.
In Q1, it reported 16 cents EPS, vs. views for 5 cents. In Q4 2014, its first full-quarter report, it had 21 cents EPS, trouncing Wall Street's 5-cent target.

CyberArk is part of a group of fast-growing companies fighting waves of cyberattacks. The blue chip group includes Palo Alto Networks (PANW), whose platform provides corporate security and whose stock boasts a best-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating. Israel's Check Point Software (CHKP) and China's Cheetah Mobile (CMCM) also are in the software security group.
(So is Symantec (SYMC), which also reports earnings Tuesday night. But earnings and revenue have been spotty and the stock has been in a downtrend. Symantec has a Composite Rating of just 53.)
CyberArk began trading on Sept. 24 after pricing at 16 in its initial public offering.

Its stock has risen 277% in nine months and closed above 60 Friday, up about 3% for the day in trading on the stock market. Shares have found resistance at the 50-day moving average since the end of June.
(By comparison, Palo Alto Networks fell nearly 6% for the week, closing below its 200-day moving average.)
Zebra Technologies makes and sells portable computers, thermal and thermal-transfer label printers, radio frequency identification (RFID) printers and encoders and other products.
Its products are used for everything from printing bar-code labels, receipts and plastic ID cards to encoding passive RFID smart labels and cards onto merchandise.
In October, Zebra completed its biggest-ever acquisition, buying Motorola Solutions' (MSI) Enterprise Solutions business for $3.45 billion.
Wall Street expects Zebra, whose stock is also on the prestigious IBD Leaderboard list, to report a 207% increase in revenue to $885.4 million Tuesday morning.

Zebra is also projected to record a 41% jump in EPS to $1.18. It topped earnings estimates the prior quarter, after missing in Q4 2014. Investors will look to see if the company can make it two in a row.

Israeli firm CyberArk Software (CYBR) smashed Wall Street expectations with its Q2 earnings beat Tuesday. The network security provider's stock price has almost doubled since its September IPO.

Savvy Americans rode the coattails of a new ETF for investment success in the relatively young cybersecurity industry. PureFunds ISE Cyber Security (HACK) launched in November 2014 and rapidly swelled to more than a billion dollar in assets.
But that very success is drawing concerns at financial data firm S&P Capital IQ. Analysts there caution investors to be careful with cybersecurity companies.
Several holdings in HACK are overvalued despite their extremely strong growth prospects, Todd Rosenbluth, director of ETF research at S&P Capital IQ, wrote in an Aug. 11 note.
Rosenbluth acknowledged that some holdings such as Symantec (SYMC) are still attractively valued; others far less so.

"Fortinet (FTNT) shares climbed 54% year to date through Aug. 10, but still traded at what is a lofty 50 times 2017 estimates," he said. "Of course, an investor's confidence with consensus estimates two-plus years out should not be considered firm."
Fortinet is the No. 1 stock in HACK, with 5% portfolio weighting. The California-based company provides firewall and VPN services to enterprise customers, including health care organizations.
Both companies have had tepid earnings growth in the past three years. But Fortinet's sales have grown at a 21% clip, while Symantec's have shrunk 2%.

Health insurer Anthem (ANTM) in February reported that a massive hack exposed data on more than 70 million members. Audacious data thefts have been reported by both corporations such as Sony Corp. (SNE), Target (TGT) and Home Depot (HD), as well as government entities. Systems at both the Internal Revenue Service and, very recently, the Pentagon were reportedly breached by Russian and Chinese hackers.
Splunk (SPLK), another top 10 holding in HACK, is also looking pricey.
"After rising 18% thus far in 2015, the shares recently traded at a lofty 117 times the FY 2018 estimate," Rosenbluth wrote.
He also notes HACK's relatively high 0.75% expense ratio, or $75 in annual fees for every $10,000 invested.
On the other hand, the $1.36 billion ETF's strategy offers fairly well-diversified exposure to network security firms. None of its 32 stock holdings currently holds more than 5% of assets.
While HACK is up 11.4% year to date, it is 12% off its June high of 33.91.
That, Rosenbluth added, is "a reminder that the stocks inside can be volatile" with a concentrated ETF bet such as HACK.
HACK fell 0.7% in big volume on the stock market today.
Capital IQ does not yet cover First Trust NASDAQ CEA Cybersecurity (CIBR). This new ETF rival to HACK has similar holdings, but their weightings are different.

Salesforce.com's (CRM) stock price managed to advance Friday as a strong earnings report fueled an analyst upgrade while Gap (GPS) shares tumbled on downward price target revisions.Meanwhile, Hewlett-Packard's (HPQ) stock price rose 7.6% intraday, but held onto just a 0.4% uptick despite its price target being lowered by both Mizuho and FBR Capital Markets following a mixed earnings report.Salesforce.com was upgraded to buy from hold by Pivotal Research early Friday after beating earnings and revenue views late Thursday. The biggest change came from Stifel, which lowered its PT to 40 from 48. The apparel retailer's stock sank 4.4.SunEdison (SUNE) was initiated with a hold rating by Axiom, then watched its stock plunge 11.4% to 10.72, hitting its lowest point since November 2013. Reports by Bloomberg and other news organizations that Symantec (SYMC) is nearing the sale of its Veritas data-storage business has one analyst applauding what he calls a "long-overdue breakup" at an attractive price.

Bloomberg reported Tuesday that Symantec is nearing a deal to sell its Veritas data-storage business to private equity firm The Carlyle Group (CG) for $7 billion to $8 billion, citing "people with knowledge of the matter."

"Symantec, which has been shopping the unit for several months, is still negotiating the terms of a possible transaction, said the people, who asked not to be identified discussing private information," Bloomberg reported. "No agreement has been reached and talks could still falter."
FBR Capital Markets analyst Daniel Ives, in a research note Wednesday, said he sees a $7.5 billion as "an attractive price tag."

Symantec in November said it would split into separate security and data storage/data management companies, but Ives said "we would welcome a sale vs. a split despite potential negative tax implications. It would be a major liquidity event for Symantec and add more dry powder to help bulk up its next-generation cybersecurity offerings and put some much-needed fuel in the company's growth engine."
Symantec stock was up a fraction in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 23. In January, Symantec stock touched a 10-year high above 27.
Mountain View, Calif.-based Symantec has said it expects to complete the legal separation of the companies on Jan. 2, with the first day of trading as stand-alone companies on Jan. 4.
On Tuesday, Veritas rolled out Veritas NetBackup 7.7, designed to improve data backup and recovery in cloud-storage services.
"We continue to believe the breakup was long overdue, as the current security/storage structure under one roof has been counterproductive over the past decade, in our opinion ... ," Ives said.
Security stocks have been doing well in general amid a string of high-profile data breaches and cybercrimes.
IBD's 23-company Computer-Security group ranks No. 7 of 197 groups, with top performers including CyberArk Software (CYBR), IBD Leaderboard stock Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Qualys (QLYS).
Palo Alto Networks has pulled back near its 50-day moving average after a rapid advance but it well extended from its last breakout.

Cisco Systems (CSCO) is telling Wall Street that corporate buyers of computer security products want to narrow down the number of their suppliers, prompting analysts to speculate about which company Cisco might buy next to gain market share."Cisco's analysis suggests that the average large enterprise has 54-plus security vendors, with chief information officers finding it an extremely tough and convoluted landscape to manage," said UBS analyst Amitabh Passi in a research report. "We don't believe Cisco has any delusions of replacing 50-plus vendors with just itself, but the goal is to simplify the landscape."Increasing Cisco's market share in the $25 billion enterprise security infrastructure market from 9% to 20%-30% is a goal of incoming CEO Chuck Robbins, says Passi.Many big tech and defense companies are jumping deeper into the security market vs. pure-play leaders such as Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), Symantec (SYMC), Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Fortinet (FTNT).Tim Long, an analyst at BMO Capital Markets, met recently with Cisco's top security business executives."Cisco believes that one of the key changes that will occur in the industry over the next few years is that customers will increasingly move from point vendors that provide niche solutions to companies that can provide an architectural approach," Long wrote in a report Monday. "Cisco expects that the changes will be necessitated as some customers currently work with as many 100 different security vendors in a single organization."This should also drive increased industry consolidation."Passi doubts that Cisco would buy a big security vendor such as Palo Alto or Check Point, despite its $2.7 billion acquisition of Sourcefire in 2013. He foresees more small deals, such as Cisco's $635 million deal for OpenDNS, announced June 30."We foresee both organic investments and M&A; playing a role in accelerating sales and growing market share," Passi said. "The fastest-growing subsegments in security where Cisco has limited-to-no presence, and are therefore areas of interest, include identity access and management; security information and event management; data loss prevention; and application security testing."Cisco Systems stock was up a fraction, near 28, in midday trading in the stock market today.

Honeywell, BAE Systems, Lockheed, AT&T, IBM, Intel, Raytheon, HP, Booz Allen, Cisco Systems and EMC are all, of course, well-known ... security companies? Indeed, the ranks of computer security vendors range far beyond the pure-play makers of security software such as Symantec (SYMC), Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Fortinet (FTNT). That defense contractors and big tech companies are moving into,…

Security software maker Symantec (SYMC), which is preparing to split into two companies, late Thursday reported fiscal Q4 revenue and earnings that slightly missed analyst expectations, as did its outlook for the current quarter.Symantec reported earnings per share excluding items of 43 cents for the quarter ended April 3, down 10% from the year-earlier quarter. Non-GAAP revenue fell 6% to $1.55 billion, while overall revenue fell 7% to $1.52 billion.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters forecast EPS minus items of 44 cents on $1.56 billion in revenue, though it wasn't clear if analyst estimates with overall revenue or non-GAAP.For the current quarter, Symantec guided EPS ex items of 41 cents to 44 cents and revenue of $1.5 billion to $1.54 billion.Analysts had modeled 45 cents, flat with the year-ago quarter, and a 6.9% decline in revenue to $1.615 billion.Symantec stock was down 2.5% in after-hours trading Thursday. Shares rose 2.3% in Thursday's regular session."Setting aside currency headwinds, continued growth in both implied billings and deferred revenue underscores the momentum in our businesses," Symantec CEO Michael Brown said in the company's earnings release.The Mountain View, Calif.-based company is preparing to separate into two companies, one focused on security software including its Norton antivirus product and the other on its Veritas information management business. The legal separation is set to occur Jan. 2, with trading to commence on Monday, Jan. 4, the company said.Symantec announced the split in October, saying it would give each business more growth opportunities, after little or no annual revenue growth the past six years.Several security vendors have reported better-than-expected March-quarter earnings as enterprises invest to improve their cyber defenses.IBD's 23-company Computer Software-Security group ranks No. 15 out of 197 groups tracked. The group boasts two companies with highest-possible 99 ratings, CyberArk (CYBR) and Palo Alto Networks (PANW), which is slated to post earnings for its fiscal Q3 ended April 30 after the market close on May 27. CyberArk shares rose 0.3% on Thursday while Palo Alto climbed 1.5%.Last Thursday, CyberArk reported its third straight quarter of accelerating growth. On April 20, Fortinet (FTNT) posted its biggest quarterly billings growth since its IPO in 2009. That same day, Check Point Software (CHKP) posted Q1 results that beat on the top and bottom lines. Both stocks rose more than 1% during the regular session.

Security software maker Symantec (SYMC), which is preparing to split into two companies, late Thursday reported fiscal Q4 revenue and earnings that slightly missed analyst expectations, as did its outlook for the current quarter. The company, however, is headed in the right direction, Symantec CEO Michael Brown told IBD in a short interview after earnings were released. If adjusted for…

Casino resort giant Caesars Entertainment is betting on Vasco Data Security International's multifactor authentication technology to provide an extra layer of security — beyond just username and password — to help prevent hackers from sneaking into its networks.Vasco's (VDSI) recently introduced Cronto authentication and transaction-signing technology is being used by Dutch multinational financial service company Rabobank to improve security, via camera-equipped Rabo Scanner card readers. Vasco's technology provides a graphical cryptogram representing a transaction. When a picture of it is taken and then decoded, customers can securely view financial details on a computer, smartphone or tablet and then authorize the transaction."Our Cronto technology uses a high-definition color QR (Quick Response) code to deliver a hack-proof method of logging in and signing, which makes the process easier for users by having them perform fewer steps than they do today," Vasco CEO T. Kendall Hunt told IBD.In March, Vasco's electronic transaction signing technology was selected by Japanese megabank Mizuho Bank to help protect online banking transactions from hacking attacks.Caesars Entertainment (CZR), Rabobank and Mizuho Bank are among Vasco's 10,000-plus customers in 100 countries.Oakbrook Terrace, Ill.-based Vasco provides authentication and e-signature products and services, specializing in securing online accounts, managing identities and transactions, and protecting assets across financial, enterprise, e-commerce, government and health-care markets."Much of Vasco's success has been in the online banking vertical, and many banks are upgrading to their next-generation multi-factor authentication and e-signature products," said Dougherty & Co. analyst Joseph Maxa."In addition, they have a new product for securing mobile banking applications," Maxa said. "They're having success in Europe and Asia-Pacific, and several U.S. banks are using or evaluating their mobile products."Some 95% of Web app attacks make use of compromised credentials, including stolen user names and passwords, according to Verizon Communications' (VZ) 2015 Data Breach Investigations Report.More than 2.4 billion users are expected to embrace mobile banking services by 2020, compared to roughly 800 million in 2014, market tracking firm Research and Markets said in an April report.Growth DriversVasco says more than half of the top 100 global banks use its products and services to protect mobile applications, meet regulatory requirements and enhance overall security. Vasco also secures access to data and applications in the cloud, and provides tools for application developers to integrate security functions into Web-based and mobile applications.Hunt says a confluence of factors is driving its growth: Enterprises need more effective defenses against increasingly sophisticated cyberattacks, users want security but also convenience, and there's growth in mobile applications."Our (security) solutions have been battle tested in the most extreme hacking environment — banking — and we believe they will have appeal in many other segments," Hunt told IBD.Las Vegas-based Caesars, with some 50 casinos plus resorts and other properties, turned to Vasco for software that enables a user's mobile phone to serve as a secure authentication device.William Worthington, Caesars' chief information security officer, says it wanted an additional authentication layer while not making it too complex for corporate users."Having a mobile solution makes it simple for employees to comply with a much higher level of security," Worthington said.Rabobank looked to Vasco's Digipass technology, with a one-time password that changes every 30 seconds, to enable a large-scale rollout of secure card readers that meet EMV (Europay, MasterCard (MA) and Visa (V) standards. Rabobank customers can do e-banking and secure e-commerce with Rabobank's secure smart card readers.Banks, retailers and other merchants in the U.S. are readying to support chip-enabled payment cards by an October 2015 EMV deadline, which shifts liability for fraudulent transactions to whichever entity involved has not yet adopted chip technology.Rabobank's purchases alone accounted for more than 30% of Vasco's Q1 revenue, Vasco noted in its Q1 earnings report on April 28 that beat Wall Street expectations.Vasco's Q1 earnings per share excluding items was 34 cents, up 278% from a year earlier. Revenue increased 68% to $65.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS ex items of 21 cents and $54.5 million in revenue.Vasco's Q1 results were spurred by an 83% increase in revenue from the banking market, as financial institutions spend on new software and hardware products, particularly payment card readers. Card readers represented 45% of Q1 revenue, vs. 21% a year earlier.Some 73% of Vasco's Q1 revenue came from the Europe-Middle East-Africa region, and 17% came from Asia, while the U.S. accounted for just 4%, and 6% was from other countries. Vasco boosted its full-year 2015 revenue guidance to a range of between $230 million and $240 million, up from a prior range of $220 million to $230 million, citing "a strong pipeline of potential new orders" for its traditional and new authentication and anti-fraud products. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters now forecast full-year 2015 revenue of $237.6 million.Vasco faces a wide range of competitors, including more direct rivals such as RSA Security, which is a subsidiary of EMC Corp. (EMC), and Gemalto, as well as other indirect competition from companies such as SafeNet and Symantec (SYMC).Vasco stock currently trades at about 26, down from an all-time high of 44.25 in October 2007.Dougherty's Maxa says Vasco's Digipass for Apps (DPA) product generates a new revenue stream."It secures mobile banking within the mobile app itself, kind of behind the scenes," Maxa said. "The user may not even know it's there. It's early, but it is being adopted and should help them gain traction in the U.S."Several banks have upgraded or are in the process of upgrading to their PIN pad tokens," Maxa said. "They're now seeing banks upgrade to their new CrontoSign technology, which is easier to use than their PIN pad tokens. Rabobank placed the largest order in the company's history for this technology, and several other large banks are trialing it. The success of Vasco's e-signature technology is due in part to its ability to prevent man-in-the-middle and man-in-the-browser type attacks."How An Attack WorksHunt says a man-in-the-middle attack involves a hacker essentially taking over a banking transaction, changing the payee and amount."For example, you think you are sending $100 to your mother in Kansas, and they change the transaction to instead send $1,000 to Eastern Europe," Hunt said. "By using a tamper-proof, high-definition color QR (Quick Response) code in the process, it becomes extremely easy for the bank customer to see the true transaction details and then verify them."Governments are eyeing Vasco's technology, as well."The Singapore government is offering citizens a free authentication token, named OneKey, using our technology so that citizens can utilize two-factor authentication to have a more secure experience" accessing government applications online, Hunt said."In Belgium, the government has a similar vision of allowing citizens to use their government-issued ID to verify their identity, but they want to take advantage of the large number of card readers that are already in use by citizens today," Hunt said.Maxa sees Singapore as "probably a bigger near-term revenue opportunity of the two, as Belgium is in the very early stages."

CyberArk Software (CYBR) late Thursday reported Q1 earnings and revenue that easily topped Wall Street expectations, fueled by increased spending on IT security as enterprises look to stop hackers inside their networks.Israel-based CyberArk reported Q1 earnings per share excluding items of 16 cents. Revenue rose 89% to $32.9 million, the third straight quarter of accelerating sales growth. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS ex items of 5 cents on $26.7 million in revenue. CyberArk has had at least 13 straight quarters of double-digit revenue gains.For the current quarter, CyberArk forecasts EPS ex items of 4 cents to 6 cents and revenue of $31.5 million to $32.5 million, up 48% to 52%. Analysts forecast EPS ex items of 4 cents on $30 million in revenue.CyberArk focuses on protecting privileged accounts that serve as gateways to sensitive and valuable information inside their computer networks. Privileged accounts are often exploited in targeted attacks by hackers that can go for months without being detected after gaining access to networks and databases.For 2015, CyberArk has guided its revenue at $136 million to $138 million, up 32% to 34%. It expects non-GAAP EPS of 40 cents to 44 cents.CyberArk stock was up 3% in after-hours trading Thursday, after its earnings release, after closing down 1.7% in the regular session, at 61.33. CyberArk stock touched a high of 70.48 on Feb. 20. The company made its IPO in September, pricing shares at 16.Other security companies scheduled to report financial results this month include Symantec (SYMC) on May 14 and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) on May 27, both after the market close.

After coming off a banner 2014, in which earnings per share more than doubled and sales rose 24% to a record $134 million, Qualys (QLYS) is expected to deliver strong results again in the first quarter.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see profit rising 120% to 11 cents a share. This would be the third triple-digit gain in five quarters. Sales are slated to grow 25% to $38 million. Top-line growth accelerated for four straight quarters, helped by new services. Qualys will report results May 4 after the close.
Its full-year earnings are expected to rise 15% to 53 cents a share. The estimate was recently revised higher. Profit for 2016 is slated to climb 30% to 69 cents a share.
The Redwood City, Calif.-based firm provides cloud-based cybersecurity products and services. It has over 7,700 customers in more than 100 countries.
Cybersecurity has been a hot topic in recent months amid data breaches at Home Depot (HD), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Sony (SNE) and Target (TGT).

With a market cap of close to $1.8 billion, it is one of the smaller companies in the highly ranked Computer Software Security group. The two biggest firms in the group, Symantec (SYMC) and Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP), each have market caps of around $16 billion. But Qualys has a highest-possible Composite Rating of 99.

Qualys has pulled back this week after bolting 14% in big turnover last week. During that surge, the stock blew past buy points at 50.10 and 49.52 from what could be called a seven-week base . Although the stock poked into new-high territory in the week ended March 6, it failed to make a new closing high. So it's OK to count it as just another week in the base. Volume was more than double its daily average on the actual breakout day of April 8.

Security software giant Symantec unleashes plenty of its own cyberattacks, but they are simulated assaults designed to immerse clients in a chaotic world.

The company thrusts chief executives and employees of all stripes into simulated attacks so they can learn how to make quick, often hard decisions that might one day determine if their business suffers a major data breach or takes a huge financial hit.

Like war games that the military uses to prepare for combat, interactive games and simulations are becoming part of defense arsenals aimed at helping companies and other organizations cope with increasingly complex threats.
Symantec (SYMC) is rolling out a cloud-based, hands-on cybersecurity simulation that customers can access from anywhere and engage in realistic training scenarios, CEO Michael Brown told IBD.

"We have been expanding our offerings for customers who find security a pretty complex area and would like some help managing that," Brown said. "We have a managed security service offering and expanded that to incident response — what to do if you're breached. You can call us and we can help you by parachuting a team in."

Simulations have long been part of well-known hacker competitions such as the long-running Def Con event, to be held Aug. 6-9 in Las Vegas. But security companies, consultants and others are applying game elements to non-game activities, creating software developed with traditional gaming techniques and technologies.
Simulations can thrust people and a computer network into realistic situations.

Palo Alto Networks' (PANW) cloud-based virtual malware analysis environment, called WildFire, can mimic company or government computers. A virtual "sandbox" security mechanism sifts through and analyzes unknown files to identify malware and other threats so as not to expose and harm a company or agency's network, says Scott Simkin, senior cyber analyst for Palo Alto Networks.

"WildFire is essentially applying a magnifying glass to all that activity that has never been seen before," Simkin said. "You basically turn all of your devices into a sensor for unknown threats — a piece of malware or exploit that has completely been able to bypass traditional security solutions, whether they be firewalls or antivirus. It's the really bad, unknown, advanced and targeted threats that WildFire is built to handle."
Once detected, WildFire automatically creates new protections and informs thousands of WildFire subscribers about the threats as they're being blocked.
Simkin says that simulation and live training puts information technology security staff "into the weeds, so to speak."

"Yes, you need user education and training," Simkin said. "But I would say it's on us, in the security industry as practitioners in the field, to do a better job of implementing the best technologies that we have to protect the users."

Palo Alto Networks' teams participate in simulated games such as Pacific Endeavor, an annual multinational exercise where teams defend against cyberattack scenarios such as infection from virus, trojans and spyware.
Symantec developed the Cyber Readiness Challenge, an offshoot of its internal CyberWar Games, which it offers to its customers online and in nearly two dozen countries.

Check Point Software Technologies (CHKP) and Blackfin Security collaborate on simulation exercises for customers, such as a "hacker academy" and "capture the flag" competitions modeled after real attack scenarios.

Security experts say that unlike assessments that evaluate a company's firewalls and other cyberdefenses, cybergames are a way to practice responses and identify gaps in preparedness and response plans. Participants can see what unexpected decisions they might face and whether they can communicate across departments while under attack.

Every year, nearly 1,000 banks and other financial institutions take part in CAPP — Cyber Attack (against) Payment Processes — an event put on by the Financial Services Information Sharing and Analysis Center, a nonprofit industry group formed by financial companies to share information about cyberthreats.

"It's one thing to have your cyber incident playbook ready to go, but practicing realistic drills based on current and anticipated threats is the best way to be prepared," said FS-ISAC CEO Bill Nelson. "Over the past five years, thousands of security practitioners and corporate teams have benefited from these exercises. We've carefully crafted and calibrated each exercise to help test existing preparation, help security teams engage across their organizations and identify areas for enhancement."
Simkin says that some cybercriminals have developed complex underground economies over the past decade, with "boardrooms" better organized and equipped than many companies.
"These are often serious people with serious goals," Simkin said, particularly groups out to steal intellectual property, medical records and identification information that they can sell.
Hackers are developing malware that can change Internet Explorer security settings, go into "sleep mode" for 10 hours to avoid detection or outsmart off-the-shelf security programs.

To defeat the sophisticated attacks, Simkin says that enterprises are embracing a security platform that combines next-generation firewalls, URL filtering, threat and endpoint protection and other strategies.
It's not just security companies that are getting into the game.

Consulting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers has a new hacking simulator called "Game of Threats" for corporate clients such as banks and retailers. The game not only makes the experience of a cyberattack real, but it also gives executives insight as they assume the role of hacker and defender, PwC global cybersecurity leader David Burg told IBD.

The law firm Cooley, with 850 lawyers across 12 offices in the U.S, Europe and China, has joined FBI agents and other security experts to offer clients training through simulated cybergames. And teams from Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the University of Cambridge began staging a cyberwar in January in an exercise to learn by stealing secrets from each other's computers.Security software giant Symantec unleashes plenty of its own cyberattacks, but they are simulated assaults designed to immerse clients in a chaotic world.The company thrusts chief executives and employees of all stripes into simulated attacks so they can learn how to make quick, often hard decisions that might one day determine if their business suffers a major data breach or takes a huge financial hit.Like war games that the military uses to prepare for combat, interactive games and simulations are becoming part of defense arsenals aimed at helping companies and other organizations cope with increasingly complex threats.Symantec (SYMC) is rolling out a cloud-based, hands-on cybersecurity simulation that customers can access from anywhere and engage in realistic training scenarios, CEO Michael Brown told IBD."We have been expanding our offerings for customers who find security a pretty complex area and would like some help managing that," Brown said.
